{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 14, 2010", "reviewerID": "A18O9T2NZ268HC", "asin": "B0009P66Z4", "reviewerName": "J. Williams", "reviewText": "A little history first: about 5 years ago I bought an Invicta 8926 to get started in the world of automatic watches. It lived up to the rave reviews I had read online and I was very pleased with its quality and performance. However, 5 years is about the shelf life for any automatic watch before an overhaul is necessary (it employs a mechanical engine after all). This costs anywhere from $150 to $200 and it's a procedure just as necessary to keep a Rolex running well as a Seiko or, well, an Invicta. Along with needing routine servicing my old Invicta had become pretty beat up from years of hard use--camping, hiking, rafting, swimming, and so on--and much as I like the watch I just couldn't justify spending two to three as mucch on repairs as I originally paid for the watch.\n\nSo I decided to get a new Invicta but wanted something a little different than the classic Submariner look and thought I'd take a chance on this model. I've had it for a week and am very impressed. The scalloped bezel and markings on the bezel insert are derived from the design of Omega dive watches and so offer a variation on the Rolex theme. The 9094 is not exactly original but it is unique insofar as it combines features from several classic dive watch styles. Also, as far as I know, the gleaming, rather than brushed, center links of the bracelet are a feature unique to Invicta dive watches. I think it's a great touch. It also looks like Invicta has made some improvements over the years in terms of design. The crown guards are much less clunky than on my 8926 and it sounds like the rotor spins much more easily. The latter is just my impression. Also, the face of the 9094 picks up the light beautifully and, like other reviewers, I have to say that pictures simply don't do the watch justice. It's running very accurately, a bit fast perhaps but this is par for the course for mechanical watches and it should settle down in the next couple of months.\n\nI have one complaint: the bezel was pretty stiff out of the box but a couple of drops of Tri-Flow lubricant placed in the seam between the bezel and the body of the watch loosened it up nicely.\n\nAll in all: I highly recommend this watch. At $70 and with free shipping it's an astonishing deal for a high quality timepiece.", "summary": "Very impressive . . .", "unixReviewTime": 1279065600}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "04 29, 2010", "reviewerID": "A2SYAQXJGRY3XE", "asin": "B0009P66Z4", "reviewerName": "zanypoet", "reviewText": "This is my everyday watch.  It is good looking, well-made (for the price) and durable thus far. Only con is that it seems to gain couple seconds a day, therefore, at the end of the month, it is about minute or two fast -  I suppose it's better than  being slow but this is expected from a non-quartz movement type of watches that use unadjusted automatic movement.  It's a trade-off for not having the need to replace the battery every few years.  If you are like me and like to wear different watches for different occasions, auto-movement watches can be a pain unless you invest in auto-winder or two.\n\nI disagree with some people; I think Invicta watches in general (I have several Invictas) have decent bands that are nicely finished and have sufficient heft to them. Compared to comparable Seiko 5 automatic watches, Seikos have cheap, light weight, rough feel to them, although the Seiko 5 are also a good choice for a daily beater - their bands tend to give out long before their auto-movements do. These Pro Diver series that ape Rolex/Omega design are the ones that put Invicta on the map in the watch world.\n\nAlthough the style is easy to copy, customer service apparently is not as noted by many user here and other watch forums. But then, if I get several years of trouble-free use out them, I'm happy. If you want the legendary service, you gonna have to pony up for a real thing (Rolex) through its authorized dealer.", "summary": "Stylish, affordable and durable", "unixReviewTime": 1272499200}

{"image": ["https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71+XdjFFIgL._SY88.jpg"], "overall": 1.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "07 12, 2015", "reviewerID": "A2DQ7TPAS1EZLO", "asin": "B0009PUPSS", "reviewerName": "Max", "reviewText": "The good is that this fan does push out an OK amount of air if it is close to you but that is where the positives end.  As others have pointed out, the magnet is not well glued into the base, and easily comes out.  The battery compartment lid, on the other hand, is quite difficult to remove.  For me, that is only the beginning of the issues.  It is a very heavy unit to be hanging onto the side of tent, especially with the D battery inside.  I tried to hand it toward the top of my Coleman tent, facing down, but after a minute or two the blade spun off of the shaft and ended up on the tent floor.  My biggest issue is that the metal piece that holds the magnet (the part that comes unglued) sticks out past the bottom of the fan.  This means that its semi-sharp corners dig into the tent material (see my photo).  To remove the fan, the instructions say to twist the metal plate off of the magnet, but doing this can also twist those corners into your material, thus causing damage to the tent.  I still use the fan but I had to do mods to it to make it functional including:\n*Roughing up the blade shaft with a file, and then epoxying the fan blade to the shaft.\n*Epoxying the magnet into the base\n*Taking the magnet holder to a bench grinder to make it sit under the surface of the fan base and then covering the base bottom with foil tape to make it smooth.\n\nIf someone could fix all of these negatives and design a new fan, it would be a great success.", "summary": "Not a good product", "unixReviewTime": 1436659200}

{"overall": 3.0, "vote": "4", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "09 30, 2010", "reviewerID": "A2Q979Z97Q1EKT", "asin": "B0009PUPSS", "reviewerName": "sh00bie", "reviewText": "I bought one of these last-second for a camping trip. It works pretty well. There's just one fan speed, the button is good, it moves a good amount of air but you can't get too far from it, and it's relatively quiet. The magnet on the bottom is MASSIVELY powerful for such a small, lightweight fan. I guess Coleman was worried a weaker magnet would cause this unit to fall off of things too easily. The metal plate is great for securing the fan to a tent wall, and the magnet redily locks onto metal tent poles or whatever. I've used it for probably 150 hours now and have only gone through 2 batteries, so it's pretty energy efficient.\n\nMy only complaint is that the material the main housing is made out of isn't as durable as it should be (especially with that big magnet working on it). There are two notches in the plastic base that the battery-door (which also holds the magnet) uses to close. One clip is broken on mine because the magnet held while the unit came away when I went to pull it off a tent pole. That's why only 3 stars. If Coleman made this out of more durable plastic (or built a more durable closing mechanism, it would be better.\n\nBut hey, it's cheap for what it is. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "4", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "07 2, 2010", "reviewerID": "A39V5ZJYM6TD", "asin": "B0009PUPSS", "reviewerName": "Valorie Spencer", "reviewText": "I bought 2 of these fans about 5 years ago. Sometimes I attach them to the canopy over our picnic table or just carry them.  We use these fans on every trip and I never worry about them falling or breaking or running out of juice.  I don't know what others are doing with their fans to have such poor performance.  I keep mine in a coffee can between trips, in a hot attic (w/o battery of course) and they work time and and time again with no problems.  I just pull off the propellers and put the pieces in the can.  Simple.  With the magnetic grip you can attach it right to the gear loft and enjoy a great breeze just like having a ceiling fan.  I love them.  By the way... you might think open blades are a safety issue but they are very gentle and stop the instant they encounter an obstruction.  I've stuck my fingers in them many times (as have my children) and they have been totally harmless.  The blade stops instantly and it doesn't hurt one bit.  It's kind of a good party joke. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 29, 2010", "reviewerID": "AB7DR7FWLMGZ9", "asin": "B0009PUPSS", "reviewerName": "steveski", "reviewText": "I almost didn't buy this fan after reading some of the bad reviews on Amazon but I needed a fan and needed it fast so I thought, what the heck. It runs on 2 D cell batteries and runs for quite a whole on those batteries which is good.  I found if you wanted air for just one person, this fan was excellent at doing that.  So if you've got 3 or 4 people in your tent, you will need 3 or 4 fans and position them over each person.  The magnet attachment feature works very nicely and holds securely and is also easy to take off when you're done and tearing down camp.  The small footprint of the thing is nice too.  It's not too heavy and doesn't take up much space.\n\nSo overall, read the reviews on Amazon but realize that for the price and size of this thing, it works well and does it's job, just don't expect \"huge industrial fan\" type performance.", "summary": "Very nice fan", "unixReviewTime": 1277769600}
{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "136", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 3, 2007", "reviewerID": "AGHBU1UWQBW2Z", "asin": "B0009PUQG4", "reviewerName": "D. Hardy", "reviewText": "This is a review as well as some suggestions for the other reviewers.\n\n1) The rainfly does cover the windows if you align it / center it correctly.\n\n2) It has excellent vetntilation.  The cealing does not have a closeable nylon covers inside the tent.  This is because it is a 3 season tent.  If you were able to close it to keep dust out you would find that the tent would be wet from condensation inside on the inside.  So the cealing is mesh to let warm air and moisture excape.  The rainfly keeps moisture out.\n\nIf the cealing had zipper covering over the mesh,it would be a 4 season tent useable in winter.\n\nThe tent sets up easy and served us well in our first weekend camoing in it.  We did not get any real rain so I cant comment on its waterproof effectiveness.  But it is gaurenteed waterproof.\n\nI love the headroom and the zippers opperated smoothly without a snag.\n\nI'm happy with it. I honestly thought that we were going to get wet.  This tent does what it says.\n\nUpdate 2009\n\nOk it is now 2009, the rainfly ripped last year but Coleman sent me a new replacement at no charge. Suggestion, you don't need to tighten the 2 side rain fly cords so tight just enough so they are away from the tent. You should however tighten the 4 corner rain fly cords snug, this help keep the rainflt and tent stable and keep pressure off the 2 side rain fly cords where rips occurred. Follow this and you should not tear your rain fly. It rained all weekend while camping this weekend. 2 nights very hard and not a drop on us. third season and the tent still has no issues. I buy the lowest grade unleaded gasoline that I can find, usually from the local truck stop.  To ensure that the fuel is free of water or other\ncontaminants, I purchased a filter funnel on Amazon. The Fuel Funnel is the Mr. Funnel AF1CB Fuel Filter, at the following link\nhttps://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000SOFLHK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1\n\nAfter my purchase of the RUG, (Regular Unleaded Gas), I use the funnel to pour some fuel from the Gas Can into a 2-quart clear\nglass bottle.  Any water and contaminants stay in the funnel and only the gasoline, with additives, go into the bottle.  The water\ncontaminants remaining in the funnel can be emptied into a pail for disposal.  The filtered gasoline captured in the 2-quart container can be again\nfiltered by using the Coleman filtering Funnel for adding fuel to the stove and the remainder poured into empty fuel bottles for later use.\n\nSo, after using RUG for a few months, I've not experienced any problems with the additional filtering process.\n\nThe stove lights up fast and allows me to adjust the flame from furnace blast down to a fine simmer with no problems.", "summary": "Nice Dependable stove for use just about anywhere outdoors!", "unixReviewTime": 1517529600}

Six of them cost us approximately $30/year and we get 4 to 6 eggs a day every day for 30 days every month (That equates to 10 cartons a month...9 of which we generally give away and occasionally sell at the Farmer's Market if we have too many). {"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 5, 2013", "reviewerID": "A1D3PI43C4T7CI", "asin": "B0009PUR0E", "reviewerName": "A. Lee", "reviewText": "I have both Coghlan's and Coleman's dozen egg container, and after using both camping my opinion is that Coghlan's is better. It's because of little things, but they stood out to me. First the handle of the Coghlan's is a little stiffer than Coleman's, so it doesn't bend as much before the container opens. Second, using extra large eggs I noticed that eggs rattled around more in the Coleman container than in the Coghlan's. And finally the Coghlan's has one hinge running almost the entire width of the container, while the Coleman's has 4 narrow plastic straps for hinges. These are little differences, but my perception is that Coghlan's lays flatter, opens easier and provides better protection for the eggs.", "summary": "Coghlan's is better than Coleman's", "unixReviewTime": 1383609600}

{"overall": 3.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 18, 2012", "reviewerID": "A22BGI38W7Q9X9", "asin": "B0009PUR0E", "reviewerName": "PWTSM", "reviewText": "I'm being generous giving it 3 stars. I think it's poorly designed.\n\nI bought this egg container thinking it would keep uncooked eggs from rattling around in my cooler. But I found that even using the largest eggs I could find in the store (jumbo) there was enough room in each compartment to allow the jumbo eggs to move and rattle around. I did not toss the case around or hit lots of bumps on the road (as I carried the cooler in my car) to see if the uncooked eggs would break - sorry, I just didn't feel like tempting fate and cleaning up the mess. But I'm not confident they would not break since there is so much movement of the eggs inside the case, and since there are \"nibs\" the eggs bump against. In other words, the inside of the egg holder is not completely smooth on both sides. See my photos above for close up of the inside.\n\nThen I thought I can still use it to hold hard boiled eggs because I don't have to fear hard boiled eggs cracking and breaking and making a mess. But that's not good for me because I want to peel the eggs before putting them in the case, which is what I wanted to do so I could have easy to grab and eat hard boiled eggs as an easy snack while driving on a very long road trip. With peeled eggs you have to deal with these \"nibs\" cutting up your hard boiled eggs. As I mentioned above, the top of half of the case has these annoying tiny \"nibs\" in it (can't think of a better word to describe them, see my photos for details) and the nibs poke and pierce the peeled eggs, which allows the introduction of bacteria into the eggs. These annoying nibs appear to be there to hold the eggs in place, but they don't (peeled or not), as I mentioned above, even jumbo eggs (in the shell) rattle around loosely in the holder.\n\nA better design would have been a thin plastic tongue instead of the nibs. The plastic tongue could act like tiny spring board, holding any egg in place. The trick would be to make sure the pressure of the plastic spring would not break a raw egg. But once that was done right, you could put virtually any egg inside (any size, peeled or not), the tiny smooth \"spring board\" would adjust to any size egg, and it would not rattle, crack, or puncture the eggs.\n\nAnd, the case/container can NOT stand up on it's own due to the tiny hinges. It must lay flat.\n\nThe design has one possible pro; the clasps are very basic and seem sturdy. The best way to get the case open easily is to pry open the handles (separating them from each other). This is a good design, if you want to make sure the case does not pop open easily, on its own or by small children. But, for someone with a disability or arthritis, opening the case would be difficult.\n\nBottom line. I think overall this case was poorly designed and a waste of money. Especially since I now have a plastic container I'll rarely (if ever) use that I may end up giving away or putting in the recycle bin. There are other brands of egg holders but I won't buy another one by mail because the coast of returning is not worth the hassle. Amazon is usually good about returns, but only if an item is defective, and I don't think defective \"design\" or poor design qualifies for free returns. My loss. I'll be more careful next time with items that need to \"fit\" properly.\n\nThese are the measurements (see photos also):\nWidth - 7.5\"\nLength w/o handle - 5.75\"\nLength with handle - 6.75\"\nDepth - 3.25\"", "summary": "Eh, it's okay, but I would NOT recommend. Sorry I wasted money on it.", "unixReviewTime": 1350518400}
{"overall": 4.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 14, 2012", "reviewerID": "AH9LT35JJOL6C", "asin": "B0009PUR0E", "reviewerName": "Kim", "reviewText": "This is a great egg \"nest\" for taking whole (hard boiled or raw) eggs on the go if you take them camping I would suggest that you seal the eggs & container in a plastic bags first, then put them in your cooler. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "66", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 5, 2006", "reviewerID": "A3EQ2ODWLGDAPZ", "asin": "B0009PUQGE", "reviewerName": "Brandon Solomon", "reviewText": "I just returned from the deep woods and found that this pump was an absolute essential item to the trip. It took me less than 2min to fully inflate a full sized mattress.\n\nWhen coupled with the coleman 4D pump, it took only 6min to fully inflate a king sized bed. The two pumps together were a perfect combo. If you are inflating more than one bed, you can use the battery, or car pump to get the beds to a certain point, then use the manual pump to finish the job. This pump comes with a variety of nozzles for every bed type in the coleman line, so you won't have to worry about being without comfort or having to look for other accessories.\n\nWhen it was time to deflate and pack up, I found that by placing the hose on the other air point, I could suck the air from the mattress easily and get it to the point where I could roll it back into the bag without hassle.\n\nI would highly recommend this pump for all coleman air mattresses.", "summary": "Essential", "unixReviewTime": 1157414400}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 27, 2015", "reviewerID": "A3EXKUYZCUT9LM", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "Bill", "reviewText": "I like to have multiple options for cooking in emergencies or camping, so I did some research on these stoves. After deciding to try one out, I picked one of these up lightly used on fleabay for $26.  I can't see any reason to overpay for anything.  As far as some people having problems with these stoves, I just can't imagine it.  This little stove is pretty awesome. If you take the time to make sure your stove is properly pressurized, it runs like a champ. It's very efficient with the fuel use too.  I got an entire weekend camping trip's worth of cooking for my family of 4 out of a single fill-up of Coleman fuel. That leads me to another important point: If you don't want your generator gumming up, don't run cheap unleaded gas in this thing. Sure, you can do it, but it's like running poor grade fuel in your car.  You want to spring for the pure, clean stuff this stove was meant to run best on. If you have the good sense to set the stove up on a flat level surface as you should, you'll have no trouble using a full sized cast iron skillet on this stove. I did it.  My wife even heated her up some water for her tea in a mil spec canteen cup on this thing. I thought she was nuts, but it worked and did it very quickly.  She did use my pot glove to remove her cup for safety's sake.  My stove seems to have no problem adjusting anywhere from a low simmering flame to a blast furnace.  I honestly thought it would be a high or low only option, but you can finesse the controls to get the output you want.  It's not featherlight, but it's not a boat anchor either.  I'd say it's worth its weight in your gear. It really isn't huge, coming in at under 6 inches tall and about 5 1/2 inches or so across at the base, but it has a heft to it being made of steel.  I guess the best praise I can give this stove is that once she used it my wife didn't give me crap about buying it.  That's the official seal of approval in a married man's house.  Mine was made in August of '03, so these things can apparently last a good while with proper care.", "summary": "Impressive little stove, but shop around.", "unixReviewTime": 1435363200}

Next, when you lift the pot (using tongs... the red hot handle will burn through gloves), it tips right over and dumps the boiling water everywhere. It just hangs freely from that wire handle and since it's so crudely made, is unbalanced and tips its contents out as soon as its lifted.\n\nAfter you've burned yourself and lost all your boiled water, you might try to cook something in the frying pan. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "11 11, 2014", "reviewerID": "A1FTJK3B3N57SG", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "Silver Hooligan", "reviewText": "I had an ancient Coleman Peak One for backpacking.  I started bike touring and for some reason thought I should get an MSR stove because of all the hype about how light and wonderful they are.  Pfffft.\n\nThe Peak One was almost 15 years old and I never had any issues, ever, of it starting.  It always worked well, fired up regardless of how cold it was.  Burns efficiently.  Takes a beating as far as being accidentally dropped, and being jostled around in backpacks or panniers.\n\nThe MSR was temperamental.  It leaked.  Wasn't as efficient, pretty much burned at high no matter what, couldn't simmer.  Then, during my trip it died, completely.  I woke up to a 48 degree morning and couldn't make my coffee or breakfast.  That was it.\n\nI sold my Peak One, so I had to replace it.  I opted for getting this Coleman to have the flexibility of burning gasoline when I was traveling through remote areas that didn't have white gas.  Yes, it's bigger, and a tad heavier than an MSR, but keep in mind MSR you need to have the fuel bottles and they don't include that in the weight.\n\nWhen you consider the fuel bottles into the MSR weight and space it takes, the Coleman isn't that much heavier or space hogging.  Considering it's reliability and sturdiness, I think it's worth every ounce.  Plus you have the option to simmer. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "60", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "11 25, 2009", "reviewerID": "A6GMEO3VRY51S", "asin": "B0009PUQIM", "reviewerName": "microjoe", "reviewText": "PROS: This pot is very sturdy, paint is high quality, strong handle, lid has a lip that if installed properly should not fall out. Has a nice chrome ring at the top of the pot where the lid fits in, a spot that is vulnerable to chip in most enamel pots. This smaller model is also good for heating water for tea, hot chocolate, and dishes. I have one for that purpose, and the 14 cup model for coffee. I prefer percolators over drip coffeemakers. I have never had to replace a stove top percolator because it was broken, but have owned countless expensive drip coffeemakers. Breakable carafes, clock to reset, takes up counter-space, buttons to fuss with, filters to replace. My simple pot lasts years longer, (I have one from the 1940's), and the clean-up and maintenance is simpler.\n\nCONS: Like a drip, there is a learning curve. This type of pot does not have a water marker for example. But there is a simple instruction sheet in the box. Next, many of the new percolator pots have strainer baskets that are really flimsy in design, including both the Coleman and the GSI brand. The real problem is the upright stem, it tilts over if you know what I mean. If they improved the basket assembly with a heavier grade aluminum, or stainless steel I think it would solve the problem. I replaced the upright stem and basket in mine with an old sturdy one from a old pot I found at a yard sale. For some weird reason, most of the manufacturers basket is the same size, no matter how big the pot is. Most stainless steel kitchen (non camp) models have a stainless basket. Last, on models with the glass dome, some folks can break them. They sell replacements in 2 sizes at Amazon.com for less than a pack of paper filters.  The good news is that Coleman will mail you a replacement dome for free if you break it, email them through their web site seems to be the best way to get this done. I am guessing they would also replace the filter?\n\nTIPS: Wet the inside of the basket before you put grounds in, to help prevent grounds from going through the holes. Use a medium ground blend. If you plan to use it on a camp fire, soap the outside of the pot and let dry for a minute before placing on the fire, to prevent soot stains. If you do it every time, it will stay looking like new.\n\nRECOMMENDATION: Coleman also sells a 12 cup and a 14 cup in this shape, the 14 cup is my favorite and looks identical with the exception of the additional glass dome to monitor the coffee percolating. The 12 cup is Stainless Steel, and also has a dome. Their competitor GSI makes an 8 cup in red or blue.", "summary": "Percolator vs the Drip", "unixReviewTime": 1259107200}

{"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 28, 2013", "reviewerID": "A3QXUTBOXM7VF2", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "L-Dub", "reviewText": "The unit can be a little tricky to get lit with several steps of priming and opening the valve in a certain combination.  Once it is lit you have to constantly adjust it to try to keep it at a certain flame size, and you can forget about keeping it at a low flame setting as it will go out.  That is because the flame vaporizes the gas in the copper hose that runs over it and if the flame is not hot enough it goes out.  If you open the valve for more gas it increases the flame size initially but then as the hose gets hotter and vaporizes more fuel the flame continues to grow. The unit is high quality and durable but it is just outdated technology.  If you are old fashioned and more comfortable with something you are already familiar with, or if you absolutely need to use liquid fuel for some reason, then this is a good stove.  I returned it and got a propane stove that is so much easier to use and maintain a consistent flame size.  Just turn it on, light it, and adjust the flame size, that simple.  Plus, propane seems to be more readily available than Coleman fuel, perhaps that is because liquid fuel stoves are a dying breed.", "summary": "It's a hassle, propane is much easier", "unixReviewTime": 1377648000}

{"overall": 2.0, "vote": "3", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 29, 2013", "reviewerID": "A15DGSXL2W8I6A", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "Neato", "reviewText": "I grew up camping with Coleman white gas stoves and have used them for nearly 50 years. The 533 is constructed and operated basically the same as one I have that was made in 1947. I had a 533 for a few years and ran it on unleaded just to see how it would do. Like others have found, the generator clogged (repeatedly). Easy to clean but I don't want to have to take something apart in the field when it's 30 degrees outside while I really want a cup of coffee. It did work great when it was working though.\n\n When I was younger, I didn't mind the fiddling that's always required to get a gasoline Coleman stove running; just part of the camping 'ritual' I'd enjoyed my whole life. However, my experience with the 533 literally 'left me cold' a couple of times. I spoke to the owner of a local Coleman repair station who told me that if I wanted reliability, I should stick with stoves/lanterns painted red or green (in other words, older models) and follow basic maintenance procedures for them. In his experience, even those running the dual-fuel models on Coleman fuel experienced less overall reliability than older models in good condition.\n\n While I still enjoy firing up my old gasoline Colemans once in a while, I don't recommend any type (especially not the 533) to those who desire a hassle-free camp stove. Bring a backup cooking option if you can.\n\n Coleman makes a great single-burner propane camp stove (Model No. 2000004125) that I've been using regularly for several years now. It beats the 533 in so many categories that it would take too long to list them in a short review here.", "summary": "Not for everyone...", "unixReviewTime": 1364515200}

From air mattresses, to pool toys, this pump has become my first choice.  It also (almost as quickly) can remove air from said mattress when I'm trying to get it flat to put back in the box. And the biggest issue is hose attaches to the handle on the pump instead of to the base.  This means the hose moves, up and down with me, as I pump.  I occasional pull the end out of what ever I'm trying to inflate, and find the hose tends to \"get in my way\" as it's moving up and down with me. I fried up a cast iron skillet full of a favorite potato dish I like to make when camping - the stove might have used a half-ounce of fuel, start to finish. My Esbit alcohol burner would use 5 times that much fuel at least, and doesn't put out near as much heat. I have an older two-burner Coleman camp stove that a friend gave me over 25 years ago. The only thing it has going for it over this one is two burners - that, and a wide, stable base and built-in wind screens on the sides. Those primary thoughts were confirmed with the first test lighting of the 285-700 lanterns.\n\nEach primed easily; each lit with easy; each gave off more than sufficient light for reading under the darkest conditions.  As with every other Coleman product we own, we know these lights will give years of service whether we are hunting, fishing or need the light in an emergency situation.\n\nI am particularly happy that no longer will we have to stock propane canisters but have the ability of using either the old stand-by, white gas, or if the need arises the lowest grade of unleaded gasoline. I am equally impressed that the burning time for the liquid fuel will be around 10 hours (set at medium intensity) which is considerably greater than one could ever hope for from a propane canister.\n\nSome may find that needing to \"pressurize\" the fuel tank (and keeping it pressurized), on these lanterns is a hassle but for me it is nothing short of a throw-back to the good ol' days when, as a small lad, Dad took me fishing or when the family spent a week camping. {"reviewerID": "A3M1RHIREM5YX7", "asin": "B0009PUR2M", "reviewerName": "Seth Johnson", "verified": false, "reviewText": "I cannot recommend this lantern more strongly than other products in this space. The propane lanterns are a post-sale continuing revenue stream for the manufacturer, to the detriment of a camper looking for conveniently-accessible fuel. In other words, those lanterns benefit the manufacturer by continuing sales of propane tanks that are non-recyclable and non-refillable.\n\nThis lantern works extremely well. Gasoline is a convenient fuel, but people have encouraged me to use the white gas.\n\nIt's durable and does not spill fuel if it is knocked over. The propane lanterns are frequently knocked over because they stand so tall. The center of gravity of this lantern is much lower thanks to the density of the fuel.\n\nIt can be difficult to light without long matches. {"reviewerID": "A1GXRUK2GVNHZ7", "asin": "B0009PUR2M", "reviewerName": "frogstomper", "verified": true, "reviewText": "My parents had an old Coleman 'Pump' lantern.  As I remember it had only a single mantle and didn't give off a very brilliant light, and being a youngster I always considered it a REAL PAIN to pump up the pressure...and that was usually my assigned duty.  I did it, though, but when I got older and had my own family I bought a propane lantern...the Coleman NorthStar.  It was great, but now that I am really, really old I hate carting around those expensive metal propane bottles that are ALWAYS in the way.\n\nI don't know why, but I was attracted to this Coleman double mantle, dual fuel model lantern.  Quickly adding up the cost of gas these days and comparing that against the cost of the 16.4 oz propane bottles, I decided that pumping wasn't all that difficult after all, and I seem to have a lot more time to do that than I used to have as a kid.  In my area unleaded regular gasoline is about one tenth the cost of an equivalent amount of bottled propane.  Please don't yell at me and call me cheap...I'm just more conservative now (hate to give up a penny I don't have to).\n\nThe lantern works perfectly, the light is very bright and can be adjusted down to gently subtle.  One tankful of gasoline lasts about two long evenings, and the pump even gives me a little exercise.  Get one...you'll enjoy it, and throw away the propane guzzler.  (I also mothballed my propane two-burner stove and went for the Coleman two-burner, dual fuel stove; WITH A PUMP...!!!", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "05 28, 2011", "summary": "Back to basics", "unixReviewTime": 1306540800}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "07 18, 2012", "reviewerID": "A2Q1ITOM6BNIGZ", "asin": "B0009PUQGE", "reviewerName": "Sandy Gardener", "reviewText": "I can't believe how many reviewers complain about the amount of effort it takes to inflate an air mattress with this pump. Let's face it, Americans are getting soft. This pump is optimally designed with a bore of about 3 1/2\" and a stroke of 12\", which combine to create about the right amount of air moved per stroke and input of muscular effort. It takes about five minutes to air up a twin size 8\" thick air mattress. The pump is all plastic, but is sturdy enough, and is a heck of a value for the price. One word of advice: sit down while pumping, contrary to the picture on the box. As far as valve adapters, the pump comes with four adapters, including a \"boston valve\" adapter which is an industry standard. Blame the other air mattress manufacturers if they have some weird proprietary valve.", "summary": "Suck It Up Whiners", "unixReviewTime": 1342569600}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 12, 2012", "reviewerID": "A1ZHDVB3QS5X83", "asin": "B0009PUQGE", "reviewerName": "Fir Tree", "reviewText": "Last year we were caught in a camping situation where we had no electricity and no way other than taking turns blowing up an air mattress by hand like you would a balloon. They lack fine mid-range temperature control, versus the Feather 400 model, are quite temperamental to cold-starts unless on high and kept on high during the cook. The smaller tank on the 533 model means more frequent in-meal pumping of the fuel tank, and don't dare DREAM of burning gasoline in the stove, regardless what the sales marketing says - because there are NUMEROUS COLEMAN WARNINGS inside the box of what it will do to your stove and its generator...they REALLY don't want you burning unleaded gasoline in their multi-fuel stove (hey, Coleman, don't make sure a big deal out of it in the box paperwork, if you are going to sell it as an intentional dual-fuel stove in the marketing phase, ok?)\n\nOverall, it is dependable to fire and burn, but hey, so are a few sticks of wood - and it is about as controllable for a fire as two sticks burning. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "49", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "05 20, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1UJJPJ7MEVCSZ", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "BigLew", "reviewText": "This is a great little stove, I have 2, they make a great accessory to  the 2 the burner stoves (425 or 413). While car camping I can make coffee on this 533 while the rest of breakfast cooks on the 2 burner one.\nI have never cooked food with Regular Unleaded Gas (RUG) but I have used one of these stoves with RUG to melt wax for making candles it seemed to burn just as well as the camp fuel (aka white gas) .\nThis stove cranks out a lot of heat on high, too much really for the smaller pots that will fit on this stove. So I use it on medium to low mostly.  Since this is a single burner it probably isn't to wise to use a big pot and have it tip over.  I rigged up a home made device, from an old barbeque grate, to hold larger pots, but it is not foldable. I wish Coleman would design and make an accessory stand or stove grate for the Sportster II with collapsible legs that the stove could be placed under and a larger pot safely on top.  Hey, Coleman I would be willing to test market such a device!\nThis is a great stove, not quite as well made as the old 502's but still very good. I have had one since '99 and the other since '05 w/ no problems and use them frequently. It is indeed a bit tricky to get this stove to simmer and it doesn't simmer very well, but it will simmer. Trick is is to get it hot first, then turn it down to a simmer, the generator (tube across burner) must be hot to vaporize the liquid. If the simmer does start to go out remove the pot turn it back to high for minute or so and then back down to simmer and repalce the pot or pan.\n\nBTW if using unleaded gas in this or any Coleman Dual Fuel appliance use regular 87 octane or less b/c it has less addidtives than premium or super grade gasoline. Also buy the gasoline from generic stations that don't offer the additive packages like the name brand stations. You're operating a stove not a car. Think about it, Coleman fuel (a.k.a. white gas) is basiacly a pure unleaded gasoline (naptha) with out all the additives designed for automotove gasoline. These additives are what plug up the generators so the less additives the better. Coleman fuel only has an octane rating of 55, there is no need to use high octane gas.  Besides do you really want to cook food with fuel that has more toxic chemicals than needed? Some reviewers that gave this stove low  marks said they used 93 high octane and then complained when it clogged up! If the generator does clog it can be user serviced and cleaned or new ones are of course available. It's your choice.", "summary": "Great stove", "unixReviewTime": 1305849600}

Plus I didn't want to drive my fellow campers crazy with the loud whinning sound of an electric pump.\n\nThis pump is ALL plastic, even the handle, but it seems pretty sturdy. There's two ports for the hose, one on each side of the handle (for inflation and deflation). The hose has two pins that lock into notches on the ports when you twist the hose on, so it won't come off during use. The other end of the hose comes with a built-in connector that fits most new Coleman air-beds, as well as two tethered adapters for smaller openings.\n\nThe pump is fairly large in capacity. Although it's only just over a foot tall, it's about as good as a much larger bicycle pump. Still, it doesn't take nearly as long as a foot pump to inflate the air-bed. Deflating does make a bit of a whistle, especially at the end, but the ability to pull out all the air and get the bed good and flat for rolling is awesome.\n\nThe only thing that could make this pump better is if it came with a bag to put it in to keep it protected and keep everything together. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "9", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 15, 2009", "reviewerID": "A18ECVX2RJ7HUE", "asin": "B0009PUQAU", "style": {"Color:": " Coleman Green"}, "reviewerName": "Willie", "reviewText": "The 533 continues the long line of dependable Sportster (not 'Sporter' Amazon) stoves.  This model can use unleaded gas in addition to white gas (Coleman fuel) because of the included generator (same part as a 433 stove, but if you use a 433 generator, you'll only be able to use white gas). I prefer white gas and never got good results with 87 octane (too much soot). This stove is NOT for backpacking unless your name is Varnell, a farm boy from Georgia, over six feet tall, 230 lbs., and can tote an M60 on cross-bayou treks with no problem. Good stove to keep in the truck or in the cabin. Dependable, fires up with little problem. Easy availability of spare parts. Not as sexy as a lightweight titanium butane/propane stove, nor as weight efficient as a good commercial or homebrew alcohol stove, but gets the job done. I purchased this set as a rudimentary set to use, and was supposed to be one of two people to bring dishes into camp. Well, they forget their set, so I was definitely glad I purchased one before we went camping. This set served my purposes well, and is definitely meant for one or two people, max. If you have a small group of people, or cook in batches, it can still do the trick, but it will just take longer. Im confident this mess kit should last me a while. Yes, it scratches easily and loses its shine quickly, but I really don't care about that since I only got it to function as a lightweight kit.\n\nThere are four main pieces in this mess kit: a small cup, frying pan, a shallow pot, and a shallow bowl. Drained the cooler once per day.  Mix of being in the car and outside in temps from 50-70.  Fantastic cooler.  Great alternative to the Yeti if you want a good camping cooler.\n\nPro tip:  Buy two blocks of ice, put them in a cooler.  Next line the inside of the cooler with a black garbage bag.  Now, line it with a second one.  The ice should be sitting below the garbage bags (outside of them).  Place your food inside the garbage bags.  That will keep your food from getting wet. {"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 5, 2012", "reviewerID": "ASREZFXN55U2R", "asin": "B0009PUPU6", "reviewerName": "James R.", "reviewText": "I bought the Coleman Tent Light for a recent camping trip, since it matched the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-Tent-Fan/dp/B0009PUPSS/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman Tent Fan</a>&nbsp;I had also ordered. The Coleman Tent Light runs on a pair of AA-cell batteries, and features a simple one on/off switch on the side. Like the Tent Fan, the Tent Light uses a magnetic mounting plate that goes on the outside of the tent wherever you choose to locate it, and the light goes on the inside, with the magnets holding it securely in place. You have to literally twist the metal plate to remove the light from its position, so it won't easily fall at random.\n\nThe light output isn't as much as you would expect by looking at the light. It wasn't very bright in pitch darkness; it had enough light to help me move around in my tent, but nowhere near as much light to read from. Because of the low light output, the price is a little high for what comes down to a camping \"night light\". I ended up turning it on at night to make it easier to locate my tent in the darkness, as it gave y orange tent a soft glow. That said, If you're looking to light up your tent you'll need to use a proper lantern instead, like I did.", "summary": "Not Bad, Not Bright, A Little Pricey For a \"Nightlight\"", "unixReviewTime": 1338854400}

I have a military issue 2-man tent, which I can't find a comparable commercial model but it has 3 poles that arch over the top to create the frame. I placed this light at the strongest junction where 2 of the poles met and even though this light feels a little heavy in the hand there was no sag to my tent. The magnets are strong, and when there's no material between the magnets and the metal bracket, trying to separate the two almost always results in the light cover coming off. This wasn't a problem taking if off the tent, and while it's in my pack I've taken to keeping the paper instructions between the magnet and the bracket which makes it easy to separate them without pulling the cover off.\n\nThis is also deisgned as more than just a tent light. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "05 27, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1VR62D823PC8G", "asin": "B0009PUPU6", "reviewerName": "Carlos Cortes", "reviewText": "I think many people already mentioned this product has pros and cons as everything in this life. Well, this tent light has positive and negative things. First of all, I use this product in a Coleman tent of about 8-feet x 8-feet. It is bright enough to help you during a night, not to read o play cards, just enough light to move within the tent. Consider that there is a new model with leds instead this krypton bulb but costs almost as double as this is. The advantage of having magnets (and a metal plate) to mount it on the tent gives you the advantage of putting it virtually in any place of the tent. Most of the lanterns have to be mounted (hang them) on the top of the tent, but this is practically to be mounted anywere in your tent. Particularly I place it right at the top of the tent's door.\n\nMaybe having two of them for my tent would be nice and bright enough if I put them in opposite walls, but I'm not gonna do that because I already own a Brunton Glorb Four LED Lantern, wich gives a poor light to be a four leds, but combining this and the Coleman is enough light.\n\nThe main cons I found in this Coleman tent light is its brightness, enough to see inside the tent but no more. Again consider that newest models of Led lanterns will give more brighter light than this on (but maybe they will cost more tha this one). It is heavy for backpacking but quite well in my case because I do car camping. So, again, consider that a Led Lanter can be smaller and lighter. As consequence of its weight, you have to be cautios were you place it, and consider that it will make your tent sag in that zone you place it.\n\nThe best thing of it is the idea of the magnets and the mounting plate. This idea gives you a kind of freedom to put this lamp in the best place according to your criteria and your needs and not only have a lamp/lantern on top of your tent.", "summary": "It helps", "unixReviewTime": 1306454400}

{"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "05 2, 2010", "reviewerID": "A15AA61MQK8DZW", "asin": "B0009PUPU6", "reviewerName": "dcn8v", "reviewText": "This lamp is easily installed on your tent. If you have a small tent it will work well.  Larger tents will need two or more lamps.  The lamp does feel heavy for its size due to the 4 AA batteries and the two magnets. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "64", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "05 27, 2008", "reviewerID": "AX6CRRFTE9V10", "asin": "B0009PUPU6", "reviewerName": "Mike", "reviewText": "The Coleman Tent Light is a great idea.  This wedge-shaped light is backed with two powerful magnets and a removeable metal mounting plate.  Take the mounting plate off, put the light wherever you want to in your tent, put the mounting plate on the outside of your tent behind the light and viola!  You now have light, and it easily clicks on and off with one hand, which is important when camping.  The magnets are strong enough to mount the light to either horizontal or verticle surfaces.  It takes AA batteries and it's easy to get the unit apart to put the batteries in or replace them.\n\nIn fact, it's too easy, and that is one of my complaints.  The magnets are so poweful that pretty much anytime I take the mounting plate off, the light comes apart, too.  I guess it's not that big a deal, but seems to me that it just could have been designed to avoid that.  Things that continually fall apart have that \"cheap\" feel to them, and that's not what I want to feel when I'm in the middle of the woods.  I want to have confidence in my gear!\n\nMy second \"complaint\" is that the light is also not that bright.  I put this in a four-person tent and it was just a little more dim than I would have preferred.  It was certainly bright enough to see and get ready for sleep; this is not going to be a reading lamp, though.\n\nAll-all-all, this is not a bad product and I'm happy I have it for the price at which it was sold.  I just wonder if there maybe isn't something a little better out there.", "summary": "A for Idea, B for Execution", "unixReviewTime": 1211846400}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "383", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "08 10, 2007", "reviewerID": "A38VQ2TIPPBKNN", "asin": "B0009PUPU6", "reviewerName": "Sir Charles Panther", "reviewText": "This is a really nice piece of camping kit, as it \"clips\" with the magnet to any part of your tent in seconds.  (It's got a pretty strong magnet bar, which goes on the outside of your tent, and the metal bracket of the light anchors it on the inside.)  At first I wondered if the tight contact of the light would cause the tent to leak, and so far the answer has been a very clear and dry no, on many tents of different fabric.\n\nThe light is incandescent, inside a traditional sealed bulb.  I have had no problem with the light or bulb in the 4+ years I've owned this light.  The lens diffuses the light nicely, so if you put this light at the crown of your tent, you will have light throughout.\n\nMy only problem with this unit is that it's kind of big and bulky.  It's not that heavy, even with the four AA batteries installed, but it's kind of large.  In a camping world in which we've got wind-up LED systems and increasingly smaller lights which provide more and more light, I would think that an up-tech'd version of this light could be smaller and throw out more light.  If you're doing backwoods trekking where every ounce counts, this is probably not the solution you need.  But if you're doing family camping, car camping, or going to camps that have existing tents (summer camps, scout camps), then this is a really fantastic piece of gear.\n\n----------\n\nUpdate, 24 July 2008\nNow about a year on, here are additional comments on this product:\n\nIt continues to function just fine, but I have one complaint.  I do not store this unit with batteries in it, so each time I go camping I open the case to install and then later remove the batteries.\n\n(The case opens by way of gently pinching the two sides together at the lamp's waist, between the on/off switch and the lower magnetic housing.  There are no locks, screws, springs or mechanical latches; the two parts of the lamp are kept together only by the plastic flex of the upper lamp housing itself.)\n\nAfter a year of easy and careful use the upper plastic housing around the pinch points has started to crack.  The unit still works just fine (I just got back from a week in the woods), but it's only a matter of time now until the housing splits or a large chunk of the plastic comes off, preventing the unit from coming together and thereby ruining it.\n\n----------------\n\nUpdate, 26 May 2009\nThe cracks at the waist are slightly bigger, and slowly growing.  The light still works fine, and just served me well on yet another campout, but the day is coming when that plastic housing breaks permanently, and this light will be finished.\n\n----------------\n\nUpdate, 8 October 2010\nAnother spring and summer gone, and this light continues to soldier on.  It's still got its original bulb and all other original parts.  No corrosion, no rust inside or out.  No clouding of the plastic lens.  The cracking of the waist area I mention above has stabilized somewhat, with no plastic pieces having come off. It still works great, and it'll be with me into another fall and winter of Scout camping.\n\n----------------\n\nUpdate, 2 June 2011\nGetting ready for another campout this weekend, and this light is packed and ready to go.  No changes since the last update, still working just fine.\n\n----------------\n\nUpdate, 19 October 2012\n\nMan, a perfect score for helpful votes--thank you, all.  This was an easy review to write for what has turned out to be a great product.\n\nI just broke it out of the attic for a camping trip tomorrow evening, and with four AA batteries dropped in, it still works like a charm.  There is no further degradation to the plastic, no flaking, discoloration, cracks or pieces coming off.  It is not brittle, but still gives nicely, and came apart and went back together just as easily as any time before.  It'll be lighting my tent tomorrow night, as it has on so many nights before.\n\nI see that there is a&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-LED-tent-light/dp/B004E4GB1U/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman LED tent light</a>&nbsp;now, for about $8 more.  I have not seen one in person nor tried one out, but if Coleman has applied the same characteristics to this new light as they did for this one, it'll be a winner.", "summary": "A Nice Piece of Kit, Somewhat Bulky", "unixReviewTime": 1186704000}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 30, 2014", "reviewerID": "A2YSBFX0HX9CZR", "asin": "B0009PUR4A", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "Alysia", "reviewText": "Perfect for my Scouts", "summary": "Five Stars", "unixReviewTime": 1414627200}
{"overall": 4.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 30, 2014", "reviewerID": "A2TGVL67XUJ4H3", "asin": "B0009PUR4A", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "Tom Desimone", "reviewText": "For the price, this is a fantastic cook kit for my purposes. I do a lot of backpacking in NY mountains, so that's the context of my usage. I use this kit with an&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/MSR-PocketRocket-Stove/dp/B00E1I36Q2/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">MSR PocketRocket Stove</a>. I've used this kit for about 3 years.\n\nI try to avoid cooking on the trail as much as possible just for the sake of convenience, but in the cold weather it's really nice to have a warm meal and a warm cup of coffee. So I can't speak to this product's usefulness for trail gourmands.\n\nMy go-to meal for backpacking is couscous. This is how it works out:\n\n1. Pour one 6oz box of couscous and seasoning in the skillet (with 1/4 of TVP sometimes), plus some olive oil.\n2. Boil water in the lidded pot.\n3. Pour boiling water over couscous (as much as can fit is perfect).\n4. Stir.\n5. Cover with bowl/lid, and then cover with bandana. (Colder weather = More insulation)\n6. Wait 5 minutes.\n7. Eat!\n\nAnd I'm left with only one vessel (the skillet) that needs real cleaning.\n\nI use the pot for boiling water only. This means that I never have to scrub it out on the trail, and that my morning coffee won't taste like garlic couscous. The plastic handle on the pot lid is a nice improvement over the metal lid handle on older sets.\n\nIt's nice to have a separate cup instead of drinking out of an all-purpose pot. Allows me to have a hot drink while eating a warm meal, and - again - a drink that doesn't taste like a previous meal.\n\nPros:\n1. The four separate vessels may seem anti-minimalist, but the convenience is worth it\n2. Light as light can be\n3. Heats up very quickly\n4. Packs together neatly\n5. Don't abuse it, and it lasts for many years\n6. Inexpensive\n\nCons:\n1. Aluminum cup will burn your mouth if filled with very hot liquid. The metal conducts the heat too well. I've found that putting a small piece of electrical tape where my lips meet the cup solves this, but it must be reapplied before each trip. Consider replacing with plastic cup.\n2. Along those lines, it does not hold heat well. You'll want to put something beneath it and cover it with a bandana or something assuming your food has to sit off the flame for awhile before eating.\n3. No carrying case included. I tie it up in a bandana and then use the bandana as a potholder/insulator when I eat.\n4. The material is delicate. If this goes in the bottom of your backpack all day, it will get bent and dented. The good news is that it's easy enough to bend back in to shape (to some extent).\n\nFor me, this is perfect. But it depends on your cooking style and your needs. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "02 4, 2013", "reviewerID": "A3QC0PB3XGEFLH", "asin": "B0009PUPUG", "reviewerName": "Brian Grzymkowski", "reviewText": "I've used these stands for several years now for both my camping grill and stove.  When all is said and done, they do work, but you have to be very careful when using them.  On the plus side, they're very lightweight, pack up small, and are adjustable.  The problem is they are also a bit flimsy.  With no back or tabletop, your grill or stove rests gingerly across two thin beams.  With the lid open and a propane tank attached, most grills and stoves are already a far cry from balanced.  Toss in a rickety stand and some uneven ground and you've got a very hot balancing act on your hands.  A modest bump would be enough to send your stove or grill crashing to the ground.  I've had a few close calls and I'm generally pretty careful.  Had my grill fall once before it was lit.  Would recommend it only for those times where portability matters and there's nothing sturdier available to work with. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "8", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 19, 2013", "reviewerID": "A35W3JQYP0M655", "asin": "B0009PUR72", "style": {"Size:": " 1 Pack"}, "reviewerName": "John Thomas", "reviewText": "I have owned a number of these Coleman mugs for years. In fact I have one that is over 12 years old that went on every hike I ventured on over those dozen years.  (It has since been retied and enjoying the good life on a shelf).  These mugs are not the kind that will appeal to everyone for sure.  You have to have a real nostalgia thing going to enjoy it them, or just like the feel of it over an open fire on a cold morning or evening.  Sure the handle gets hot if the coffee is really steaming, but it dissipates quickly if used outdoors where it has always been in service with me.  The number of times I have used it at home over the fire place the hot handle has never bothered me since I don't get the coffee as hot as over a campfire.\n\nAs to some of the other more critical reviews of this about it chipping and peeling, I think one of the fallacies about old time enamel mugs like these is that they are prit' near indestructible which is not true.  Just because they are made of metal you can't toss them on a pile of rocks or expose them to all manner of rough weather.  I've always treated mine like they are made of out glass and done just fine with them.  No doubt some of the reviewers here that had their mugs peel and whatnot were as careful as I am and still saw their mugs fail or fall apart way too fast.  All I can tell you is that the number I have owned have held up well for me and I have never had a problem with them. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "468", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "01 18, 2017", "reviewerID": "ABBA5RERGQHVC", "asin": "B0009PURKO", "style": {"Color:": " Black"}, "reviewerName": "Zantos", "reviewText": "For what you pay and what you get with this cooler, it is of EXCELLENT value. Those Yeti's may be amazing but those prices are just absurd and cannot be justified by anyone who isn't literally a mountain man or a hunter who needs ice not to freeze for 10 days. Most of us normal guys who go weekend camping, don't fall into either of those categories, and so we turn our Yeti search into a \"what cooler is also awesome but doesn't cost me my first born child\" search.\n\nI've only ever owned Coleman and Igloo coolers and so that search began with those two. When I was underwhelmed with what Igloo had out there, I made the switch to Coleman and was immediately impressed by this cooler.\n\nMy search criteria where as follows;\nMetal hinges (had an old Igloo with plastic hinges finally blow out on me, granted it was a 30yr old cooler so props to Igloo)\nMetal handles\nSolid handle and/or locking mechanism\nHard lined and o-ring sealed\n\nThe Coleman Steel-Belted Cooler fit all of these criteria and was available for the modest price of $80. I deemed the 54 quart to be of substantial size based on the \"can capacity\" that is listed in the description. I love that Coleman knows their customers and knows we will want to know how many beer...I mean soda cans, that the cooler can fit.\n\nTrust me folks, I've beaten this thing up to heck and back on my camp trips and it has performed admirably. {"overall": 2.0, "vote": "2", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 18, 2014", "reviewerID": "A3LO72OXJOI6ID", "asin": "B0009PUR4A", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "joel750", "reviewText": "I owned one of these mess kits back when I started to go camping and this was the only kit that I can afford. It was OK for it's purpose but back then, I didn't know any better. Back then I had the notion that all camping equipments are pretty much the same that it just all depend son how you use and utilize it. Now for the life of me, I couldn't understand on how I managed to burn frying scrambled eggs which is a No-Brainer for everyone which I cooked on this mess kit. Little did I know that the workmanship of this mess kit is sub par at best: that it's made for beginners and Boys scouts in particular made as their first kit. So I just accepted the fact that I can never fry perfectly good eggs with this until i came to a Army Surplus store  in Berkeley and found my first REAL Military mess kit which is the German Bundeswehr mess kit. It was $9.95 and I said \"Why Not!?\" I tested that and immediately i found out that having the RIGHT gear really makes all the difference! I fried a couple of scrambled and sunny side up eggs on that mess kit that now I know how to fry it right and it's perfect every time! Right after that, I decide to donate this Coleman mess kit to charity and vowed never again to use inferior-made products. It was worth a little from when I used it but I wasn't satisfied from the results from it. And just like everything else in life...you actually get what you pay for, Using a Military mess kit against this is like night and day difference. My newly acquired German mess kit was clunky, quite heavy but robust, dependable and made just like a Tiger tank! This mess kit was flimsy..just like any other American-made car with a ton issues. This kit is NOT recommended and you would be advise to look for a better mess kit anywhere else. If mess kits is your thing then I would advise to get ANY military made mess kits for they're not only dependable but also \"battle-tested\" and used in the field. There are some mess kits and canteen cups out there that at least 50 years old and it had been in at least 2 wars and it's still functioning and usable!", "summary": "Just like everything in life...You get what you pay for!", "unixReviewTime": 1395100800}

I have used them on the open fire, usually raking a few coals out to the side and cooking on them. If they bend i have always been able to bend it right back. Being made of aluminum they are lightweight. The whole thing nests together and then secures closed with the skillet handle and a wing nut. I bought mine for around 7 dollars at wal mart and could not reccomend at Amazons price of over 11$ at the time of this review. I have a floppy brimmed boonie type, and as light as the mesh is, it's small diameter deforms the brim inward. Due to the too short length, a gap exists right at the collar if you are wearing a T shirt or similarly constructed shirt collar. Bugs WILL find that gap, that's what they do. In addition, the elastic around the neck area is sewn in place, though you could pull it and the mesh thru a cord lock to keep bugs from getting inside if you were wearing a shirt with a \"sealable\" collar. The mesh will stop mosquitos unless it is up against your skin (because the net is too small!) but seems too coarse to stop no see-ums. I think it is just fine enough to stop the black flies that are a plague in the Adirondacks, but I haven't been able to get back there in years so I'm no longer sure about that. I do know that they would absolutely find their way in around the collar area. Some got thru our pants cuffs even though we shock corded them shut. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 15, 2015", "reviewerID": "A151R01M3AL59K", "asin": "B0009PUSZI", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "Math Addict", "reviewText": "Yes you look stupid wearing it but it's fun watching the mosquitoes trying to get at your face.\n\nI do a lot of hiking and I have turned around in the past because the bugs were so aggressive. The little buggers would actually fly around my sunglasses and land on my eyeballs. They would also bite me so much I'd look like I had some virulent plague by the end of the hike. Then I bought a bunch of these and all my (head) problems were solved. I do recommend getting a broad brimmed hat, preferably one that protects the back of the neck too. When you wear this net over the hat it stays away from your face and is no inconvenience at all, until you try to drink from your hydration system! If it turns out that the bugs are behaving you can fold the net up and put it under the hat.\n\nMany times I've had other hikers tell me they wish they had one and ask me where I got mine. They're so cheap I have several spares in the house that I can lend to co-hikers. Most of them have bought their own by now, though.", "summary": "I wish all problems could be solved this easily", "unixReviewTime": 1447545600}

{"overall": 2.0, "vote": "3", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 25, 2012", "reviewerID": "A19VISO9EHD1OM", "asin": "B0009PUR4A", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "JNieporte", "reviewText": "My local WalMart sells these for $9 - about the same as Amazon - and I own three of them. After using the military-issue mess kits, I wanted some more for camping. This is what I ended up getting. I'm disappointed. I'll talk about this kit piece-by-piece.\n\nIn general, the aluminum is pretty thin for a mess kit. Even when being very careful, I can only get five or six uses out of a piece before it gets too weak to be useful. The metal bends, melts, and gets holes in it with normal use. It's just not made to withstand heat. Yes, it all nests together, provided you put it back together the same way it came out of the box. I've found that I have to bend the plate (which is more like a bowl) somewhat to get it all back together. Unacceptable.\n\n-Eight-ounce cup. Yeah, it's an aluminum cup with a handle. It holds eight ounces. The handle comes off without much use, which of course it's not supposed to. If you're thinking about boiling water in this... don't. This will work fine as a cup for cooled liquids.\n-Six-inch deep dish plate. It's not six inches deep. It's 6 inches in diameter, and about 1-1/2\" deep. It's more like a shallow bowl. Good for using as a plate or shallow bowl. The corners seem to be weak in mine, but the bottom always burns through first. It's better than using a sheet of aluminum foil, but not by much.\n-7.5 inch frying pan. This is the same as the plate, just a tiny bit larger, but with a handle secured to it with a wingnut. Tighten the wingnut to lock the handle into place, either open for frying pan use, or closed to keep the kit together. The handle is very weak, and can barely support the weight of the pan with food in it. Again, it falls apart with normal use.\n-16-ounce pot with lid. The pot and lid count as two pieces in this five-piece set. It's a weak pot with a weak hanging wire. You can boil some water in it, sure, but it's not well-suited for cooking food. The lid is crappy and thin, and the small nub on the top (it's supposed to be a knob) is just a piece of plastic that's lazily screwed into the lid. Between the screw and the underside of the lid is, well glue. Something to drip into your boiling water when it heats up.\n\nOverall, this is a very cheap set. Not inexpensive at nine dollars, but cheap. It's flimsy, and at times, dangerous. There's no way you're going to make a meal, even for one person, with this thing without spilling stuff. Better than aluminum foil, sure, but not by much. Also, make sure you stick some plastic silverware in this. You'll have to snap off the butt end of everything so it fits, but you'll have it.", "summary": "Cheap, Disposable", "unixReviewTime": 1340582400}

{"overall": 4.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "05 26, 2011", "reviewerID": "A3W1CX78I81IB1", "asin": "B0009PUQLE", "reviewerName": "Tobias, Son of Floyd", "reviewText": "As an avid knife collector who likes to collect hobos and camp knives, it seemed I should have one made by Coleman. My choices were paying $25 for a Swiss Army knife or $10 for the Coleman. I'd advise leaving it disassembled with the all utensils in the open position while drying.\n\nThe fork is small but you can poke chunks of meat with it and the tines will hold. There are 2 cross poles for the tent, and 1 cross pole for the rainfly, and the rest is just staking it out.\n\nI have found the tent to be sturdy, and most importantly, waterproof. For privacy, the rainfly covers the mesh on the sides, and the front and back mesh can be closed.  I have not taken this tent cold weather camping for 2 reasons.  First, I don't do cold weather camping, and second, this is a lightweight tent with lots of mesh, so it will not keep you warm. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "02 23, 2018", "reviewerID": "A23D13HKTA95WX", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "David Hostetler", "reviewText": "I've had one of these for years. One thing I didn't consider when I got it and I now know, DO NOT USE this to heat up so called oven safe plastics like freezer meals ship with. First time I used mine I tried baking cookies that came on one of those sheets and it took me forever to get it off of there.\n\nOne tip. I have an 8x8 baking stone that was a thrift store find that I use in the bottom. It helps dissipate heat more evenly through the oven.\n\nDo remember that your stove is the heat source, so if you have low BTU output burners, your oven won't get very hot. I have a Coleman stove with 10K BTU burners and the oven does 400 deg F no problem.\n\nBakeware that actually works in an oven this small can be a challenge to find, be on the lookout for \"toaster oven\" size bakeware.\n\nA second rack would be a nice addition, I am considering adding one soon. That way I can do a dozen cookies in one shot instead of doing 2 different batches...\n\nIt's been a great addition for those times we want to bake up some fresh cinnamon rolls, or do biscuits and gravy for breakfast. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "8", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "02 7, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1VMDNO47SKCXN", "asin": "B0009PUQJQ", "reviewerName": "Myra Binnicker", "reviewText": "We live in Florida, and stuffy or leaky tents are an issue. This tent was built in a fashion that neither of these issues were a problem. The plastic bottom extends up the sides about six inches, making a great lower water barrier. The top half of both sides of the tent are netting. The rain cover extends out over the front and back doors, and about six inches from the netting on the sides. This allows for ventilation, but also assures privacy (as no one can see in through the netting unless they actually bother to come and stick their head in between it and the cover). The rain cover extending over the doorways also helps to keep out rain if you are slipping in and out of the tent during a shower. The last weekend that we used it, we had a twelve hour Florida rain. All of our belongings stayed nice and dry. It was about 50F out, but with the doors totally zipped, it didn't get too cool either. It comes with a couple of neat features. There are pockets sewn into the inside, to help you keep track of your pocket items, glasses, and other little things. There is a door on both sides, and plastic \"welcome mats\" the stake down outside, which helps keep the sand out (beach campers here). There is a small zipper in the back to allow electrical access, without opening up your entire tent. There is also a small (approx 12\") access door down low to the side. It has both netting and a full cloth door. It says that it is so you can access your cooler or place a fan. We were thinking it would be perfect if you have a small dog that needs to go out at 3 am. Put it on a leash, unzip the small door, and not have to get out of your sleeping bag (just be sure to pick up anything he may have \"left behind\" come morning). I like that in addition to hooks, the rain cover also has Velcro straps that wrap around the tent poles. It was pretty windy during parts of the last storm, but it stayed firmly in place. Due to the large amount of netting used in this tent, I am not sure how well it would do in very low temperatures, but for Florida it is a great product. As long as you are camping in mildly cool to warmer weather, I can recommend this tent to you.\n\n****Just a quick update*** We went beach camping with this tent. A heavy storm came up. The winds were sustained at 35 mph, and it was holding up fine. We started getting gusts of 57 mph, and the poles on the side taking the brunt of it snapped. I think that is a fair expectation for this style of tent in a storm of that strength. We drove into town the next morning, and went to Wal-Mart. They had replacement Coleman pole kits, but the sizes were off a bit, and we had to use a pocketknife to shave some off to make them fit into the joints of the other sections. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "12", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "04 18, 2012", "reviewerID": "A2ZCXIZHS191TG", "asin": "B0009PUR4A", "style": {"Size:": " one size"}, "reviewerName": "Fred Anonymous Smith", "reviewText": "This is an ultra lightweight, individual, field mess kit for backpackers and similar. The design been around for decades (have used a few over several of those decades), popular because it offers more than the traditional Army individual mess kit. Despite it's apparent \"thin & flimsy\" construction, it will last for years with only moderate care and maintenance. Dents, small scratches, and scorch marks can be tapped or buffed out. Bent handles can simply be forced back into place (notice none here have said the handles fall or break off). In the end, this kit supposed to be basic & functional, not comprehensive & pretty.\n\nCooking in the field requires experience and skill. It's not the same as cooking on the stove at home. Temperatures should be lower (coals, not flames). With this kit, each camper cooks their own meals (with their own kit), with individual portions instead of group portions. Heavy foods should be cooked with spits or skewers, not these lightweight containers. The pots & pans should be supported on something when force is applied. Most just eat directly from the pots & pans after cooking. Tote an aluminum coffee pot if that, cocoa, or hot tea is desired. Millions over the years (including me) have done all this and it works.", "summary": "This Lightweight Kit Is Supposed To Be Thin", "unixReviewTime": 1334707200}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 16, 2017", "reviewerID": "AFJGF1BCJ7HV2", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "Stanley Troy Thompson", "reviewText": "This is a really great, and very well made item.  It is also very convenient and easty to use.  You just screw the top on and plump the cylinder into the base.  It uses the short, fat cylinders--not the longer kind you usually see plumbers using with torches.\n\nI had one of these things but I cannot locate the thing anywhere so when Hurricane Irma headed towards Florida I hurried and ordered another one.  Thankfully, the hurricane did not hit the part of Florida I live in, the panhandle.\n\nMy old stove got me and my late father through the hell that was Hurrican Ivan which did hit here in September of 2004.  We did not have power or drinking water for the better part of the week and half the trees were knocked down.  Our roof lost every other row of shingles, the storm windows blew out with loud bangs, and the siding of our house, which my neighbor, John, returned to me as a joke, blew three blocks down the street.\n\nDad and I did have hot coffee and hot meals, though, and we did have plenty of water since I am a home winemaker and had filled my six  six gallong fermenter spigot buckets up to the brim.\n\nI also have a two burner, Coleman propane stove around someplace but I cannot find that either.  I used this stove once or twice before deciding the single burner was more than sufficient for coffee, tea, or dinner.  We ate chilit mostly, Hormel with no beans with two cans of Bush's chili beans thrown in.\n\nWith this stove, you do not have to go through the routine of putting soapy water on the joints to check for gas leaks.  There is only one connection.  If it does hiss when you screw it on it means the valve is open so you just rotate it.\n\nTo light it, just open the valve a bit until it hisses and light it with a match or butane lighter.  You turn it down or up or off with the valve.\n\nIn case you are not familiar with propane torches, the gas coming out makes the connection near the tank icy cold to the point that frost starts to form.  No kidding.  Frost will form because it is the same principle that makes your refrigerator work.  I said torch mind you.  I did not let the burner run full blast.  The flame might eventually hurt the cooking grid part though it seems very sturdy.\n\nI think they have improved this burner a bit since my old one and, if I ever find the old one, I will compare the two.\n\nA word about liquid fuel stoves.  A Wal Mart add for a dual fuel stove said the Coleman dual fuel will burn over four times what's in a cylinder per gallon.  This is a no brainer though since the cylinders only contain a bit over sixteen ounces of liquid and the gallon has 128 ounces.\n\nThe also used to make endless jokes about liquid fuel gasoline stoves blowing up and sending people to heaven when I was little.\n\\\nThe straight line gases in order from lighest to heaviest are:  methane, ethane, propane, and butane.  After this you get gasolines followed by mineral spirits, kerosenes, fuel oils, and paraffins like Vaseline and tars.\n\nMethane and ethane, often called natural gas, are not liquids at safe pressure.  Propane is a liquid at about 15 atmospheres of pressure.  The stuff in your little bottles is a liquid and not a gas.  Butane is liquid at about the pressures you find in soda or beer bottles.  This makes butane ideal for plastic lighters though it is more expensive normally than propane per ounce.  Natural gass, of course, is cheap but an actually cylinder of gas, as opposed to liquid, would give you very little cooking time.  They do use gas gas in city vehicles but the things do not have a great range per charge.\n\nSo: if you live in hurricane country or like to camp, this and other Coleman products are very nice.  I do give it five stars.", "summary": "Stan the Man Reviews:  Coleman one burner propane stove.", "unixReviewTime": 1505520000}
