{"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 11, 2017", "reviewerID": "A268P3FXWN8ILW", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "Apestoso", "reviewText": "After receiving a replacement because the first one did not include a baking rack, my finger was deeply cut by the VERY sharp edge of the metal box.  Not a good way to start, huh?  So after a few days of healing, the replacement unit was unfolded and assembled....but not easily.  The metal tabs did not align properly and the top was slightly bowed;  this made for a very frustrating ordeal, not unlike wack-a-mole as one tab would come out as the others were inserted.  The 'problem' was fixed after using a pair of needle nose pliers and pushing from the inside to seat each tab-: ta-da!! Now for the cooking part: I use this on a Camp Chef and it  heated up quickly and cooks very hot on low.  Ergo, the cobbler, bread and polenta had rather toasty undersides, but other than that, the food was cooked evenly and on time.  My caveats are this: WEAR gloves when removing and assembling and check for sharp edges; practice a few times (empty) to find out how it functions with your particular stove;  place a small cooking stone in the bottom to diffuse the heat and avoid scorching;  This a a real hot box/hurt locker so be very careful to avoid touching it while cooking, and wear hand and arm protection when removing foods.  My last recommendation is once it is assembled, leave it that way until it needs to be stored or transported, Otherwise, keep the first aid kit or band aids handy. This product fills a cooking niche that can improve camp cuisine or reduce kitchen heat in the summer if properly and safely used.", "summary": "Hot Box", "unixReviewTime": 1497139200}

{"overall": 4.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 1, 2016", "reviewerID": "AE5W5BLOW0YF9", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "johninde", "reviewText": "I used this to bake bread in a small cast iron Dutch oven placed inside it and heated over a propane Coleman stove. The resulting bread was as good or better than expected. There are two reasons I marked it 4 stars, and I did contemplate 3 stars. The temperature gauge is way off. As I was preheating it to bake the bread, I found it was really struggling to get over 400dF, when I needed it to be 475. All the while it was smoking (as I expected) and seemed awfully hot - after all it was over a 10,000 BTU burner on high. I put a separate oven thermometer inside and closed the door. It was well over 600dF. Once I got the bread inside after cooling it to 475, I could watch the oven temp gauge outside after matching it to the right number inside. My second issue is that because I was unknowingly heating it so high, there was some minor warping afterwards. Otherwise, I think the oven is well conceived, well priced and adequately constructed. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "16", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "05 27, 2016", "reviewerID": "A29MRSU25Y5T8X", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "Geoff Lodal", "reviewText": "I hadn't heard about this oven until finding it on Expedition Portal with glowing reviews.  At $30 I gave it a shot and have used it for 3 camping weekends thus far.  Holy moly, I can't figure out how we lived without it now.  It is astonishing how much a pan of cinnamon rolls on a cold morning can change morale.\n\nI use the oven on a Coleman Grill Stove&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-PerfectFlow-Insta-Start-Grill-Stove/dp/B000BPEE4M/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman PerfectFlow Insta Start Grill Stove</a>.  The trick here is to remove the grill portion and just set the oven right over the burner, it prevents the grill from melting and doubles as a nice wind break on the burner.  I have given up hope on the thermometer, so I typically just set a medium flame and monitor the contents until they're done.\n\nThe grate can be set at 3 heights.  Higher is better in my opinion, helps prevent burned bottoms, which I've had a couple times.  I'd also recommend a dedicated cookware set, I bought the Farberware set&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Farberware-Nonstick-Bakeware-4-Piece-Toaster-Oven-Set-Gray/dp/B008NPUTFA/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Farberware Nonstick Bakeware 4-Piece Toaster Oven Set, Gray</a>.  Make sure you have a good oven mitt too so you can pull out hot pans.\n\nI deducted a star because the details are lacking.  As I said, the thermometer is way off, the washer behind the door knob has already fallen apart on me, and the latches to hold it together are really easy to bend.  This isn't a new product, so I'd like to see Coleman up the quality a bit, maybe bump the price $5 or so, and call it good.\n\nIt packs small enough that it's always with us when car camping.  With the latch issue mentioned above, I wouldn't be surprised if I break something over the summer of camping, but I'm sure I can kluge it together to keep it going for a while.  Solid 4 stars and highly recommended for making happy campers.", "summary": "Game Changer", "unixReviewTime": 1464307200}

{"overall": 3.0, "vote": "34", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 18, 2016", "reviewerID": "A1NBDAIOROQB3H", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "UNACAMPER", "reviewText": "I mostly use this to boil water when I'm camping......I refill my small tanks.  I purchased one about 15 years ago that got swept away in a Gully Flood. Bought this to replace it. Looks the same. Not the same.. Good idea, but has the same poor quality construction I find in most things from Coleman in recent years. The attitude of \"let's make it as cheap as possible\", found in most \"made in China\" equipment they produce, leaves me unimpressed. The internals of the valve mechanism are all plastic, feel loose and do not give me a feeling of confidence when I turn the valve off. As always, when not in use, the Tank and Stove must be separated. Why not use a quality valve? I would have paid an extra $15.00 - $25.00 for this product to get better quality. I have simple propane soldering torches that screw to the top of the tanks, with 10 times the quality for about the same money. Coleman wants you to break the valve, then throw away the unit and get another? Sad that so many people here accept poorly engineered products these days and give 5 stars to everything they purchase. I tend to see it as reading about 100 degrees high.  It's probably reading accurately, but since the heat is coming from the bottom, it can be a lot hotter on the bottom of the pan, or at the top where the heat accumulates, than it is right where the thermometer is. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 29, 2014", "reviewerID": "A336D7ODUB7NFG", "asin": "B0009PURKO", "style": {"Color:": " Green"}, "reviewerName": "Nancy E.", "reviewText": "Quality. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "11 19, 2014", "reviewerID": "A1GRBKL1FZCKYU", "asin": "B0009PURKO", "reviewerName": "Ductape", "reviewText": "That is what this cooler is like......... because when you walk into a room (or campsite), and this cooler is there, you just have to look at it. It's sooooo darned sexy !!\n\nOK, so we have had ours about seven years or so. We bought it when we were still tent camping, and now we use it with our pop-up camper. We could not be much happier with any cooler. You need to make one improvement as soon as you buy this, but it's so inexpensive, I still have to give this 5 stars. I'd give it 6 if I could. Go to your nearest big box home improvement store and buy a small roll of white adhesive backed 1/4\" X 1/4\" foam gasket by Frost King or similar manufacturer. Clean the groove in the lid with a solvent like Mineral spirits or similar. Peel the backing off the gasket and stick the gasket into the groove in the lid, working your way around to  the back where you started. Cut the gasket so its essentially one continuous seal, leaving as small of a gap between start and finish as possible. Now when you close the lid you will have a virtually air tight seal.\n\nWe go camping a week, or sometimes eight days at a time. Before we leave I go to the grocery store and buy 2 five lb. pieces of block ice to put in the bottom. If you have the freezer space, you could make some block ice at home and save the 4 or 5 bucks. After placing the block ice one either side of the bottom of the cooler, I add our weeks worth of food.... bacon, dogs, burgers, bacon, milk, butter, bacon, steak, bacon, you name it ! Then on top of the food I add regular ice, which I make at home, though sometimes we buy it bagged at the store. This cooler keeps ice 8 days or more this way....... no kidding ! I'm so completely impressed. I have left the cooler closed after returning home and had some of the block ice still in it over 9 days.\n\nYes, I also grew up camping with a 1960s original steel belted Coleman cooler and, yes, I'll admit the quality of the vintage coolers was better. Thicker steel, better latch, screw on O-ringed drain cap, and built in bottle opener. Believe me, I will get that ole Coleman from my big brother one day !! It will be mine...... oh yes, it will be mine !!! But the reality is, the 'new' steel  belted coolers are what we can go out and buy today, and this one is great. Get it in stainless steel and it will be guaranteed never to shrink, stink, wrinkle or rust !", "summary": "CLEAVAGE !!!", "unixReviewTime": 1416355200}

I have tried other lights, like some of the many LED or fluorescent lanterns, big and small. Most, or actually all, of them collect dust in the basement. Never have liked the quality of light from the LED, nor the archaic by now fluorescent. LED's have become better, but not so much the color characteristic of the light - too whitish/blue.\n\nSo, I returned to a favorite light we used more than 20 years ago, the Mighty-Lite I think it was called. Basically, it was the same as this light, but with the advantage of the ignition piezo. I like it because it is compact, easily packed in its box, and into the camping box. It certainly doesn't compete in sheer light output like the big ones, and doesn't hiss aloud, but one doesn't have to shield their eyes either.\n\nI think the quality is nice, not a cheap looking/feeling product. The ignition works fine. We either hang it over the camping table, or on it, or anywhere one wants to put it. Mantels are hard to find in local sporting goods stores, even REI's flagship store here in Seattle. Save yourself looking for them - buy them online, and buy 4 or more to keep in the box as mantles can be damaged easily with too much bouncing, knocking around. The glass globe is well protected by the cage.", "summary": "Nice light", "unixReviewTime": 1391040000}

{"overall": 1.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "01 22, 2015", "reviewerID": "A2NGME1UO4ZGX1", "asin": "B0009PUPWE", "reviewerName": "Anne", "reviewText": "I purchased this lantern for my elderly mother to use as an emergency light in power outages.  Not the cheapest available, but I knew Mom would get a kick out of the old-style looking Coleman in a modern battery version.  That was 8 years ago.  The lantern has probably seen a maximum of 12 hours of use, if that.  It functioned beautifully until the batteries leaked.  I know that is not the fault of Coleman, but I would guess it is not a terribly atypical problem. They were Duracell, but still, batteries will leak over time.  I cleaned up the leaked batteries and found one of the terminals to be badly corroded.  I cleaned up the terminals, still, the circuit could not be completed.\n\nI decided that the part needed to be replaced so went to the Coleman site.  There are replacement parts for this lantern, but not the battery holder (which is a little plastic housing with terminals; you put the batteries in it and slide the whole thing into the base of the lantern).  I called CS and was helped by a very nice man but all he could tell me is that the part is discontinued and not available.  This renders the other barely used and fully functional parts useless.\n\nSo here we have a lantern still on the market and a critical part, one that may be easily damaged by faulty batteries, is discontinued.  I have white gas Coleman lanterns from 1950 that are still fully functional!  How wasteful and shortsighted of Coleman to not continue to provide critical replacement parts for a lantern still on the market today.\n\nI will be replacing this lantern with an LED model from another company; I simply cannot support a company that supports this kind of built-in obsolescence.  Our landfill does not need this kind of needless waste.  Simply irresponsible behavior by a company that makes its money off of people who love the outdoors.  Sickening.", "summary": "The lantern functions well but Coleman is irresponsible regarding replacement parts.", "unixReviewTime": 1421884800}

{"overall": 3.0, "vote": "14", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 7, 2012", "reviewerID": "A1VBOWZAVL7SPM", "asin": "B0009PUR54", "reviewerName": "TechWrite", "reviewText": "Unlike my 2-mantle lantern, this little lamp can be turned down very low and the control even has detents so that you can tell which setting you're selecting. On full brightness it's about half as bright as a 2-mantle lantern - which is quite adequate for many purposes. But it's gas consumption is also half that of a 2-mantle lantern, so you can really stretch the fuel when you turn the light down low. According to the label, a tank lasts 12 hours at full output, or 18 at reduced output. I was without power for 10 days after Hurricane Sandy when there were no gas bottles to be found anywhere. I only had a few, so I was very happy to have this little gas miser. I had no problem installing the mantle but, like another reviewer, I reduced the rating one star for workmanship. The lamp does not sit quite straight on the gas bottle and the globe is not centered within the wire guard. An additional concern is that this lantern hangs from a rather short chain rather than a hardened wire hoop like the larger lanterns. I reduced the rating an additional star because the chain gets so hot that you can't touch it without receiving a severe burn. Moreover, anything it hangs from might be singed or ignited, so you'll need to operate it in a support ring on a flat surface. While I appreciate the effort to make this lantern as portable as possible, the conventional wire hoop is an indispensable safety feature.", "summary": "One-Mantle Compact is a real gas miser!", "unixReviewTime": 1352246400}
{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 3, 2012", "reviewerID": "A30ZXZRW7B10BX", "asin": "B0009PUR54", "reviewerName": "CRECK", "reviewText": "We really like our little light. Zamudio", "reviewText": "Overall, this lamp is awesome. For a signle-mantle unit, it really kicks out the light when you need it. It also runs for hours on end, as long as you are prudent with your settings. Why use full-bright when you can turn it to mid-range and let your natural night-vision make up the rest? We used one tank of fuel over 5 nights of camping, and I am certain that we had it on for at least 4 hours each night.\n\nFuel options for this unit aren't so great. You are stuck using the standard green Coleman 1lb cannister, which is very bulky (compared to other fuel containers of similar capacity). The fuel tank is bigger than the lantern! So far, I have not been able to find any compatible propane tank of a smaller capacity that would fit this. For a 2-night trip, a 1/2lb tank would be great, but only if it were half the container size of the 1lb tank. You can get away with using this lantern for backpacking, as along as you have someone who is willing to carry the fuel tank. If you are packing it solo, forget about it. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 23, 2012", "reviewerID": "A6RZG1711OSGT", "asin": "B0009PURX6", "reviewerName": "Adam Geiger", "reviewText": "love this item for a quick and easy pump inflate for a camping trip.  so glad we purchased it before our latest trip", "summary": "great item", "unixReviewTime": 1353628800}
{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 12, 2013", "reviewerID": "A2GL4ND7RYKQWX", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "thedalles", "reviewText": "After recently purchasing a camper that had a stove but no oven, my family was faced with either giving up some of our favorite breakfast foods like biscuits and cinnamon rolls, and easy bake desserts like brownies, or buy a stand alone oven that would work on a camp stove like this Coleman.  While we have only used it on one trip so far, it performed well for what it is, and can be improved upon with a little knowledge and pre-planning.  First of all, several reviewers have mentioned how this oven cooks at a higher temp than the simple temperature guage reads.  This seems to be true for mine as well.  I am guessing based on cook time, that at a reading of 350 degrees, the oven was closer to 400 or a bit higher.  Even checking the rolls a few minutes earlier than the earliest cook time at 400 degrees, the bottoms got a bit burned at 350 degrees.  Try cooking at a lower temperature and taking your time to avoid brown or crusty roll/buscuit/cornbread bottoms.  Unless your guage is closer to true temps than mine, you would be better off to assume the reading is 25-50 degress cool, and cook accordingly.  Another tip is to move foods that will fit to one of the top two racks when cooking.  This can also help the top side of your baked goods heat up a little better and more evenly with the bottom of the pan.  Finally, use as thick and heavy a pan as will fit, and/or locate a small round or small rectangular pizza stone that will fit inside on the bottom of the oven to help regulate the heat intensity and hold temperature better when opening the door to check progress.  With just a little effort, this Coleman Camp Oven can work pretty well, despite its light weight and construction.  Also folds down flat for easy transporting.", "summary": "A great addition to any camping outing", "unixReviewTime": 1378944000}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 29, 2013", "reviewerID": "A2A9BA56TRDIQB", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "monstercatambush", "reviewText": "Now that I fixed the thing it works pretty much as advertised. THAT's the type of trips this oven will be going on.  That all being said...  Now that I drilled a couple of holes in the top so I could re-attach the handle with a couple of pop rivets its up and running.  It does work just like a home oven and fits neatly on my Coleman camp stove.  Biscuits come out nicely browned, and I made a pretty decent lasagna in it.  The temperature gauge works well, as does the little door latch.  The oven rack is adjustable, so that between regulating your oven flame and the rack height you can get pretty decent results. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "28", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 16, 2013", "reviewerID": "A1P99CJ8VCQ0HB", "asin": "B0009PURKO", "style": {"Color:": " Green"}, "reviewerName": "Review King", "reviewText": "(I left a shorter review of this cooler earlier, but after further use wanted to return to leave a more comprehensive review.)\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nI purchased this cooler on the recommendation of a friend who had several at a tailgate party I attended. After searching around for the best price I settled on purchasing the green colored cooler (which was the cheapest at the time) from Amazon. As a prime eligible purchase, it arrived two days later in perfect condition. Absolutely no dings, scratches, or dents like other reviews mention. It was perfectly packaged in factory boxes.\n\nAPPEARANCE\n\nThe cooler is plastic encased in steel. The colored portion you see is steel whereas the white portion is plastic. Some people seem to believe this cooler is all steel. It is not. It is steel belted as the description clearly states. The latch is metal and plastic. The handles are also metal but with plastic grips. The cooler's appearance is stylish. Also, there is NO bottle opener on this version of the cooler. Some reviews allude to the presence of a bottle opener on the outside of the cooler. There is certainly not one on the version I ordered.\n\nFUNCTIONALITY AND USE\n\nHands down this is the best cooler I have ever owned. I take a lot of road trips and travel a lot for work and used to carry along an old generic plastic cooler with me to keep snacks, water, and soda. This cooler has replaced my old beat up travel buddy. It fits nicely in the back of my Ford Escape and has more then enough storage space for meats, cheese, bread, yogurt, fruit, beer, and ice. I can stock it with enough food for a 3-5 day trip easily. The cooler keeps ice for about two to three days outside of extreme temperatures. Two or three two liter bottles of ice are enough to keep everything cold for at least 2 says. If necessary, the ice can be supplemented with a bag of two from the motel to get you through the last day or two of your trip. I do not use the chemical ice packs (except one small one, see below), but they might last a little longer.\n\nNow just one thing to consider before you purchase this item. The cooler can get heavy especially when fully loaded. Of course it depends on what you put in the cooler, but I have loaded mine up to what was probably more then fifty pounds. That can be a lot of weight to carry especially longer distances. Unless you are a large burly man don't plan on carry this cooler, fully loaded, around all day long. (The plastic grips do a good job of stopping the handles from cutting into your hands when carrying and it is on the heavy side). To get around this limitation, I keep a small cold pack in the cooler and a small insulated bag I got as a freebie at a convention. Whenever I need to take something from the car to a different location and do not want to lug the entire cooler I just place what I need in the insulated bag with the cold pack.\n\nTIPS\n\n1. Don't waste your money buying bagged ice at convenience stores. Fill recycled two liter bottles 3/4 way full of water and freeze them. Use these bottles as ice packs. It will not only save you the mess of melted ice, but also a few dollars because you won't have to buy ice.\n\n2. Make sure to chill everything that will go in the cooler at least overnight. This will help extend the life of the ice in the cooler.\n\n3. It is useful to keep something like a bottle opener or cork screw in your cooler. Even a small folding knife can be a lifesaver when you need to cut open a package or some food.\n\nCONCLUSION\n\nThis cooler is well worth the money. Yes, you can find cheaper alternatives in stores and online. But, the value of this cooler cannot be surpassed. You may save a few dollars by buying a generic plastic cooler, but those savings will quickly be lost with all your ice purchases and loss of food due to heat.", "summary": "Great Cooler, Excellent for Roadtrips", "unixReviewTime": 1379289600}

Like the other reviewer said - it's just a fan - not made for high pressure, but it IS made for high velocity.\n\nThis pump has ran like a champ since the day we bought it.  We take it on the boat, in the motorhome, and it has a permanent spot in my garage next to the compressor.  I use it for everything. I always use the hose and I think I would be bummed out if I lost it.\n\nAfter 5 years, I can hear the motor finally conking out. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "4", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "12 9, 2011", "reviewerID": "AOOCZBTIWKRDB", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "Rave On", "reviewText": "The Coleman ovens have been around since at least 1960 from what I can find. The fact that the design exists today nearly unchanged is a tribute to the product itself. Unlike the early steel models, Newer models are made of lighter-weight aluminum.\nThe Coleman ovens are designed to sit on top of the traditional box type Coleman two or three burner stoves with the heat of a single burner providing the heat.\n\nThey work best in windless environments with the temperature over 50 degrees.\n\nIn windy environments and/or temperatures approaching 30 degrees F or less, The oven is more finicky with the temperature more difficult to control and maintain. In these challenging conditions, the baking can have hot spots where four biscuits cooking at the same time might have two perfect and two burned.\nGetting the tops of food to brown without burning the bottom takes a lot of experience and is something I have not mastered.\nSo, the oven is not perfect, but that is all part of the camping cooking experience - to try to achieve perfection in more challenging environments.\n\nYou can enhance the performance of the oven by draping a couple sheets of aluminum foil around the oven when using it.\nThe Coleman oven does expand the camp menu significantly. Now you can have pizza at camp, which is a novelty. Instead of griddle cakes, you can have muffins. Instead of fried eggs, you can have quiche. If you have picky eaters or new campers, the Coleman oven can bring some familiarity and comfort by offering foods typically enjoyed at home.\n\nThe Coleman oven is a fun device that adds a bit of a thrill for both the cook and the outdoor diners. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "658", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 10, 2009", "reviewerID": "A1WT4C5BZHW8KV", "asin": "B0009PURJA", "reviewerName": "Flo Smith", "reviewText": "I have seen these ovens on store shelves most of my life.  I was certain that a little aluminum box could not function as an oven. But recently, we were embarking on a 10-day camping trip, and I was going to need to bake while we were there.  I am pretty adept at baking with coals from a campfire or a charcoal fire, but on the trip in question, there was a burn ban in effect.  What to do?  I got on Amazon and read reviews about the Coleman Camp Oven, and decided that if my original opinion was correct, Coleman wouldn't still be making this little gem.\n\nI purchased the oven and it arrived when promised.  We took it to the campground, and were totally amazed at how beautifully it worked.  We baked brownies, biscuits, potatoes, cornbread and even gluten-free hamburger buns and rolls.  Everything was wonderful. The oven was easy to set up and use.  But it is not like baking at home in your regular oven.\n\nTips you should know:\n  > Only use the oven on a camp stove.  Try to get your stove as level as possible.\n  > Start warming it up with a low flame, and increase the stove flame as the oven begins to pre-heat.\n  > Plan to use small bakeware.  Coleman suggests 8x8 pans. Here are some products that we found worked well:\n  *&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Nordic-Ware-Toaster-Oven-Baking-Sheet/dp/B00004RFS9/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Nordic Ware Toaster Oven Baking Sheet</a>\n  *  Ekco mini muffin pan for 12 muffins\n  *&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Fox-Run-Set-of-Four-English-Muffin-Rings/dp/B0000CFME7/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Fox Run Set of Four English Muffin Rings</a>&nbsp;(for the burger buns) on the baking sheet\n  *&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/MSR-Blacklite-Fry-Pan/dp/B000FBYNIE/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">MSR Blacklite Fry Pan</a>\n  *  8x8 foil pan\n  > After your food is in the oven, you really need to watch the temperature gauge from time to time.  The longer it bakes, the more likely you will need to adjust the stove flame to regulate the temperature inside the oven.  This is NOT set-it-and-forget-it baking.\n  > We found that timing was pretty close to baking at home, as long as the temperature was constant.\n  > Try not to peek too often.  Peeking lowers the internal temperature.  Look when you need to & that's all.\n  > Clean up spills (outside and inside) as soon as the oven cools.  Don't let gunk bake on during the next use.\n\nThe oven folds up quickly when it is time to pack up.  We keep it in its original box, and it is ready to go!\n\nI still love the thrill of accomplishment of baking using a campfire, but this little oven is a great addition for those times when a fire is not convenient.\n\nMay we all have many years of excellent campground baking! For my wife and I, Big Camp is all about making great meals with a great view.  Those dehydrated bag meals are fine for light weight backpacking, but if its Big Camp, then we try to eat well. Our Big Camp kitchen includes three&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-Powerpack-Single-Burner-stoves/dp/B0009PUS6M/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman Powerpack Single-Burner stoves</a>, a&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/GSI-Pinnacle-Griddle/dp/B001LF3I7A/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">GSI Pinnacle Griddle</a>&nbsp;and this Coleman oven.  Those single burners are lighter and more compact than the standard 2-burner stoves.  I carry and organize it all in this&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Mountainsmith-Modular-Hauler-3-System/dp/B001RYNR62/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Mountainsmith Modular Hauler 3 System</a>.  I can use the single 1lb propane bottles or a bulk 10 or 20lb refillable tank.  We also use the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/GSI-Outdoors-Bugaboo-Pots/dp/B0018BLH3Y/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">GSI Outdoors Bugaboo Pots</a>&nbsp;and I really like them. That's a serious camp kitchen even Alton Brown would appreciate. As far as this oven goes, it's always fun to use. I've had great success with tube cookies, rolls and croissants as well as brownies and quick bread mixes even at high altitude.  I've baked a breakfast casserole just below treeline. 6/13 we baked cornbread to go with the fresh trout.  7/6 I baked brownies with it outside because I didn't want to heat up the house. This is no Viking Range. This is a rudimentary folding metal box, but it works.  Baking with this can be an active sport and you have to pay attention.  The thermodynamic properties of aluminized steel are beyond the scope of this review, but suffice it to say that one should not initially turn the burner on full blast or the box will not heat evenly and could warp.  Likewise, one should not place this directly over a camp fire.  For campfire cooking, get a dutch oven.  You can make great things in those too.  For this oven, I keep the burner low at first and let it all heat up slowly to about 200.  I then turn up the burner and let it slowly rise to about 375.  It then requires adjusting the stove burner every few minutes to keep the temperature even.  By \"even\" I mean between 350 and 400. I haven't warped it yet.  I looked at the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-InstaStart-Portable-Oven/dp/B000W4TH30/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman InstaStart Portable Oven</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Camp-Chef-Camp-Oven/dp/B0013LLSZG/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Camp Chef Camp Oven</a>, but this simple box can't be beat for portability.  I can carry three burners, a griddle, pots, hoses, propane and this oven in far less space than one of those ovens takes up. Maybe this winter, I'll make a cover to increase the oven's efficiency.  I thought about using aluminized fiberglass&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/something-like-this/dp/B001G7BXJI/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">~something like this~</a>&nbsp;or simply just laying a&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Silicone-Bake-Mat/dp/B000FPZ2YO/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Silicone Bake Mat</a>&nbsp;over it. In addition to the GSI pots and pans, we also have some silicone bakeware because it's lightweight and smashable. We don't bring this oven on every camping adventure, but there is something really fun about this little \"easy bake oven\".  P.S. It's generally a good idea to keep the camp kitchen away from one's sleeping tent.  That's not always possible in developed campgrounds.  We keep our camp clean, lock it all up at night and have never had a bear or raccoon problem.  It's work, but organization is the key.  I've found the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Mountainsmith-Cubes/dp/B0007WK62S/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Mountainsmith Cubes</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Eagle-Creek-Cubes/dp/B001M0NXJ2/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Eagle Creek Cubes</a>&nbsp;to be a great way of color coding all the gear. I was camping in the Rockies recently, and had to set up my tent on very hard ground, and these were the best stakes for the job. I couldn't even get the little metal stakes that came with my tent to go into the ground, and the larger yellow plastic stakes got all bent up. I wound up going out and buying a dozen more of these big stakes, which are basically nails with green hooks on top. (The green hooks are kinda flimsy, unfortunately.)\n\nThe mallet is nice for pounding in the small metal or plastic stakes, but pounding the big metal stakes into hard ground did leave some scars in the mallet's rubber head. It'd be nice if one side of it had a metal cap or something.\n\nThe stake-puller is basically too weak to pull out any stakes that you can't just pull by hand, although it's nice to use so you don't strain your hands. It's completely worthless for pulling stakes from hard ground, and will just bend until it's wrecked. I'm going to buy a small crowbar instead.\n\nThe dustpan is pretty flimsy. Mine immediately cracked along its edge, if I didn't receive it that way. It's also pretty difficult to put back in the bag.\n\nAll in all, it's a cheap set, but you're basically just getting a decent mallet, 4 good stakes, and an occasionally-convenient stake puller. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 13, 2014", "reviewerID": "AU7O296O6PXZM", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "ideas", "reviewText": "I've been using this stove for about a year now.  It's a heavy, well-made burner best suited for car camping where size and weight are not big concerns.  A major advantage of this burner is the low cost and wide availability of the 16 oz. propane canisters that power it. You get far more bang for your fuel buck with this stove, as compared to stoves using the smaller isobutane canisters. At my local big box store, a 16 oz propane canister costs about $2.50, whereas an 8 oz. isobutane fuel canister costs $5.  Twice the fuel for half the cost is never a bad thing.  Propane canisters also last a long time and are widely available.\n\nLighting this burner is easy.  Simply turn the knob to release the gas and provide a spark (manually), and you're cooking. The simplicity of this burner also has advantages in reliability. As for cooking performance, this stove excels at boiling water and tasks that require a high flame.  The major flaw is that this stove doesn't have a setting that I would describe as truly low.  If you're cooking foods that are prone to sticking or burning on thin camping cookware, you will find that this stove burns too hot even on the lowest setting.  A couple times I've made pancakes on camping trips, and I had to hold my pan above the stove to avoid burning, even on low.  It hasn't been a problem on most foods, but the lack of a very low setting can be troublesome.  I'd recommend checking out the Stansport burner here on Amazon, or the Ozark Trail brand burner sold at Walmart.  I believe both will do a better job cooking at low temp.\n\nOther than that, this is an inexpensive, reliable, and well-made burner that works great. If simmering or low-flame performance is a concern for you, I would pass on this stove.", "summary": "Great burner for cooking at high temperature.  Not great on low", "unixReviewTime": 1407888000}

Read the description.  It clearly states you need to buy the propane separately.", "summary": "May not be new", "unixReviewTime": 1401148800}
{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "5", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "04 4, 2014", "reviewerID": "A2KYC3ZKNAAWCF", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "Desert Gecko", "reviewText": "I love this stove.  I've had mine four years now, and it still works like new.  I recently loaned it to a friend who says he is now going to buy one, so I thought I'd see if Amazon still carries it and I read some reviews.  I was shocked by some of the critical comments I read.\n\nThis stove heats water very quickly, even at high altitudes (though water will not heat as quickly at 10,000 feet as it will at sea level with any stove!)  Compared to a white gas stove or a Jetboil, this stove does heat slightly more slowly, but the difference is negligible and not worth the $100+ difference in price and putting up with the delicate craftsmanship of the others.  This Coleman is solid and durable.\n\nThe head has many small holes, or jets for the flame to ensure a regular, evenly-distributed level, adjustable with clicks on the dial from high to very low simmering to off, with a couple more stops in between.  The design of the burner shields the flame from any wind, so in all but the most windy conditions it works fine without any additional shielding.  Mine simmers perfectly, with a very small flame.  Some reviewers here complained that the simmer is too strong, so they may have a defective unit.  If I were to design a stove, I would design the flame control as utilitarian as this one is.\n\nThe burner easily separates from the tank and base to split up the load for hiking.  The tanks can be found for just a few dollars, and Coleman claims a tank will last for more than two hours on high or nine hours on low, which is plenty to cook many meals and heat water for cleanup.  I've used it to prepare all meals for a three-day backpacking trip for six people at 9,000 feet, and I didn't use up a single tank. I suggest starting with a full tank (or two, depending on length of trip) backpacking, and keeping partial tanks to use on camping trips, where having extra tanks is not an issue.\n\nFor the price, this is a steal.  It's a very good stove for backpacking and for camping, though a little heavy for the hiker.  Not a problem for a group, however, to distribute the load.  Remember, when you're a couple days in at 10,000 feet, you want a good, reliable and durable stove like this - and not a finicky white gas or special-canister, overpriced butane stove.", "summary": "Best Bang For The Buck Available", "unixReviewTime": 1396569600}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "28", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 24, 2013", "reviewerID": "A2I689S2XU9V51", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "RT", "reviewText": "I get a kick out of reviewers here who deduct stars because they are surprised by the specs which are plainly displayed. Yes, the base is the size it is in the pic. The burner is wide so your pans don't fall off. And the regulator sticks out so it's bulkier to pack. It sits high (just like in the pic) so if somebody wobbles a picnic table it will tip over. And no, it's not designed for backpacking... (do people know they also have to pack a bulky bottle to go with it?)\n\nBeen using this for two Summers now. It's a breeze to set up. No built-in ignitor is fine by me - the less crap and gizmos they put on these things the less that will go wrong and the less you rely on said crap and gizmos. It will boil a large pot of coffee in 5 minutes at 10,000 feet. A 12\" pan sits just fine unattended on the large oversized burner but you have to stir more often from the middle - out. 10\" pans are perfect. The flame is powerful and consistent (you can tell just by the sound it makes). The low setting is fine for simmering (The regulator is NOT variable because you don't want to accidentally turn it off forcing you to relight over and over again). Bottles screw in easily. It's just the right height to sit on the ground and I've never had it tip over. (If you're paranoid just put a couple of rocks on the base). For those of you that cook in the wind, newsflash: Wind and fire do not mix. Wind will carry the heat away. Get a wind screen.\n\nI've been through at least 20 bottles on this thing. It works the same way every time. I just store it in a cheap vinyl bag I got somewhere. For longer trips with 4+ people, this stove compliments a 2 burner stove perfectly.", "summary": "Surprise: It does exactly what it says it will do...", "unixReviewTime": 1372032000}
{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 23, 2013", "reviewerID": "A3EIC66HRI30FV", "asin": "B0009PUR5E", "reviewerName": "JJ", "reviewText": "Bought two of these for car camping instead of a 2 burner camp stove. I figured these would be easier to  pack up. I found from two days using them, it is difficult to know  how low you can cut it before it goes out when you already have a pan on top cooking, but that probably goes for any camp stove. Both mornings, it was breezy and raining, and the wind was blowing across on the flames so I had to have the gas turned up relatively high. Fortunately, with the power these things provide, I had no problem finishing the bacon. Having them set on top of a picnic table, a pan tip over twice due to other people moving while sitting at the table. While they work fine, I think I would have been better off with the dual burner camp stove for the stability of a lower cooking surface and the wind protection they provide. I plan on making a plywood base to secure the two propane tanks and maybe a cooking grate to avoid any more tip overs.", "summary": "Camp Stove", "unixReviewTime": 1371945600}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 11, 2015", "reviewerID": "A12B7H4SEIS3MS", "asin": "B0009PVUOG", "style": {"Color:": " Blue"}, "reviewerName": "Brendon Petersheim", "reviewText": "Every time I use this I get exited about how well it is designed! Setup is easy, and you can get the net very tight easily.  It slowly loosens over time, but a quick tug and you're back to perfect again.  Only improvement would be longer stakes if you're playing in sand.  The trick is to loosen the lines so your stakes are far from the net and at a 45 degree angle from the side line,then scoop away as much sand as possible to get down to more solid ground,  then angle the stakes back toward the pole and drive them as far as you can into the sand with a hammer. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "54", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 23, 2006", "reviewerID": "ANOEOHRLK11P0", "asin": "B0009PUQXW", "reviewerName": "D L", "reviewText": "My dad had some Coleman gear when I was a kid about 40 years ago, but I haven't gone camping in those intervening decades, so had no idea what had happened with the legendary Coleman name in all this time.\n\nAs soon as I pulled this stove out of its carefully-packed box I could see that they still were building high-quality equipment.\n\nThe stove sets up within a couple of minutes,  and provides a very stable base. Stability is of paramount importance if you're going to use it in reality-based situations (instead of on the back porch) because nature is not flat nor smooth in most places.\n\nIn a disaster or other emergency things are dark, confused and in a huge mess, one of the last things you need is for some of your dwindling food supply to topple over while the stove happily starts your shelter on fire. That will not happen with this Coleman stove on the ground.\n\nThe two gas valves are large for precise flame control and have a silky feel to them. The \"off\" position cinches the valves down tight.\n\nThe lid and side wind shields hook together and stay that way until you want them to come apart. The chrome grill comes off easily for cleaning.\n\nPropane for this stove is inexpensive and readily available at our local stores. You can disconnect a partially-used propane cylinder and use it again later.\n\nI got this one to add to our emergency gear for when the next power outage hits, wish I'd done it two outages ago.", "summary": "Very high quality and a good deal for the price.", "unixReviewTime": 1166832000}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 6, 2015", "reviewerID": "AXQNHNSB6SP5R", "asin": "B0009PURHC", "reviewerName": "Tree", "reviewText": "Fits perfectly! Accessories too!!", "summary": "Five Stars", "unixReviewTime": 1446768000}
{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "4", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 8, 2015", "reviewerID": "A2AR8K2Y3VN4S4", "asin": "B0009PURHC", "reviewerName": "d", "reviewText": "A little tempermental in that it can get extremely hot in seconds.  Not a bad thing though.  If you want to be able to turn the water on and off throughout your shower experience without having to turn the unit on and off, you can install a valve on the hose.  But you must be sure to install a bypass valve that allows the water to go somewhere, otherwise you WILL burn up your pump.  The water needs to continually flow.  Best way for me was to follow example of a very helpful you tube vide (guy in garage) where he used an open mouthed jug instead of the bladder bag it comes with.  He rigged his system with a bypass valve that routed the water back to the jug when not spraying through the nozzle. Not only does this recycle your water so you don't waste any from letting in spill on the floor when not using it (soaping up), but it saves your pump AND sends heated water back to the water source where your thermostat senses it.  Guess what happens?  You burn less gas heating water because the reccyling effect sends hot water back to the source and you end up with a bucket of hot water pretty much set to the temperature you desire.  CAn't beat this product at all.  Read all the positive reviews that offer lessons learned.  If you follow their examples and advice, you will definitely enjoy this product.  Mine did not leak anywhere BECAUSE I did not block water flow.  Blocking water flow with a simple on off valve instead of a bypass valve causes pressure to build up in the pump and in the unit.  You have to imagine that building up pressure in anything is not good.  Be sure to rig a three way bypass system that allows water to flow in one way and out two ways (nozzle line or second line that runs back to water source or wherever else you want it to go.  Enjoy this product because you can.  Also, the best way to use this product for us was in a two-sided shower tent.  We had the unit propped up on a simple stool on the dry side, near the door, so we could easily reach out of the shower side and make water temperature adjustments.  Having it outside the stall like the guy in the you tube video did not work for us as we could not control the water temperature on the fly.  With a recirculating water setup, you are going to want to have this level of control because the hot water will return to the jug and you may get some of that back doubly hot unless you turn down your temperature setting just right.  Plus, the space a double stall affords just makes your outdoor camping shower experience that much more pleasant, day or night (battery operated lanterns inside stalls).", "summary": "Not a bad thing though", "unixReviewTime": 1444262400}

{"reviewerID": "A1U4JWHUO6QDVP", "asin": "B0009PURCM", "reviewerName": "Marcus", "verified": false, "reviewText": "This catalytic propane heater is adequate for a very small area such as a hunting blind, but it does not put out enough heat for  use as an emergency heater at home or for an RV.  There are other larger, more expensive catalyst propane heaters available that you could use for those applications if you pay attention to the safety precautions.\n\nWith this heater, the propane burns very efficiently in the catalyst disc, so carbon monoxide production is greatly reduced.  However, the instructions caution that you still must provide a ventilation opening to outside air for oxygen and to vent any carbon monoxide.\n\nThe earlier instructions included with this heater model and the similar older match-lit version strangely did not mention the necessary \"break-in\" period.  I think some reviewers say the instructions now cover this. You must initially run this heater for a number of hours outside, or in a vented garge, to get rid of an initial bad smell.  It's probably best to burn a whole small propane bottle.  If you don't do this, you could have a very unpleasant experience breathing in whatever smelly stuff it burns off the new catalyst disc for the first few hours.  After that, it will only have a very slight musty odor that is not too noticeable if you use adequate ventilation as the instructions say.  However, if you are sensitive to odors, this could be still be a problem.\n\nThere is no flame, and the combustion takes place inside the catalyst disc, but you still must be careful not to put it near flammable items due to the high radiant heat right above the the screen-covered disc.", "overall": 4.0, "reviewTime": "11 27, 2010", "summary": "Heater O.K. for small area, but must burn-in first outside", "unixReviewTime": 1290816000}

{"reviewerID": "A3USHFZRLOD1IC", "asin": "B0009PURCM", "reviewerName": "N. Rengler", "verified": true, "reviewText": "I didn't have any design or function problems with my unit, at all.  It worked fine right out of the box.  For my purpose (heating a tent or a small bedroom in case of a power outage), I'd buy it again (and the price is right).  BTW, the Winter temps in northwest WA are usually pretty mild at sea level, so although the 1500 BTU output isn't much, it is all I need.\n\nThe very first time I lit my unit, I was puzzled why it took 5 or 6 clicks of the insta-start spark to light it, even though Coleman predicts this in their instructions.  By telling you to start clicking the spark right after opening the valve, I suspect Coleman is making sure you don't let a large amount of propane build up before you hit the button.  In other words, I suspect it takes the same amount of time to click the starter 5 or 6 times as for the unit to build up enough propane to light.  When it does, there is a small poof of blue and yellow flame.  True, if you waited a few minutes after you open the valve to click the starter, one click might be enough to light the unit, but you might also lose your eyebrows (or worse).\n\nOne thing for sure... run your heater outside or maybe in your garage for a LONG time when it is brand new.  In fact, I'd say use up a whole container of propane to break it in.  The reason for this is that the smell this heater puts out when it is new is nasty!  Ever get a rug stuck in the rotating brush of your vacuum cleaner, and the rubber drive belt starts to smoke?  Well, it's like that smell TIMES TEN!  I couldn't find any mention of the odor or warnings about toxicity in the Coleman booklet, so Coleman must not think is is harmful.  But, believe me, it sure is unpleasant and Coleman should mention the idea of \"breaking in\" the heater when new.  After I ran about 3/4 of a tank of propane through my new heater, the smell was completely gone.  But, fair warning... break this puppy in, before you bring it inside with you.\n\nOtherwise, no complaints, and I'd buy it again and recommend it to you.  Stay warm out there!", "overall": 4.0, "reviewTime": "11 4, 2008", "summary": "Break It In, Before You Use It", "unixReviewTime": 1225756800}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "4", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "02 6, 2013", "reviewerID": "A38VQ2TIPPBKNN", "asin": "B0009PUTCU", "reviewerName": "Sir Charles Panther", "reviewText": "If you're a real trekker, carrying all your gear, tent, food and water, then this is not the product for you.  These are very heavy-duty tent stakes, suitable for a very large tent, or for securing a tent that is going to be in very windy weather.  They are big and heavy, way too much for lightweight or weight-conscious camping.\n\nThat being said, in the three-odd years I've had these stakes, they go in and they stay in.  This is for hand placement or a stomp with a boot.  If you're using a hammer, and you run these things down into the earth, they are as secure as you can get, and it's going to take a tornado to take your tent away.  But, surprisingly, they have always come out very easily.  They usually come out with a simple hand pull, or I just hook one stake into the other, and they come out with this method.\n\nI have experienced absolutely no bending with these stakes.  They have not even had their blades bent or warped from emplacement or removal.  They are very tough, very sturdy, and will retain their shape.\n\nMy only complaint is that they stain very easily and quickly.  After one campout there was considerable staining on all stakes from contat with earth.  They always clean up easily in hot water with a quick brush.  They still work fine, and still have not rusted, but they are very blotchy, as the staining is black/dark gray.  This staining has had no effect on performance.\n\nBottom line: for car camping or other equipment-heavy camping, or for use where your tent or fly or shelter needs to be secure, this is a great purchase, well worth the price.  But for true trekking and hike-in/out camping, these are really more than you need.", "summary": "Very Sturdy Stakes, Heavy", "unixReviewTime": 1360108800}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "81", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 2, 2006", "reviewerID": "A209QRVZ99UQDC", "asin": "B0009PUQFU", "reviewerName": "Calamity Jane", "reviewText": "I keep this lantern handy for power outages. I plan to take it camping next time I go. I recommend keeping the Styrofoam case that protects the glass globe. It's much easier to dismantle and store the unit without fear of breaking the globe.\n\nThis two-mantle lantern throws out lots of light. It starts easily with a match.\n\nI don't like the way the propane tank sits in the base. To move the lantern from one room to the next you must support the plastic base, otherwise it falls off.\n\nVery important! Do not over-tighten the top ventilator nut. The glass globe will crack because it has no room to expand when it heats up. I cracked two globes before contacting Coleman, who showed me the error of my ways.\n\nDespite the problems, this is a great lantern, and it's much easier to use than Coleman's pump version that uses liquid fuel.\n\n****UPDATE**** October 2011. I still use the same lantern for camping and power outages.\n\n****UPDATE**** February 2017. The lantern stills works beautifully. We've changed the mantle a few times, but that's expected.  This Coleman still goes with us on every camping trip. And despite the arguments I receive from some readers of my reviews, we use this lantern indoors to light our way during a power outage. The best part is that we never have to worry about dead/weak batteries when a storm unexpectedly knocks out the power. We keep a couple of propane tanks on hand at all times.", "summary": "Perfect", "unixReviewTime": 1149206400}

I'm nostalgic for the lanterns of old, but I have to admit this version does everything they did.  No fuel to spill, it burns great, you can adjust the light output and it breaks down to a small size without the tank.  I set this up a home with the mantles, packed it away and went camping at a campground with no electricity, when night came and I wanted light, out came the lantern.  On the first night when I turned down the light because I didn't need it at full throttle, it whistled for about two seconds on low, the next two nights it didn't make the sound at all.\n\nA few things to remember folks, this thing uses combustion to light, it burns propane, keep it away from flammable material it will get hot, don't use it in an enclosed space, and allow it to cool before putting in a tent for overnight storage. {"reviewerID": "ALDV8DDZWWPYE", "asin": "B0009PURP4", "reviewerName": "Miss Darcy", "verified": false, "reviewText": "Today I used a battery-powered pump, purchased for under ten dollars at the grocery store of all places, to inflate this for the first time. It is true that it takes some guesswork to assemble the paddles correctly. Basically, the instructions don't explain that the closed end of the poles is where you attach the paddles; this creates a seal and then water doesn't seep into the poles.\n\nAnyway, since it was the first time, it probably took 10 minutes or more to inflate but the process was very simple. The air chambers are numbered so you know which part to inflate first.\n\nIt's a little tricky closing the plugs without letting all the air out (because it is built to deflate quickly). My sister-in-law made the smart decision of keeping the pump running and then quickly pulling it out and closing the plug. In any case, it's very manageable.\n\nThen we took it out into the pond, on a day windy enough for whitecaps. We could not believe how well it tracked. It actually has two skegs, which my quite expensive, \"real\" kayak lacks.\n\nThe paddles do drip but again, compared to my hundred-dollar \"real\" paddle (the price of this entire inflatable package), they do an excellent job. Just plan to get a bit wet (bathing suit bottoms recommended!).\n\nMy 82-year-old dad, who has been avoiding tippy canoes and can't get in my \"real\" kayak at all, came with me and he LOVED it. It was so nice to be able to get him back on the water again.\n\nMy six-year-old did not come with me---it was really too windy---but I tried both the front and back seats myself and I feel confident that she will be able to sit very securely in the front seat. Even as the waves bounced us up and down the kayak felt very sturdy.\n\nI really can't say enough good things about this kayak. My only advice would be that if you plan to paddle alone often, you might want to consider a single---this one is surprisingly large.  One middle-aged and one elderly thumbs-up!!", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "05 25, 2009", "summary": "So much fun for such a great price", "unixReviewTime": 1243209600}

As much hassle as real mantels can be, they emit the most pure and brightest light I can imagine. I've bought and owned several battern-powere lantern, but none comes close to propane for sheer illumination. If you're camping alone in a relatively remote area, it's nice to put this lantern on a rock or tree stump and have good vision for quite a distance (easily 50' if you're burning on high power).\n\nAs someone else mentioned I think there needs to be a better way to attach the base (though sometimes I just stick the propane tank in a pile of gravel or dirt and it's pretty steady) so that you can move the lantern quickly. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "20", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 28, 2009", "reviewerID": "A1G8USRY17IR1X", "asin": "B0009PUT5C", "reviewerName": "Michael D. Adams", "reviewText": "I recently purchased the Coleman Dry Gear Bag (size Small - 24\" x 10\") from Amazon for a 4-wheeling trip to West Virginia. As it turned out, I didn't really need to use it, but in case it rained I wanted to have it with me.\n\nAs usual, the shipping from Amazon was speedy, and I received the bag in under a week. Unfortunately, I wish I had taken more time to look at my local Bass Pro shop first. This bag is around a 20oz bag, which I found to be almost too small for what I needed/wanted it for. It's also a very stiff bag. The little loops that are attached are nice, as is the translucent see-thru nature of the plastic. But in terms of overall construction quality, it's not as nice as a 30oz bag I could have gotten locally for around $12.\n\nHonestly, I'm not 100% certain that this bag would be the best if there were a chance of it getting submerged or sitting in standing water. After putting items in mine and rolling it, I could still push air out. That tells me the seal wasn't very solid/complete. Conversely, I have a small \"<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/SealLine-Baja-Dry-Bags-Spring-2010/dp/B0009RNVPA/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">SealLine Baja Dry Bags (Spring 2010)</a>\" bag that I can NOT do that on. And the bag I tried out at Bass Pro could have doubled as a pillow with the way it held air.\n\nIn the end, it's caveat emptor. You get what you are paying for with this bag. If you are looking for something cheap and simple just to keep the rain or mud off of your stuff, then this might be a good choice for a relatively low price. But if you are looking for something that is more durable and air-tight, I'd encourage you to take a look at some of your other options, both on Amazon and at stores like Bass Pro or Cavenders.", "summary": "An OK bag for the price", "unixReviewTime": 1256688000}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "4", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 24, 2017", "reviewerID": "A2SWZBHFAUKRP1", "asin": "B0009PUQAA", "reviewerName": "Phil", "reviewText": "Hard to find propane adaptor.  I used this adaptor to attach the female end of my propane extension line to my 20 lb propane tank instead of attaching to the one pound throw away propane bottles. Think of it as a coupler between a 20 lb propane tank (or larger) and a propane extension line.", "summary": "Adds versatility to your propane extension lines.", "unixReviewTime": 1498262400}
{"image": ["https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71AhDoNv10L._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71wnZRjLWBL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/819YOP-hpFL._SY88.jpg"], "overall": 5.0, "vote": "15", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "01 18, 2017", "reviewerID": "A1IJAYV7XM5MRQ", "asin": "B0009PUQAA", "reviewerName": "kenny", "reviewText": "After reading the reviews, I wasn't sure what type of adapter I was going to receive. Some reviews said it can be used to refill 1 lbs. canisters and others said it can't. Others said it's only good to be used for the 8 feet extension hose. Okay, here's the lo down on this adapter. One end of the adapter is a POL connection. It is a male connection. You counter clockwise screw it into your 20, 30, 40, etc. propane tank.. The other end of the adapter is a male 1\" X 20 throwaway propane canister threading. It is the exact same male threading as those 1 lbs. green Coleman propane canister or 14.1 oz. blue Bernzomatic  propane canister. So you can not screw those canisters into this adapter as both are male threading  therefore this adapter is NOT for refilling those canisters if that is your intention. I bought this for the purpose of using a 20 lbs. propane tank  instead of the 1 lbs. canisters so this was the correct adapter I needed. This adapter will fit into ANY female 1\" X20 throwaway propane canister threading and not just the 8 feet extension hose. I have the Bernzomatic 5 ft. extension hose and it works great. I connect the POL end into the 20 lbs. tank, I connect (screw in) the female end (which has the pin) of the hose onto the other end of the adapter (the male 1\"X 20 throwaway canister threading) and then I connect (screw in) the other end of the 5 ft. extension hose into my Bernzomatic torch.  You can attach any appliances that uses the 1 lbs.propane canisters onto the adapter. Those appliances or hose should all have the female 1\" X 20 throwaway canister threading. with the pin in the middle. If you some how have a female threading WITHOUT a pin in the middle, it is the wrong fitting and will not work with this adapter.\nThe adapter is of excellent quality. The POL screw part is a loose sleeve with a fitted hex nut. It screws in and on easily on both ends. You might need a wrench but I had not problem tightening it by hand. If you only have the POL end of the adapter screwed in and you open the tank valve, no propane should be released. Otherwise you didn't tight the adapter enough and it's leaking by the threading or the adapter itself is defective and it's leaking through the center hole. A/o 1/17/2017, the Amazon picture is exactly the adapter I received.", "summary": "Excellent adapter and great quality. POL by male 1\" X 20 throwaway canister threading", "unixReviewTime": 1484697600}

{"reviewerID": "A2R2FEL51LG2AW", "asin": "B0009PURP4", "reviewerName": "Monkey Bingo", "verified": true, "reviewText": "This is a great boat. In its deflated form, it can fit under a modestly high bed or in a closet. With a pump, it inflates in about 5 minutes. It isn't too heavy (though might be a bit much for a child). It won't go fast, but goes faster than you might think. On calm water, it is surprising easy to power and maneuver. The going gets rough with even a little bit of current.\n\nThe paddles come in sections that you screw together. They are adequate for calm water. Buyer Beware for stronger current. I was recently paddling against a minor current in Biscayne Bay and one of the plastic pieces where you place your hands snapped in two. {"reviewerID": "AJMNUWFYAZBX9", "asin": "B0009PURP4", "reviewerName": "David", "verified": true, "reviewText": "My wife and I took this Coleman inflatable kayak out for the first time today on Lake Ray Hubbard in the DFW area. I received it Wednesday in a very compact box and inside, it had the kayak, instructions, and 2 kayaking oars that came in 7 pieces each. These went together quickly, and come with collars that separate each oar into 3 pieces for easy transport and storage.\n\nWhen I unfolded the kayak for the first time I was really amazed at just how big it is. I'm 6'2\" and my wife is 5'7\". Both of us fit very comfortably and there is probably enough leg room for someone up to about 6'6\" or so to feel really comfortable. There is a storage area in the front and the back that's triangular in shape. We brought along some snacks and drinks in a plastic bag, but I'd be willing to bet you could get a small cooler in there as well.\n\nAs for performance on the water, it worked better than I had expected. We launched from the shore over some floating debris and the sides barely displaced 2\" of water with a combined weight of 320 between us. It was very stable to get into and out of because it's wide and has seems that allow the side air pockets to pivot and stay still while the bottom moves as you move around. It was a little slow over the water because of the same width and it's also because of the width that I have my only gripe. The included oars are a bit short for the size of this boat, which means you are going to get wet if you plan on getting anywhere in a decent amount of time... you are forced to swing the oars over so far that the opposite oar drips right on top of you.\n\nWe did encounter some boat wake, and it took that no problem straight on and at an angle. I would not be surprised if it even took a parallel wake without flipping. It just feels that stable. I wouldn't recommend taking it out in a lot of chop, however... the kayak does move and gyrate a whole lot when you encounter different levels of water.\n\nBlowing up and packing couldn't be any easier. I bought an Ozark Trail large volume hand pump from Walmart to make my life easier, and I was able to fully inflate the kayak in just over 6 minutes from empty. There are numbers on each of the 8 valves that tell you the order to inflate in. Deflating for me was as easy as undoing all of the valves and rolling the kayak one way, then unrolling and rolling the other way. It collapsed on it's own to a size small enough for even the smallest trunk.\n\nI expect to get a lot of use out of the kayak this summer. It's very fast to set up and a lot of fun... just remember that the oars are going to get you wet.", "overall": 4.0, "reviewTime": "05 19, 2007", "summary": "Fun and Easy!", "unixReviewTime": 1179532800}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "04 14, 2015", "reviewerID": "A24MN4ZKLCY1EH", "asin": "B0009PUPX8", "reviewerName": "K. moon", "reviewText": "I just tried this out and I like it. BUT, I do want to answer the people that could not get it lit. I couldn't either, Until I watched a youtube video. It seems the instructions aren't very clear about opening up the priming pump. It says to turn it to open and hold your thumb over the end. when I did this, I couldn't push it in and pump.\n\nAfter watching the video I finally realized that I wasn't turning the end to the open position. It must be turned counter (anti) clockwise about 3 times before it is truly open. Only then can you hold your thumb over the hole and prime it 30 times. once I did this it fired right up!\n\nSo don't think its going to break because you feel tension when turning it to open it, just use some force on it when turning it to open and then it works great. Also remember to slowly release the pressure when undoing the filler cap or it will explode gas out!", "summary": "I finally figured it out! A 1 star review turned into 5!", "unixReviewTime": 1428969600}

{"reviewerID": "AYVDD924CHR1", "asin": "B0009PURP4", "reviewerName": "Sandy Beach", "verified": true, "reviewText": "I bought this inflatable kayak primarily because several local adventure races require soft-sided boats.  It turns out to be one of the best $100 purchases ever, and I'm using it much more than I had originally thought. I love the ease of rolling it up, tossing it in the car trunk and being ready to hit the water almost anywhere. I've used it in the Gulf of Mexico, in the bay, and little inlets and it handles pretty well, even with a non-paddling passenger. It's a fun way to poke around the wetlands, do some birding, etc.--with its shallow draft you can paddle in literally inches of water. Because it is wider and flatter than most kayaks, the wind will push it a bit, but it's fairly responsive and maneuverable, even fully loaded. Definitely spring for the rechargable inflator, which does the job in less than five minutes. The paddles could be better, but they're OK for the money. This kayak is a great option for someone who'd like to paddle sometimes but doesn't want the hassle of storing a kayak, strapping it to the roof of their car, or dragging it to a launching spot. The price works out to be about the same as just a couple days of kayak rentals, and it opens up so many possibilities of kayaking where there aren't any rentals.", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "06 5, 2006", "summary": "Cheap fun!", "unixReviewTime": 1149465600}

This is plenty of fuel and will last 5 days under light use. Refilling is easy enough and you should use one of those&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-Filtering-Funnel/dp/B0000AS5QB/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman Filtering Funnel</a>. I sometimes just pour it into the lantern from the fuel bottle.\n\nThe control knob feels very cheap on the propane lantern and there are sort of preset clicks for different levels of intensity, this is a nice feature, the globe seems pretty hefty.\nIt's fairly well built but I would worry about the footing that slide out possibly breaking off.\nThe propane tank sits tight inside the base.\n\nI will most likely donate this to the Boy Scouts with my&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Coleman-2-Burner-Dual-Fuel-Powerhouse-Liquid-Fuel-Stove/dp/B00006I56J/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Coleman 2-Burner Dual Fuel Powerhouse Liquid Fuel Stove</a>\n\nIf you plan on replacing a liquid gas lantern with propane, Don't , unless you plan to use this for Scouts.\n\nYou may be disappointed, however, I would highly recommend this item for a&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Stansport-Distribution-Post-2-Piece-30-in-3-Outlet/dp/B005EUE1II/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Stansport Distribution Post - 2 Piece - 30 in. - 3 Outlet</a>&nbsp;or a&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Century-Two-Piece-18-30-Type-1-Safety-Post-with-Bag/dp/B0007LQ26S/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Century Two-Piece 18-30\" Type 1 Safety Post with Bag</a>&nbsp;but as a primary lantern that will get hung in a tree, placed on the ground, placed on a picnic table etc...,I suggest spending the extra cash and getting a Dual Fuel Lantern.\nI hope this was helpful.\n\n*UPDATE 2013/10/22\nUsed this on a recent C.O.P.E trip with the Boy Scouts and worked well, the base worked fine. I really hate to mothball my gasser, but for Scouts this is much more practical. I will be ordering a Propane tree and will update again.\nI updated my rating from 3 stars to 4, for the simple fact that it does what it is intended to do and it's a fair price for what you are getting.\nI keep the Gasser when camping in the trailer.\n\n*UPDATE 2015/02/22\nI mentioned earlier in this review about the presets being a nice feature, However, after my most recent trip I am not happy with the presets.\nUsing this in a tent (please no comments on using in a tent) on our winter camping trip I realized the presets suck, the lowest setting was too low so the next click up was too bright, we tried running on the lowest setting but it let out a horrible whistling sound.\nThis is still a decent lantern but proved to be  a bad choice in our 8 man tent. I have since opted to order the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Primus-Micron-Lantern/dp/B00EE67FVS/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Primus Micron Lantern</a>, I will review this later.\nI left the rating for 4 starts because these cons will not apply to most folks.", "summary": "It's worth the money but you get what you pay for.", "unixReviewTime": 1373587200}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "38", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "04 8, 2012", "reviewerID": "A3EQ2ODWLGDAPZ", "asin": "B0009PUQFU", "reviewerName": "Brandon Solomon", "reviewText": "Me and some buddies go camping once a year and I (the camping guru) would always bring the battery operated bulb lanterns. Well, this past year, a friend brought along one of these and the difference was staggering. If you turn that dial as high as it goes, you can practically simulate daylight. He put it on a stand and we were able to spot a snake that was, ironically, closest to my lantern. Needless to say, I purchased one of my own the first chance I got.\n\nI prefer this model to the self-ignition version due to the fact that the more hands-on something is, the more proficient one becomes in using it. Also, it will be easier to spot when something is wrong with the unit this way. The last thing one wants to discover is that something has rendered their lantern useless that could very well have been predicted and fixed before the next outing.\n\nInsofar as the base goes, I have done away with the flaps that come with it and fashioned my own out of a paint can. I sprayed it with Rustoleum and then cut a hole in the top to barely accommodate the propane cylinder and flared out the base in order to create a near indestructible base that weighs practically nothing and can be strapped to the outside of a pack without worry about rust. I also went so far as to keep a carabiner on hand to attach to the handle and, along with some 550 cord, I am able to affix it to any tree, should the need arise.\n\nThis has come in handy for those times when I have lost a race against the sun and still have a couple miles to go before making it the distance I had planned to travel for the day before resting. When these times strike, I attach it to a propane hose and keep the tank in my backpack (to better accommodate the weight so I can keep the light held high for longer). I have even, from time to time, attached it to a stick to hold out before me to better show the terrain and judge elevation better.\n\nI keep another one at home (permanently affixed to a hose w/ a stand), along with some 20lb propane canisters for whenever the weather knocks out power. I'll have a strong light source to keep working and have even used it to show my way when shoveling snow at night.\n\nTo the point: This lantern is one of those purchases that will always come in handy. It can be used for emergency home situations and outdoor, alike. Keep an eye on the mantles and when they go on sale, stock up. You may never need all of them, but they will at least be around in case you do.\n\nFinally, a word of WARNING: This lantern can get hot enough to ignite or melt nearby objects. For this reason, it would not be very safe to use in a tent or around combustible items. I have seen people, pinched in an emergency, use this as a tent heater; needless to say, I'd have to be in a very difficult situation before I attempted going down that same route. I definitely wouldn't fall asleep in a tent with this on.", "summary": "Night turned to Day", "unixReviewTime": 1333843200}

{"image": ["https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/51iswmjZ8gL._SY88.jpg"], "overall": 5.0, "vote": "15", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 13, 2012", "reviewerID": "A1731WPMYLOSF7", "asin": "B0009PUPX8", "reviewerName": "GearGuy", "reviewText": "I'm the third generation in my family to use Coleman. Mine arrived this morning and I immediately set it up and prepared breakfast and percolated coffee. It was a real nostalgia trip setting it up and using this stove. Some of my earliest memories are watching my Dad set up 'this' stove in Yosemite, fussing to get it lit, and cooking over it. The clanking metal, pump sounds, and hissing sounds of operation are all  distant but familiar memories.\nThis version is still Made In The USA, in Wichita Kansas; I probably wouldn't have bought it otherwise.\nIt still folds up and secures with a strong metal clasp, and carries like a little suitcase.\nThe fuel bottle has been re-designed, and seems to be an improvement. For safety reasons it must be taken off, rested on its side, filled, then put back on. Its dead simple, two tabs and notches.\nWith routine maintenance I expect this nearly identical model to last 30 years or more just like the previous one did.\nHighly recommended for those campers who actually enjoy operating machinery.\n\n5 year UPDATE Ive used this several times a year, year round. The valves and gaskets are holding up, and it still essentially operates like new. The metal rusts where exposed, so I suggest repainting the bare spots as needed. Id still buy this model again despite the newer butane types; I prefer liquid fuel and the option to use gasoline.
