{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "23", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 30, 2012", "reviewerID": "ABKUJX7YJZ3DA", "asin": "B0009PUPX8", "reviewerName": "The Suburban Hippie Experimentalist", "reviewText": "UPDATE:  I have had this stove for 3 years now, and have used it quite a lot, and have never had a problem with it.\nWe are also just bought our second camper, which has a suburban propane stove, hooked to a 25 pound propane bottle, and we still take this little guy along with us, set it up on the picnic table and cook outdoors.\n\nI just couldn't be happier with this little guy.  Everything I said in my original review still holds true!\n\nOriginal Review below is still valid\n\nI haven't had this stove long, but I just cooked dinner on it, and did a review.  Go to Youtube, and type in \"themarkfellows2\" and look for my review.  It will be uploaded tonight, and ready for viewing in the morning.  I cooked a large pot of Chicken, Egg Drop soup, and it performed great, with plenty of power from the main burner(I didn't use the auxiliary burner, but I am sure it is fine).  I boiled 8 cups of chicken broth, 2 cups of water, and cooked 2 pounds of chicken, and vegetables, in about 30 minutes.  Start to finish.  The stove, lights, and works very well.  The Auxiliary burner is easy to light, and extinguish.\n\nI used Coleman fuel that was AT LEAST 10 years old, and maybe 20 years old, and left first, in a porch exposed to cold, and heat, and sunlight.  It burned just fine.\n\nI have found Coleman fuel to be Extremely stable.\n\nPropane is more stable, and burns cleaner, but I just can not justify using those little 1 pound bottles, and then chucking them in the trash when they are empty.  It just seems really stupid to me to use those.\n\nIf they have an adapter to make one of those propane stoves use a 20 pound bottle, more power to you.  I will stick with liquid fuel if I can.  It generates much less waste than the 1 pound bottles, and you can get fuel anywhere.  Plus, this can run on gasoline if you wish.\n\nAnyway, back to the stove.  It is great.  It lights easily, has plenty of power, has great fine adjustment on the heat, and burns very steadily after the first five minutes, and the generator heats up.\n\nThis will be a fine stove for my car camping( I already have an MSR Dragonfly for backpacking).\n\nOne big plus was that it was manufactured in the USA.  That means a lot to me, over Chinese goods.\n\nBe aware though, the first couple times you use it, you will likely burn some paint off, so you will smell burning paint fumes a little, if you have the burner turned up high.\n\nAlso, the stove body gets hot, so keep stuff that will melt away from it.\n\nI put a video on youtube, where I cook a pot of soup with 20 year old coleman fuel.  Go to youtube, and look for \"the suburban hippie survivalist\" and look for my video on it.\n\nGood luck!\n\nMark :)", "summary": "Good little stove, with plenty of power", "unixReviewTime": 1333065600}

Plus, the cost of tanks is pretty expensive, and I can never tell how much is left in them.  I love being able to bring 2 or 3 tins of fuel (yes, I know, overkill) and know that we'll never run out.  The cost of the fuel tins is so much cheaper than propane tanks.\n\nI also like the fact that I can tell how much fuel is in the front tank. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "6", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 8, 2010", "reviewerID": "A1A277WR7LH40U", "asin": "B0009PUPX8", "reviewerName": "Madmaxinsa", "reviewText": "I received the stove yesterday.  No problems with shipping or packaging.  I purchased a 1 gallon can of Coleman fuel at WalMart for about $7.  The stove came with a filter funnel which made filling easy.  The stove instructions were a little hard to read but this is a simple product.  I pumped the stove about 40 pumps to pressurize the stove.  I lit the stove and there was very high yellow flames initially so keep your windscreen out of the way so you don't overheat the paint.  I opened up both burners and let it rock for 3-5 minutes.  Soon the wild yellow flame disappeared and I got a nice blue flame.  I turned the stove off and it burned out in 30 seconds.  It is a small cooking area.  If you are hosting a large camp site and plan to be using very large pots and pans you might want to look at the 3 burner.  This would be fine for a small base camp with small to medium size cookware.  This would easily serve well for a 2-4 person camp.  I liked that the instructions were posted on a sticker inside the lid.  They show it being lit with a match but i think it would be safer and easier to use a long lighter if you have one.  WalMart had the stove for $78.00. with tax it would be about $85.00.  It was $88.00 online, $78.00 in store.\n\nOne last but important note.  The instructions say you can use unleaded fuel if necessary.  It is the \"if necessary\" language that bothers me.  That is legal speak for \"you can use unleaded fuel but we prefer you to use Coleman fuel.\"  If that is the case, you might be better off just buying the stove that operates on Coleman fuel.  I saw a post that talked about unleaded fuel containing ethanol corroding the seals but I cant verify this.  Overall a good piece of equipment.  Happy trails.", "summary": "nice little stove", "unixReviewTime": 1275955200}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "7", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "04 3, 2010", "reviewerID": "A21DAKV9WGV6BY", "asin": "B0009PUPX8", "reviewerName": "C. Twining", "reviewText": "I just bought a second one of these for my folks to have for car camping and earthquake preparedness. I have had the other one for over ten years and it just keeps on fine. These are very durable little stoves. They are easy to use ( except that you need a match or lighter) and are very stable. Certainly much more so than the 1 burner camping stoves you see for backpacking etc. As far as the requiring a match, its actually just simpler that way. You can always find matches at a store but you won't often find the replacement parts for an ignitor unit when it finally needs to be replaced.\n\n A lot of people like the propane stoves but then they waste a lot of those expensive canisters. A ten dollar gallon can of fuel for this thing will last as longer than 15 of the propane tanks for most stoves. And of course being able to run it on unleaded gasoline in an emergency is a very useful feature for earthquake/ emergency preparedness.  I have actually used my stove for weeks on end while camping. If you are in an emergency situation this will allow you to boil water and still make good hot food when your gas line or electricity is out.\n\nThere is enough space that you can use pretty decent size pots and pans. For instance when I make my spaghetti and italian sausage there is plenty of room to boil the water in a big pot while cooking up the italian sausage in a skillet right next to it. If you are really worried about space, have a big family etc, than you should consider the three burner variant of this stove.\n\nIf you are a car camper or want a good little stove for emergency situations this is the one for you.", "summary": "Useful little stove for car camping or emergency planning", "unixReviewTime": 1270252800}

I must have one myself now that I am older and do my own camping more often than the family camping. She's 79 and still organizes a family camping trip every other summer.\n\nAnyways, this stove is very much like the old-school units, escept I think the steel is a little thinner. I think it is sturdy enough though. The Dual Fuel designation allows me to use less expensive gasoline instead of Coleman fuel. My experience with gasoline on this stove is the same as using Coleman fuel. It is easy to light, and as long as I follow the lighting instructions word for word, I don't have any issues with flooding burners or high yellow flames. I like how the windscreen really works, and how the tank stores inside and then the windscreen folds down and closes like a lid, making the stove look like a green metal briefcase.\n\nThis is a must-have for anyone who does car camping or state-park style modern camping. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "3", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 31, 2013", "reviewerID": "A15DGSXL2W8I6A", "asin": "B0009PUS6M", "reviewerName": "Neato", "reviewText": "I've owned many camp stoves over the past half century; cheap and expensive ones. Been using this one regularly for seven years or so and it's possibly the best single-burner stove I've used for car camping.\n\n Unlike most single-burners, its large footprint, rubber feet and low profile make it very stable, especially with larger pots & pans. This makes it safer than others; important if you've got kids around. Nothing more disappointing than having a nice pot of chili cooking and have it tip over into little Johnny's lap.\n\n Easy to set up and get cooking right away. No liquid fuel to spill, no odor, no pumping or waiting for a generator to heat up. I've used it in windy conditions and it's rarely blown out.\n\n Easy to clean. Many stoves have a lot of exposed parts on top that catch spilled food. This one doesn't. The large painted surface around the burner stays relatively cool, so I haven't had to scrub any burned food. It just wipes off.\n\n Very sturdy. I've used heavy cast iron pots without fear of crushing it. The pot supports go down to the feet rather than into the stove itself.\n\n A few tips:\n\n This stove can simmer fairly well at the lowest setting and has a large diameter burner that spreads the heat heat out better than smaller ones. However, a simple diffuser plate (many available here on Amazon) on top of the burner helps this (and most other type) stove keep from scorching food in the center of the pan. Very useful if using thin aluminum camping pots.\n\n A little powdered graphite applied to the threads of the propane fitting makes it easier to thread the bottle into it.\n\n Protect the fittings of the propane tube assembly form dirt/damage. I keep the assembly in a ziplock bag. Be careful not to cross-thread the bottle when screwing it into the fitting.\n\n Propane isn't as cheap as liquid Coleman fuel for the same heat output, but at ~$2 for a 1# propane bottle that will generally last for many hours' cooking, not bad. No need for the expensive little proprietary cans that other stoves use. Can also be hooked up to a larger tank if need be.\n\n This is a great item for anyone wanting to simplify their camp cooking. Can't say enough good about it!", "summary": "Best single burner I've found", "unixReviewTime": 1364688000}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "3", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "12 13, 2012", "reviewerID": "A1M6G5R2AK56W1", "asin": "B0009PUS6M", "reviewerName": "Matthew", "reviewText": "I bought this for my stepdad as a gift. So, I haven't actually used it. It does appear however, to be of the same quality as the two burner Coleman I do own. This 1-burner model is well made. It's definitely designed in a way that could accept either a small coffee pot or other camping pot all the way up to a nice sized cast iron skillet or a huge regular sized pot of water usually used for boiling spaghetti or the like. I went with this product because of its stability. I love the low profile and wide base. It will really give a nice pot of chili the stability you need when cooking and stirring. The other models that screw directly onto the burner seemed like they'd be top heavy or would need a really level surface to be able to relax a little while cooking. It's got a good weight to it - durable enough to know it'll support what you're cooking, but not so heavy that it's going to be a pain in the ass to take places. This is the perfect burner for the weekend camper, the car camper, the occasional camper....basically any camper that's not going on a 5 day backpacking excursion. It's also a good \"just in case\" burner in case you lose electricity or need something in an emergency situation. I also like that it attaches to the smaller gas tanks that are cheap and convenient to pack and carry. It may not be absolutely wind resistant, but its low profile gives someone with a little ingenuity plenty of options to fashion up some sort of wind barrier if it comes to that. I haven't actually used this yet, but like I said it looks and feels a lot like my two burner Coleman and that one has worked flawlessly for years without any issues whatsoever. It even has the same gas attachment as my other Coleman, so it looks like they just took things and reconfigured for a single burner model. I really can't foresee this model acting up, but I will update as I have a chance to. For the price, I couldn't pass this up. Great value. I only gave it 4 stars because I haven't actually used it yet. So that rating is based on my initial observations and my past experience with Coleman burners.\n\nWhile I don't own any 14.1 oz tanks, I imagine those would work just fine. The 16.9 oz are the commonly featured tank and I know those fit perfectly with this stove. I believe the bushings/threads are the same on the 14.1 oz tanks. I also know they sell 14.1/16.9 oz-to-20 lb tank adapters so that you can hook this puppy up to a 20 lb. tank. {"overall": 2.0, "vote": "64", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 23, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1D70YKLWLTJE7", "asin": "B0009PUS6M", "reviewerName": "Loren", "reviewText": "I have used this stove for both car camping and cooking at bike races and like a few things about it. One is that it is much more stable than the typical single burner stoves, so putting a large pot or pan on the grates is not a problem. In addition, the propane gas cylinders are quite cheap in comparison to the jetboils or other small tank stoves, so it is cheaper to operate.\n\nOn the other hand, there are a few easy fixes that would make this a better product. One is that the unit requires a small extension tube to connect to the fuel tank and this needs to be unscrewed and carried separately. The bottom of the stove has lots of room but that is taken up by a rather useless piece of aluminum that could easily have been modified to allow the tank connector to snap into place, so it is not lost in moving the unit around. Organization is particular important for camping as you have lots of stuff, and if one of the parts is missing, it means the unit is worthless.\n\nIn addition, the aluminum piece on the bottom is razor sharp, so while cleaning it this evening, I brushed my thumb on the edge of the guard and had a nasty cut. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 11, 2017", "reviewerID": "A17AJYK7IMI5RZ", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "rmoco", "reviewText": "After several seasons with a Sport Brella, I've concluded umbrellas don't work at the beach because it's only a matter of time before the right gust uproots the Umbrella.  I've tried a number of anchoring methods, all with the same result.  I see only Pros and no Cons with the Coleman Road Trip Beach shade.  There are some practical Considerations.\n\nPros especially vs Any Umbrella:\n1) Uni-directional full shade for 2 in Beach Chairs.\n2) \"Front Porch\" flap lets you leave sand and damp towels outside your sitting area.\n3) Rear door enables ample circulation and eliminates gust-capsizing.\n4) Full zip-up offers full privacy or some security when you go in the water or head for snacks.\n5) 360 degree protection from a rain- or wind-storm.\n6) It CAN'T blow away since you and your gear are weighing it down!\n7) Oh, and it has a FLOOR! (you have the option of sitting or setting things anywhere!)\n8) Pockets at all 4 corners for sunglasses, snacks, keys, whatever.\n9) Less than half the pack size & weight yet more than twice the functionality of any Umbrella.\n10) No center pole! Wide open spaces!\n\nConsiderations:\n1) Takes longer to set up and pack up (but the benefits are definitely worth it!)\n2) If you're at a crowded beach, you'll block the ocean view of those behind you. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "77", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 2, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1EN86G2D5ABO5", "asin": "B0009PUS6M", "reviewerName": "Thomas H. Lawler", "reviewText": "I have some nephews starting into boy scouts and was interested in a stove they might like.  I liked the idea of one like this versus ones that sit on disposable tanks since it looks more stable (as well as being able to connect it to a bulk tank if wanted with a hose).  Looking at the online pictures I liked the way this one looked with round bars for the pot support (versus bent sheet metal supports in similar ones) and thought \"That looks better if someone did try to carry such in a back-pack since it won't have knife-blade like edges easily ripping into things\".  So I ordered one up even with seeing some reviews of \"This is bigger than I expected\" thinking it may be ~8-10 inches across versus ~6-8 (and not seeing anyone giving dims on it).  The truth is that the main body is 12 inch diameter at the base, it is almost 14 inches across at the feet (the widest points) and the pot support bars will hold an 11 inch diameter pot with it sitting flat on the horizontal parts of the bars.  So maybe that tells you more about how \"Big\" it really is versus pictures of it alone (that are hard to scale with no comparisons).  This also explains to me why it goes for over $30 versus many single burner stoves going for $15-20 (that I wondered about too before ordering it).\nI'll keep it since having this may be as good or better than many 2 burner stoves (where putting a 11 inch pan on them ends up with almost 1/2 the pan hanging off the edges), but I hope this helps minimize surprises for others of you considering this.", "summary": "A \"Big\" single burner stove", "unixReviewTime": 1306972800}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "2", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "08 3, 2008", "reviewerID": "A1QMNQAXM75KJC", "asin": "B0009PUTES", "style": {"Color:": " 1PCS"}, "reviewerName": "J. C. Bednar", "reviewText": "This is a good little tool to take along with you on hiking/backpacking trips or to dig a SMALL trench around your tent if camping in order to re-divert rain water. It also comes with its own carrying pouch that easily slips onto any style belt. I suggest matching the belt size to the belt loop of the carrying pouch, otherwise this tool will dangle about and flop around while walking. I bought mine a Cabelas, so I paid a little extra for it. This tool is also good to keep inside your car, especially during winter. If you get stuck on an icy road, this tool will chip the ice quite nicely. I've read some of the reviews stating that this tool is heavy, doesn't stay connected, or they hurt themselves with it. True, this tool does weigh little more than the advertized pound; that's because it is made out of steel and steel tends to be heavy. This tool, when everything is screwed together tightly, does loosen itself over continued use, it wasn't designed to go prospecting for gold, digging a grave, or such. You might actually have to stop what you are doing and periodically re-tighten the connections. Read another review that someone hurt them selves with this item, well, good for you dumb a$%! He was most likely utilizing this item in an unsafe manner. Overall, this little shovel will do what you need it to do, provided that you are safety concious. Mine works just fine for digging the emergency poo parlors while hiking/backpacking. Believe it or not, that is what this little tools intended purpose was. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "4", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "04 22, 2011", "reviewerID": "A1OBIRO53S5X4Z", "asin": "B0009PUQVE", "reviewerName": "Arkaybee", "reviewText": "I grew up around this lantern while camping and wanted one of my own for a very long time.  It burns very bright with an easily adjustable dimmer.  If you want a real camping experience, ditch the LED lanterns and pick this baby up.  It comes with two mantels that are easy to tie on and \"prime.\"  I don't see any problems with the build quality of these later coleman lanterns.  The pump does have some plastic parts but oil it once a year and don't put crappy fuel (gasoline, kerosene) in it and it'll last forever.\n\nYes it is a little noisy (slight hissing sound, not a big deal) and yes it gets very hot.  It's a lantern for cryin' out loud.  Don't touch it, don't put it in your tent and don't leave it burning in some grass. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 21, 2017", "reviewerID": "A2X04TJEANY7EU", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "GalaxieBlast", "reviewText": "I burn. I burn very, very easily. My wife goes outside for five minutes and gets a fantastic tan. I'm a little bitter about that, but hey, we all have our shortcomings. Mine is that I crisp instead of tan. Our new apartment is about a 15 minute walk to the beach, and with her being from Virginia Beach, she loves the water. I decided to search around and find something that might spare me the agony of sitting on the beach for more than five minutes, and I found this.\n\nWhy the green color is cheaper than the others is beyond me, but a slight discount is a slight discount, so I went for it. Maybe there's better colors out there, but given the sea of lime green beach shades I've seen so far at the beach, I'd say we're all cheap and want to save what we can. The design is a bit tricky for me. I've put together various tents my whole life, and this one is a bit of a challenge. Personally I think the fabric tube for the cross-tube that goes longways across the shade is much to narrow, and it makes it tricky to get the pole to successfully stay in one piece while you're trying to set up the shade. I'm sure the more I use this the more I'll figure out its quirks, but I wasn't particularly pleased spending a massive amount of time putting this small thing together (and ripping some of the mesh tube) when I've put an 8 person tent together in what seemed like a much shorter amount of time.\n\nThe quality of the shade (other than the narrow pole tubes) is great. We spent several hours in the shade and it was very comfortable. The attached 'flooring' is a nice touch, though sand will get everywhere and if you're wet from the water when you sit down, it'll pool and sand will stick. I think next time we'll place towels down first. The stakes were great quality and I'm thrilled they were metal instead of plastic. The included bags to store everything were also well-made, and with some patience (aka giving my wife the tent and bag) the whole thing did end up fitting back into the storage tote. I will mention that even with the window in the back and the entrance to the tent being open, it does get pretty warm in there. It wasn't unbearable, but I did end up ordering two small battery-operated fans anyway to help circulate some air. I'm sure the majority of people won't need to do that, but if you're like me and you sweat and become very warm easily, then you may want to invest in some cheap fans.\n\nI'm super happy with this so far, and it has absolutely made my trips to the beach much more fun and much less painful, so for that, I'm very grateful!", "summary": "Thank you for saving my skin from certain combustion", "unixReviewTime": 1500595200}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "07 21, 2017", "reviewerID": "A36EXMLDJV00JQ", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Jon Doeringer", "reviewText": "I'm glad we got this one. It's well-made, and designed.\n(but the mesh sleeves for the poles should be solid. The curved mesh catches on the metal ferrules, and separates the links).\nWe've been using cabana's for almost 20 years, and love it! This is the biggest? (and 6\" too big for the beach we are headed to, in height and width. Beach police, beware!). If it's too high, I will scoop 6\" of sand out, below it.\nA TRICK for setting it up, solo - take at least 3 medium rubber bands along. When you get the rod through, band the rod to the tab with the grommet on it, so it won't pop out as soon as you turn your back, to work on the other end. SO much easier. I struggled in the living room, on the test run, before I remembered this. The dogs simulated the wind, and other problems on the beach...\nAnd I'm so glad they didn't send the one with the big lantern printed on the sides. That seemed a bit much.\nFor all those who don't like the mesh sleeves - you could cut a long strip of nylon fabric, the length of the pole sleeves, and sew it into a tube - which would go inside the mesh sleeves. You may need  to sew it to the ends of the sleeve, maybe more than that. A pain - but it would eliminate the mesh problem. A small rubber ball, stuck on the fwd end of the pole may help, too. (but the problem is when the ferrules catch, and the segments separate).\nAFTER using the tent, and seeing how wrong the mesh sleeves are for the poles to go thru, I went to Lowes and got 5' of 1/2\"OD plastic waterline. (not pvc). And I glued a cap on one end. Now, I start the tube in the sleeve, then push it the rest of the way through with the pole. Then, pull the tube out the other end This will save the mesh. But really - don't they make designers try these things out??? The mesh will quickly puncture, with the poles, as designed.\nThe tent was nice, with no problems. (you might want to put the filled sand bags in zip-lock bags? They don't hold sand that well). The carrying bag was well made, and the tent fit back in. But what would it cost them to add an inch of material, to make it easier?\nAnother tip - a strip of plastic or cardboard, for when you zip the bag up. This will stop the zipper from grabbing the tent, as you need one hand to pinch the sides together, and one to zip.", "summary": "Set-up trick- and water line", "unixReviewTime": 1500595200}

Reihart", "reviewText": "I have the older version of this heater without the auto lighting feature.  I've used this heater for about five years and can't say anything bad about it.  Originally I bought it for tent camping in a small tent.  During a cool rainy spell we stayed in the tent and were as snug as a bug in a rug.  (We being myself and my cocker spaniel).  I then went up to a popup camper and used it there as well and was pleased with the heat it put out for such a small heater.  This winter I've been using it in my small computer room and it has really warmed up the area if I keep the door closed except for about 6 inches.  I would recommend this heater to anyone.  Don't expect it to heat a large room or large tent.  But, for the price and the operating cost, you can't beat it.  I also recently ordered an adapter that allows you to refill the 1 lb bottles from a 20 lb tank.  You can't refill them indefinitely, but 3-4 times, which will save a bunch of money and you put less of these bottles into the landfill. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "150", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 7, 2006", "reviewerID": "A32Z1V9II49XZY", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "Adam S", "reviewText": "I took this heater camping in Delaware on Columbus Day weekend (October).  I used it in a well-ventilated 4-person (medium-sized) tent.  The first 2 days were cold and rainy, and I was VERY glad to have brought it.\n\nNow, this heater is not going to make your tent into a sauna on a very cold day, so don't expect to get in the tent and lounge in your skivies like you might do at home!  But after burning for about 10-15 min, it should raise the temperature in your tent several precious degrees making it bareable; even comfortable.  For instance, it did keep me from having to wear my heavy coat while inside the tent, which pleased me.\n\nSince it would certainly heat a smaller, less-vented tent better than a larger, more-vented tent, your results may vary.  As for me, the results were not dramatic, but certainly noticable, and well worth the money spent.\n\nNote: This kind of catalytic heater requires those mini propane tanks.  It works by a chemical reaction between a meshy platinum filter and the burning propane gas, so while there's no obvious propane smell and no open flame, there's still a very hot surface that could catch objects on fire if they are placed directly in front of it for too long.  FYI, when you first light it, you may indeed see an igniting flame, but that is just upon start up.  Once the starting flame vanishes, put your hand gently over the heater - if you feel it eminating warmth, you'll know you've started it successfully.\n\nWarning: Just as the instructions warn you, I do NOT recommend leaving this heater on through the night when you and your family are asleep.  It is both a breathing hazard, and an obvious fire hazard.  But warning stated, I did just that and I didn't have a problem.  I slept very comfortably on a couple cold nights and I didn't die in my sleep. Again, your results may vary.\n\nHowever, I should note that my own tent is extreamly well ventilated, with the entire ceiling being mesh under the rain fly.  In addition, the night was windy, and I could actually feel a breeze of air circulating in my tent.  In truth, if I had brought a less-ventilated, cold-weather tent with me that weekend, the heater may not have been needed at night, but since I was stuck with a drafty tent, I took the calculated risk that this would also lessen the threat.  In addition, I took every possible precaution to ensure that nothing was near the heater before going to sleep.  Even so, it's a risk that I could not blame anyone for not wanting to take.  Also, if you do this, expect the propane tank to be empty by morning.\n\nAll in all, other than the obvious handle-with-care factors, I could not find a downside to this product.  In fact, I could not imagine cold-weather camping without it.  P.S. They also sell a slightly cheaper version, which is the same in every way, except it does not have the self-starting switch, and you start it manually with a lit match.", "summary": "Pleased with performance.", "unixReviewTime": 1165449600}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "12 9, 2014", "reviewerID": "A2NJ9S9X35MWTB", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "CC Rider", "reviewText": "First of all, the price listed here is incorrect.  These retail at most sporting goods stores for between $80-$100.  The optional piezo-electric starter is not needed if you simply keep a lighter handy.\n\nI've used one of these while motorcycle camping for a couple years and it really works well.  It produces enough heat to raise the temperature of my 3-season, 4-man tent about 25 degrees when it dips below 30 outside, even with two screen walls.  That makes the difference between being really comfy and sleeping well, or being restless and waking throughout the night.\n\nThe heater will operate at full power for ~10 hours on one propane cartridge (I've run it that long), so you don't have to worry about it running out of fuel at 4:00 AM.  It operates silently but the heating surface does get very hot.  It will instantly melt/char nylon or other fabrics, so you have to very carefully place this thing away from tent walls, sleeping bags, inflatables, pets and clothes.  It also needs good ventilation, as it consumes a lot of oxygen.  Respect it and be smart and you'll be safe and warm all night...  Coleman understandably recommends not sleeping with it operating, but that's why we buy these things.\n\nI highly recommend that you test run it for a couple hours before using it in an enclosed space.  When new, it can produce a disagreeable odor, kinda like burnt metal and paint.  After being broken in - it's fine.\n\nThe plastic body which surrounds the heater is bulky.  The earlier version of this with a simple wire prop stand was much more compact.  Still, if you have the space, it's a great investment.\n\nIt's said, tents keep you dry - sleeping bags keep you warm, which is true, but a little gem like this will put a smile on your face when the temperature drops below 40 degrees...", "summary": "Solid, Functional, Reliable Heater.  It Really Works...", "unixReviewTime": 1418083200}

{"overall": 3.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 31, 2014", "reviewerID": "A3ULZN5RNVM3SU", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "P. Hanson", "reviewText": "Been using it for a couple of years now and works good. Puts out decent amount of heat for Colorado nights.\nThere are several issues with this product:\n\nLighting can be a bit unclear when it is actually lit pending on the lighting conditions to be able to see the mesh faintly glow indicating it is lit. But it does light fairly easy and convenient with the built-in switch.\n\nOne of the legs fractured a bit from rotating it - although some user error to blame there, wish it was more durable. it still stands up ok though.\n\nThis product does NOT have tip over protection (where it will shut off upon tipping over). Although it has legs and a tripod stance, it could tip over pretty easily on a tent floor on rough ground or just being knocked from accidental impact.\n\nThere is no low oxygen sensor  or shut off protection from low oxygen.\n\nThe Coleman website specifically states to use in well ventilated area and do not use while sleeping. I'm assuming for several safety reasons including possibility of tipping it over. But I bought this item to use at night while camping since that is when it gets cold mostly.\n\nI would recommend looking at the Mr. Heater one as well for around the same price which looks sturdier and has safety features built-in and is approved for indoor use.\nhttp://www.amazon.com/Mr-Heater-F215100-3800-BTU-Indoor-Safe/dp/B001CFRF7I/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1407387059&sr=8-2&keywords=mr+heater\n\nhttp://www.amazon.com/Mr-Heater-F232000-Indoor-Safe-Portable/dp/B002G51BZU/ref=sr_1_1?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1406819767&sr=1-1&keywords=mr+heater+buddy+portable+heater\n\nAs far as other safety issues: there are concerns of carbon monoxide poisoning with any device like this, but rv-roadtrips websitie explains the safety an risks involved with catalytic heaters. Which from what I have read, catalytic heaters do not burn with an open flame and this reduces the amount of carbon monoxide and other toxic fumes emitted compared to an open flame heater. BUT, it is NOT the existence of carbon monoxide or toxic fumes which is the danger when using a heater like this indoors, it is the potential for the LACK of oxygen since this also consumes oxygen. So still having a well ventilated space to allow for oxygen to flow into your space is still a must.\n\nsafety info here: http://rv-roadtrips.thefuntimesguide.com/2012/02/catalytic-heaters.php", "summary": "Could have better safety features", "unixReviewTime": 1406764800}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "19", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "06 7, 2012", "reviewerID": "A34ZEKVLYY0QZM", "asin": "B0009PUTHU", "reviewerName": "Asher Taylor", "reviewText": "First, I should probably note that the version of this pad that I bought at a brick-and-mortar store is labeled 'Coleman Max,' so it may not be exactly the same thing -- but it looks pretty much the same.  It's the same color as the darker one in the close-up of the valve, and the valve is identical.  I actually paid about ten dollars less than Amazon's posted price at the time of this review.\n\nI'm a bony guy, and really wanted something with a little more loft than my Thermarest SOLite pad (which is a little on the large side when rolled anyway, even though I bought the short version) for bike camping trips.  It had to be reasonably light and packable, and I figured I'd give this a shot, since I could return it if it didn't work.\n\nMy expectations, I admit, were not actually very high.  I've been disappointed by many sleeping pads in the past, and would actually have just purchased one of those small floatation-device style air mattresses if my hubby had not firmly suggested that one of these might offer better insulation and so forth.  I was willing to give it a try, but still worried that my boniness and side-sleeping tendencies could be problematic.\n\nIn practice, this pad significantly exceeded my expectations.  That said, there's a bit of a process involved in getting it to work right:\n\nA) Pre-Inflate.\nAs the manufacturer suggests, before your first camping trip, unroll it, open the valve, and let it sit for as long as possible -- twenty-four hours if you can (I bought mine the day before my trip, so I had to make due with six-ish).  Then deflate it, roll it, close the valve, and pack it.\n\nB) Don't Wait 'Til You're Ready for Bed\nWhen you make camp, set your tent up, unroll your pad, open the valve immediately, and let it do its thing.  Of note, we rolled into camp on our second night only a couple hours before bed.  I set up my tent and pad right away and it was fine.\n\nC) Give It An Assist\nPerhaps most importantly -- give the pad several good puffs by mouth (this, by the way, has been recommended for every single self-inflating pad I've considered -- including much more expensive models).\n\n--\n\nThe style of the valve makes this a bit challenging, but you'll get the hang of it quickly.  You'll want to give it a little more air than you think you need, because it will lose a little as you're screwing the valve shut.\n\nSome users find the tufted design of this pad uncomfortable.  I, on the other hand, feel that the tufted design is exactly what makes it so very comfortable for someone like me.  Where a non-tufted pad might be compressed flat at my bony points, the tufted 'billows' in this pad offer support and relief.  On its first night out, I shoved it into my sleeping bag and slept better than I sleep at home.  That's not hyperbole, by the way -- I really mean it.  I slept better than I normally do at home, even after a comparably-challenging day on the bike.\n\nThere are pads in the world that pack smaller, and there are probably better pads -- and if I were backpacking instead of traveling by bicycle, I might want one of those.  However, for less than fifty bucks, a little finagling makes this pad work just fine.\n\nPros:\n-Tufted design works well for bony people\n-Holds air once inflated\n-Deflates easily and packs reasonably small, for the price\n-Built-in compression straps are great\n-For its price point, offers exceptional comfort\n-Attached pillow can be inflated by mouth or left uninflated.  Your choice.\n\nCons:\n-Some users don't enjoy the tufted design\n-Not entirely 'self-inflating'\n-Inflates a tad slowly\n-Not ideal for backpackers (doesn't pack small enough)", "summary": "Very Good for Some People", "unixReviewTime": 1339027200}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "04 5, 2012", "reviewerID": "A3P21Q51UNG8EY", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "Bob", "reviewText": "Unit seems to work very well.  I had the 1000 BTU version before and that model just didn't put out enough heat other than to warm your hands (Granted we were camping in 9 degree weather).  This 3000 BTU unit puts out a very noticeable amount of heat.  I have yet to try it again in 9 degree weather, but we used it outside one cold night, sitting around a table just to see how well it worked and 4 of us noticed the heat.  I think this unit will work extremely well inside a tent.\n\nWhile supposedly safe in a tent, I am still a little nervous about carbon monoxide.  I tested the unit inside my house with a home CO detector sitting a foot away.  I left it running for 20-30 mins and the alarm never went off.  That reassured me a bit.  I think we may make a habit of taking the detector with us when we plan to use this inside a tent. {"overall": 2.0, "vote": "9", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "01 2, 2012", "reviewerID": "A2ICKE6A3MJMM5", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "E. L. Green", "reviewText": "Upsides: It works.\n\nDownsides: The InstaStart thingy doesn't. No matter how many times I press the button, I see the little spark but apparently not enough propane is in the vicinity of that spark to fire it off. I use a long-snout butane barbecue lighter to light the thing without being barbecued.\n\nIt's not very adjustable. There's low heat. There's high heat. That's it.\n\nThe metal grill on the front gets very hot. You must be very careful where you place this thing so that said grill doesn't contact you, your tent, your dog, your upholstery in the small van you're trying to heat up, or anything else flammable. You'd think they could at least put some sort of flared guard or bumpers around the front to help keep stuff from coming in contact with that metal grill, sort of like the \"bumpers\" on chicken house heaters to keep their metal grill from contacting stuff if the heater is knocked over, but apparently that'd require too much thought.\n\nThere's only one safe way to place this heater -- on its side with the legs extended, as shown in the product photo. You can't stand it up like a candle, it might fall over and then that metal ring around the front (which gets very hot) would contact something that you probably don't want contacted.\n\nThis doesn't put out much heat on high heat but still drains a 1 pound can of propane within four hours. No problem, you say, you'll just hook it up to the 20 pound tank for your barbecue and have plenty of heat for all night camping for a week? Uhm, no. a) there is no way to hook a 20 pound tank to this heater, and b) if you did rig up a hose of some sort, see the part about only one safe way to place this heater -- by removing the rear \"leg\" (the 1 pound canister), the heater is now in an attitude that is unsafe. Coleman says \"don't do it\" and they're right -- this heater simply is designed wrong to be safe when used with an external propane tank.\n\nThere's no safety cut-off to turn off the heater if it gets bumped and falls over from the pictured attitude, which as I noted is the only safe attitude. So don't leave the heater alone with a dog  or large cat that might bump into it and make it fall over, or you might come back to a smoldering tent and barbecued Fido/Fluffy.\n\nAll in all, this heater works, but it's profoundly mediocre. I've used it in my garage to supplement an electric heater that struggles with cooler temperatures, but due to its limitations never used it for camping as originally intended, and probably won't ever do so. In particular, the very hot grill on the front is such a safety hazard that I refuse to use it anywhere but on the concrete floor of my garage, where if it falls over all that'll happen is that it contacts non-flammable concrete.\n\nI'm now researching better options for a tent heater, because this just isn't acceptable to me. You'd have to haul along a metal roasting pan and a piece of fiberglass insulation to make this safe to use in a tent (the pan to hold the heater, the fiberglass insulator to go under the pan to insulate it from the tent floor), and at that point you're into a realm of clunkiness that makes me say, \"eh, time to do something else.\"", "summary": "Profoundly mediocre", "unixReviewTime": 1325462400}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "17", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "01 4, 2011", "reviewerID": "AIIYOR1IQKYSM", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "amazonconsumer", "reviewText": "This is a review from a hunters perspective and rates the performance of the Coleman BlackCat EI Catalytic Heater heater according to the environment it is used in.\n\nWhy I purchased the heater:\n- To use in my Primos Ground Max Eclipse Hunting Blind (http://www.amazon.com/Primos-GB2500-The-Eclipse-Blind/dp/B001P5G6TI), which has the dimensions (L x W x H): 77.0 x 77.0 x 70.0, while deer hunting\n\n- Because I do not have adequate cold weather footwear (I should buy some) and my toes get too cold very easily\n- I hunt in Texas where the wind is always blowing and because so, it can chill you quiet quickly even with our mildly cold winter weather\n- To have a portable heater for tailgating events and to play my guitar on my back porch in the winter w/out freezing.  How stereotypically hick of me :)\n\nHow I used it in context to this review:\n- I used it in my Primos Ground Max Eclipse Hunting Blind (http://www.amazon.com/Primos-GB2500-The-Eclipse-Blind/dp/B001P5G6TI), which has the dimensions (L x W x H): 77.0 x 77.0 x 70.0 while hunting deer.\n\nPros:\n- Heats well for the reasons I bought it.  I keep it right at my feet and it heats up my feet and legs warm which in turn keeps me warm all over.  Does not keep the hunting blind warmed up as I have the hunting windows open preventing any real heat build up in the blind.\n\n- It is very simple to operate.  You turn the knob to high for about 30-45 seconds so propane will feed out and then you press the electric striker to fire up the heater.  I have seen other portable propane heaters that need a match or that force you to prime the device for 1 minute, then you strike and hold the knob in a pilot light ignition position for another minute, then you reset the knob and turn on to the desired heat level.  That is too much trouble.\n\n- The heater is very quiet.  An animal within 5 yards will likely not hear the sound. The closest encounter I have had is a deer 20 yards away and it did not hear or smell the heater.  Even the strike of the ignition switch is not much louder then when I bump my rifle against my chair leg or my shooting stick.\n\n- Works well on high and low settings.  I used it on both settings in 12F temperature, where everything was covered in frost, and with 15 mph wind blowing from the north.  Had no issues keeping my feet and in turn my body warm.  When my fingers got a little cold I just put my hands down between my legs to catch the rising heat and they warmed up nicely.\n\nCons:\n- Has a very slight propane burning odor on high setting.  It was only noticeable when I bent down to warm my hands and the heater was on high.  I did not really notice it when the heater was on low or when I was sitting completely erect in my chair.  If you are hunting you should be upwind of your prey anyway making this slight odor a non-issue.\n\n- Takes 30-45 seconds to start up.  I would stop the heater after I would warm up and then start it up again later when I was getting chilled.  I would become impatient waiting the 30-45 seconds and click the starter a few times making noise and taking my attention away from hunting, etc.  This is basically a \"me\" problem and could be solved by just being more patient.\n\nConcluding Statement:\n\nI have not used the heater in a great deal of situations so I cannot give you any information on the life, durability, and exact efficiency of the heater.  All I know is that it works well for my hunting needs and I would buy another if I needed it.  I also think that it would keep my feet and legs warm even in an open tripod hunting stand or a tree stand.\n\nFor non hunters this would work fine for direct heat in a camping or emergency situation.  It would not effectively heat an uninsulated space larger than the dimensions of my blind.\n\nI hope this information is helpful :)", "summary": "Hunting Related Review of Coleman BlackCat EI Catalytic Heater", "unixReviewTime": 1294099200}

You get about 15 minutes of good light out of it, then it starts to dim, after about 25 minutes it'll start flickering, and after about 45 minutes it'll get so dim that it's unusable if you don't pump it up some more. Put about 30-40 pumps in it and repeat all night long. It says you get 7 hours of run time on high, but the adjustment range is so narrow that you don't get any more run time by turning it down on low. These are nothing like the old 200A and 220 series lanterns that they used to make. Also, the mantles that it comes with aren't very good. IT also is small and light enough that I just carried it on the plane as an extra carryon without any hassle. We took it to the beach every single day. It takes 5 min to set up and 5 in to take down. By the end my 10 year old was doing it herself. I love the sand bag pockets. One day there were maybe 30 -35 mile an hour winds so we filled up all the sands bags...along with the bags provided for the tent poles etc. and the tent stayed up! We would also just put our beach bags etc in the tent to help it stay put on the seriously windy days. Definitely better than an umbrella. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "22", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 25, 2009", "reviewerID": "ASHJAZC9OA9NS", "asin": "B0009PUQW8", "reviewerName": "Stephen C", "reviewText": "I bought this because we were going camping while it was still pretty cold outside.  When you get it you need to burn it to get rid of the initial fumes.  It lights easily and does project a warm area in front of the unit.  If the air is still you can use it outside.  If it is windy forget about it.  It is still not clear if it is recommended for use inside a tent while sleeping.  I found conflicting information.  We have a large 16X8 dome tent with an open mesh top covered by a fly so I felt like it would be OK to run inside.  I'm still alive so it didn't kill me.  It did warm the tent but in reality the heat is going out the top of the tent.  It helped keep us warm during a very cold night. We actually got some sleep; everyone else in our group was groggy the next day because they were so cold. I woke up at 2 am with a frozen face and replaced they empty cylinder then relit it.\n\nThere are heaters that burn outside the tent and warm inside but they are big and expensive.\n\nMy wife and kids liked the comfort.  Is it worth the cost of the unit and a few cylinders of gas to keep you warm at night?  For us the answer is yes in the right situation.  When it's cold and you have kids or a frozen wife it's worth its weight in gold.\n\nThe quality is decent, not great so I give it 4 stars.", "summary": "Difficult product to review", "unixReviewTime": 1256428800}

{"overall": 3.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "05 2, 2015", "reviewerID": "A2LR03AY7BLCWS", "asin": "B0009PURIQ", "style": {"Size:": " 1-(Pack)"}, "reviewerName": "Schutzenschnurr", "reviewText": "** Please Note:  This is a re-post and re-edit of a review of the dual fuel lantern WITHOUT the hard case, written 10 JUN 14, and includes new information.\n\n*** Amazon no longer lists the lantern this review was originally for, even though it's the same exact lantern as the one offered here.\n\n**** Also please note that the lantern and case offered here costs less than the lantern alone from WalMart, so this is likely the best way to go.\n\nAre the lanterns sold through WalMart of a different quality from those sold through other retail outlets, or is Coleman's overall quality declining?\n\nHard to say which, but it took SIX of these from WalMart to get three that worked after a fashion, and even then had to replace the pressure valve in one (tank wouldn't pressurize after only six or eight uses) and the pump cup in another (very stiff, draggy pump action, even after proper lubrication) - I just got to the point where I didn't want to hassle with bringing numbers 4 and 5 back.\n\nI occasionally have to use three of these in the nesting barn, hung from the ceiling in a row spaced about sixteen feet apart and the difference in the amount of light each individual lantern put outs is quite apparent.  Using unleaded gasoline, two are reasonably bright-ish in an orangey sort of way (but still don't put out as much light as I remember the green Coleman Fuel Only lanterns producing, and the light is NOT bright white), but the third is only about two-thirds as bright as the others no matter how I tweak it or what variables I change.\n\nI've tried all the big-name unleaded gasoline brands as well as the cheapies - 10% ethanol blend (which is about all they sell in and around Mount Goatmore Texas) and pure gasoline when I can find it - and it doesn't seem to make much difference.\n\nThe dual fuel lanterns work just fine with Coleman fuel, (but then what's the point of paying the premium for the alleged dual fuel capability?) and work almost as well with a 50-50 mix of Coleman Fuel and 10% ethanol unleaded gasoline, which is the route I'm going. Their light output with the 50-50 mix is still not quite bright white, but it IS brighter and less orangey than using unleaded gasoline alone.\n\nI'll likely have to dig down to the bottom of my camping box and see if I still have any of the lantern mantles from the 80s that were made with thorium and were BRIGHT - BRIGHT - BRIGHT and see if that helps any.\n\nThings to consider:\n\n1. If you're going to store it fueled up for emergency use, store it 3/4 filled with Coleman fuel and NOT unleaded gasoline.\n\n2. Buy the hard plastic storage case if it is not included as part of a package - worth every penny.  Make sure the bottom tabs are properly secured when you close the case.  I've never had a problem with the case bottom coming unfastened and dropping the lantern (I have these three lanterns, two green Coleman Fuel lanterns, and one 1975 red single mantle lantern - all in Coleman plastic cases), but other reviewers have experienced this.\n\n3. A long-nose disposable butane utility lighter will make lighting a snap, and will store inside the hard plastic storage case.\n\n4. Two or three packs of spare mantles will store under the lantern in the hard plastic\nstorage case.", "summary": "Better To Light A  Coleman Lantern Than To Curse The Darkness (If You Can Get The Lantern To Light!)", "unixReviewTime": 1430524800}

{"reviewerID": "ABLOQZIL42W7I", "asin": "B0009PUPXS", "reviewerName": "kone", "verified": true, "reviewText": "I purchased this for a trip to Glacier National Park and for other camping adventures. There is enough stove-top space for a frying pan and a smaller kettle for sides.  I have owned two of these units, and am happy with both.  My current stove has a slight problem, in that the fuel container does not fit snugly in the cut-outs.  I will need to do some bending of the inserts to get it to stay in place (thus the 4-star rating). There are two side wind shields that help contain the heat from the burners under the grill area.\n\nAfter each use, purge the fuel container of excess pressure to make the gaskets last longer.  Periodically oil the plunger for years of trouble-free use.\n\nMy last unit lasted over 25 years. {"reviewerID": "A18ECVX2RJ7HUE", "asin": "B0009PUPXS", "reviewerName": "Willie", "verified": false, "reviewText": "This 425 2-burner Coleman stove has remained (relatively) unchanged in more than 50 years. This stove is simple, mechanically bombproof, and offers features unmatched by today's assortment of higher-priced, more 'convenient' stoves. For example, the 425 may be found nearly everywhere and shares rarely needed replacement parts across the product line. Tanks, valves, and generators are nearly interchangeable. The stove is easy to clean, spacious, and offers two burners: the main with a higher output, and a secondary, controlled by a simple turn key on the left-hand side of the stove case for simmering. This means that Iron Chef-wannabes can easily cook multiple entrees or multi-course meals on the camp table. The case offers a built-in windscreen. The tank is suspended by two tabs, although you can pin the tank if desired. The pump uses the ubiquitous Coleman pump assembly (although more recently this assembly uses a plastic washer). This stove will last a lifetime and you will not be disappointed. It is one of the most classic stove designs in history.", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "04 14, 2009", "summary": "unchanged in more than 50 years", "unixReviewTime": 1239667200}

Solid quality.", "summary": "Great product for the price!", "unixReviewTime": 1410134400}
{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "38", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "09 8, 2014", "reviewerID": "A303SNZ4AR7TDQ", "asin": "B0009PURIQ", "style": {"Size:": " 1-(Pack)"}, "reviewerName": "SirStinky", "reviewText": "We had a couple of these years ago. We are pretty serious about camping and I know a thing or two about Coleman liquid fueled lanterns, so I wanted to share my experience with the \"Dual Fuel\" model. It's a liquid-fueled, two sock mantle lantern. It burns either gasoline (regular unleaded) or Coleman's camp fuel (a classified mixture, probably mostly naphtha and some additives for storage life). You have adjustable light outputs and runs on air pressure. It's incredibly simple and there are few moving parts, so it's incredibly reliable. You can also repair it if something breaks or wears out.\n\nIt's made almost entirely of steel (with the exception of brass generator and pump parts, and the brass fuel cap, plastic fuel control knob) that's been coated in enamel (the chimney and top cap) for long life and heat resistance. The fuel tank is painted, heavy gauge steel, and the rest of the lantern (globe holder/base, heat shield, valve shroud) is stamped galvanized sheet steel. It will last a long time if you take care of it.\n\nIt's simple how it works. The pressurized fuel is squirted up the brass generator to a burner at the top. The fuel is sprayed out of the generator and disperses in the burner. The operation depends on high temperatures to work right so it has to warm up (hence the mantles being close to the generator). The heat vaporizes the fuel into a gas and it passes down the burner stalks and is ignited, which burns very hot and makes the mantles glow.\n\nIf lighting for the first time, you need to burn-in the mantles. Make sure they're tied tightly to the burner stalks. Doesn't matter how they are positioned. Fill the fuel tank (don't overfill it or you'll get leaks and it could catch fire when you light it), cap it. Unscrew the pump 2 turns and pump it up 30-50 times. Make sure your thumb covers the vent hole on the pump knob. Don't over pump it. When it gets stiff, stop. If you're burning in the mantles, light them on fire. I use a barbecue lighter to reach through the hole on the globe support and light each mantle. Let them burn until they are mostly white ash and while they are burning, open the fuel valve until you get fire. Don't turn it up high, keep it on low until the mantles are completely burned and are white. You'll get fire coming out of the burners and that's normal until the generator gets hot and vaporizes the fuel. It takes about a minute for it to reach operating temperature and the mantles start glowing on their own and the fire stops. You might have to pump it some more while it's lighting for more pressure.\n\nThat's it! It can be kind of intimidating at first with the fire coming out, but that's normal and will go away. Don't worry it won't explode. Just don't turn the fuel valve on high while it's doing that or you could get big fire. Once you've done it a couple times, you get used to it.\n\nIt's really bright on full blast! Will light up a campsite no problem. Brighter than an LED lantern, and the fuel tank will last you about 8-10 hours on full power. I have run it two evenings and nights before and only used 3/4 of the fuel so it lasts quite a while. It can burn either regular unleaded gasoline or Coleman's own fuel. I prefer gasoline because it's cheaper (about $3.50 a gallon opposed to almost $9 for the other stuff). I noticed it doesn't run as long or get as bright on gasoline, but the difference is made up for in the cost savings.\n\nIt's very durable. The only real issue I had was from taking them razor clamming and getting ocean water on them, which rusted the exposed metal and made a real mess of the lantern. It still worked fine though after some cleaning. If you properly maintain it, it will last for decades. The only consumable parts are the mantles and possibly the rubber seal in the air pump piston, which can dry rot over time if not kept oiled (use a medium oil, you want something viscous like just regular general purpose oil. I use Hoppes oil). Everything else lasts a long time, the life of the lantern. If something does go bad, you can order a new part from Coleman. I rebuilt another one of these (not dual fuel) with off-shelf parts and some parts I had to order from Coleman it works great. It's also cheap to fix. On the downside, not really a fault of the lantern, is that you can't take it in a tent with you like an LED lamp. It makes carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide on gasoline, plus it gets real hot. It makes a great hand warmer though. It's also fragile due to the glass globe and mantles so you have to be a little careful transporting it.\n\nThe plastic cover is nice, but make sure the locking tabs are pressed into the base to keep it from falling out. Plus it can hold mantles in the space under the fuel tank.\n\nPros:\n\nVery bright\nLasts forever\nUses cheap unleaded gas\nEasy to maintain\nLong run time\n\nCons:\n\nCan be intimidating the first time you use it\nNot cheap\n\nIf I had a choice between an LED lamp and this, I'd probably choose both. LED for in my tent and the gas for outside. It's not cheap and is designed for outdoor use only, but you can't fault it. It is super bright, will last for thousands of hours and is cheap to run. Gets my high recommendation.", "summary": "The Classic. Super Bright and Reliable with Economical Dual Fuel Operation", "unixReviewTime": 1410134400}

I went through a few mantels at first but now the mantle seems to be lasting forever.  And I've been using gasoline only.ive burned almost 2 gal by now.  that's a lot of burn time. {"overall": 3.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "07 23, 2011", "reviewerID": "A3NDCJ6BA9K8SJ", "asin": "B0009PUQ8M", "style": {"Style:": " Tent Kit"}, "reviewerName": "Jeff", "reviewText": "Not bad, but could be better (and for anything but casual camping, you'll want better).\n\nThe best, and most used, feature is the broom/dustpan.  I'd love a bigger broom though.  If this is all you have, you'll do a lot of uncomfortable stooping and sweeping even a small tent will take forever- it is very small.  A short broom that you can use on your knees, or bent over while standing, and using this as a dust brush will be better.  I love the dustpan- it has a little indent so that sand and other small particles are less likely to fall out the front of the pan.  The broom and dustpan get 4 stars (5 for the pan, 3 for the broom).\n\nThe mallet is OK.  Nice, heavy rubber mallet.  However, it isn't all that heavy duty, and after several uses, it is clear I will need to replace it at the end of this camping season.  The mallet is 3-3 1/2 stars.\n\nThe stakes, before I used them I thought they were great.  The whole setup is quite inexpensive, and these are some nice (looking) heavy duty stakes.  The flimsy stakes that come with most tents are only acceptable in perfect weather, and having this kit in my trunk with these stakes gave me peace of mind.  Then, last weekend, it was very windy when I put up my tent and I didn't think the stock stakes would hold, so I used these.  They did their job well, they held the tent and stayed sturdy despite some pretty nasty winds...then I tried to break camp on Sunday.  Well, these are 10\" nail style stakes.  They hold well.  You need some real leverage to get them out.  The nail head offers nothing.  The plastic at the top broke.  At that point, any hope of ever getting these out of the ground were gone.  I had to work my tent loops up and over the stakes and leave the stakes in the ground as there was no way I was ever getting them out.  I'd suggest holding on to these for nothing but emergency use, and buy a set of sturdy aluminum stakes with a metal \"loop\" at the top like the Kelty \"No Bendium\" stakes or with the nylon pull strings like the Coleman Heavy Duty stakes or MSR Ground Hogs.  The stakes are only 2 stars (2 and not 1 since they do work well as heavy duty stakes in a pinch, but, especially in hard ground or heavy roots, you'll never be able to recover them).\n\nThe stake puller is OK.  It seems like it is a bit flimsy.  When using the cheaper pegs that come with my tents it does a fine job pulling them up.  When using longer pegs (like the aforementioned stakes that come with this set), it did do some bending.  It is still useable, but I think I will be looking for something heavier duty. 3 stars.\n\nSo, overall, it is an OK set.  It probably serves best to keep it in your trunk at all times in case you need it and forgot something when packing for camping.  Price is good, so if you are camping and forgot something, and need something now, and this is all the stores have, you'll be fine with it to fill in for your regular gear.  All the items seem a little flimsy for long-term use.  Good in a pinch, not so good for  your go-to gear.", "summary": "Buy items separately, spend a little more, and do better, but OK for quick, budget buy", "unixReviewTime": 1311379200}

This package from Coleman, consisting of (1) a small broom and dustpan, (2) four aluminum stakes, (3) a rubber-headed mallet and (4) a stake remover, definitely falls in the second category.\n\n(1) Broom and dustpan -- small, plastic and green, this just might get the most use out of anything in the package.  Not much to say here -- it does its job.  Save the plastic wrapper this comes in, because its hard to get the broom back into the mesh bag without it.\n\n(2) Four aluminum stakes -- these are actually pretty good. A bit heavy, if anything.\n\n(4) Stake remover -- Cheap, bends out of shape.\n\nAll of this comes packed in a little mesh bag. {"overall": 4.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 21, 2013", "reviewerID": "AO09APZ33SV5E", "asin": "B0009PUR86", "reviewerName": "Sandra", "reviewText": "I bought these from either Walmart or Kmart, separately.\n\nDishes: They are actually pretty decent, but I have not been careful with them and now they are chipping. I suggest getting a bag for them - or one of those fabric coolers on wheels, which is what I opted for. The best way to care for them (besides not throwing them around or dropping them) is to make sure they are packed tightly and separate each piece with paper towel. The edges are a bit sharp, but nothing I've cut myself on. Like any dishware, they scratch and chip if you are not careful. This dishware is strong and sturdy, but once scratched/chipped, beware of rust. Also, hot foods will heat the dishes and can burn you. Common sense, but worth mentioning.\n\nSilverware: These are ok, and worth having if you're sick of wasting money and plastic on throw-away utensils. Here's what I think is important: when cleaning, be aware of any food stuck on the inside of the fork tines and the knife serrations. Also clean the area where the metal meets the handle. I don't have a problem, but I can see how food could build up there if you are not careful. Again, common sense. The knives are actually very useful - I can cut steak with them. That also means they can scratch the dishes. I threw the carrying case into the washer and dryer, and it might have tried to shrink a little, but everything still fits inside perfectly.\n\nAll said and done, I still think these are worth buying - if you take care of them.", "summary": "Dishes - pretty good, but take CARE of them. {"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 27, 2016", "reviewerID": "A2F1V6JKYFP67M", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "mofo83", "reviewText": "This is a nice beach shade once it is up, but just be aware that setup is slightly confusing and involved.\n\nThere are three separate tent poles, and the sleeves you need to slide them into aren't very well designed - they're a mesh material, which sort of binds on the poles, whereas a solid nylon fabric would have allowed the poles to slide more easily.\n\nI would also skip using the stakes - they're terribly cheap and bendable, and any sort of rock or resistance will stop them in their tracks. Just weigh it down with the included sandbags (by placing them inside the tent) or just use your beach gear to weigh it down.\n\nOnce it is up and stably in place, it's a nice beach shade - very roomy, width-wise and height-wise, with a huge front door that doubles as an extended floor. Blocked the sun well, too. The well-designed back door is important for air flow. It seems well-constructed, overall.\n\nYou may never get it back into its original bag ever again, by the way. This is a common problem with tents, but this one is really bad - especially considering you'll be trying to fold it up on a (sometimes windy) beach. I'd just get a separate tote bag and shove it inside that instead.\n\nOverall, recommended. Just realize this is NOT a simple \"pop-up\" shade, and will take some time to construct.", "summary": "Nice beach shade, but NOT a simple pop-up by any means...", "unixReviewTime": 1469577600}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "3", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 12, 2016", "reviewerID": "ABOKL9VZUKETS", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Danny", "reviewText": "We purchased this Coleman Beach Shade tent last year and have used it about three times now.  So far, it has held up to our use pretty well.  It can be a little tricky to put up and will probably be aggravating for you the first time you set it up.  I suggest practicing before you go to the beach.  After becoming familiar with it, I can put it up by myself in about 10 minutes.  It helps to have an extra hand at the beach especially because it is more windy there.  When we purchased ours and set it up the first time, we noticed two small holes in the side of it.  I used some seam tape on the holes to help it from tearing or opening up more and that did the trick for us.  It's pretty roomy and a bit bigger than most of the instant shelters that I have seen.  The front can be zipped up and there is a back window that can also be covered.  I wanted this one mostly because of those features as it would allow for us to change clothes inside and not have to use the dirty public rest rooms that are at the beach.  It can get hot inside especially when the back window is closed but with the front and back open, it provides good wind flow through the tent.  There are netted pockets in the corners of the tent and it comes with small sandbags to assist in holding it down.  Directions for putting the tent up can be found sewn to the inside of the tent bag and they are pretty easy to follow.  The tent also has guy lines and stakes included.\n\nOverall, we are pretty pleased with it but it does take a little longer to put up than some of the \"instant\" shade shelters.  It's roomy, provides good UV protection, and we like that we can use it to change clothes inside.", "summary": "Takes a bit longer to put up but we like the option of changing clothes inside rather than dirty public restrooms.", "unixReviewTime": 1468281600}

{"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 29, 2011", "reviewerID": "ABOKL9VZUKETS", "asin": "B0009PUR86", "reviewerName": "Danny", "reviewText": "I've been camping ever since I was a kid and I remember my family always using Coleman products for these events.  I had a \"camping\" themed Christmas this year because I wanted to stock up on supplies to take my own family to the great outdoors.  One of the items I asked for was this set of enamel plates from Coleman.  Upon inspecting them, I noticed a lot of enamel paint chips in the bottom of the box.  Two of the cups have large sections in which the enamel coating is missing.  This doesn't look like a packaging or shipping defect...it looks like poor quality on how they were coated.  Some of the bowels and plates have runs in the coating as well...but at least it is covered.  What surprises me is that all the contents in this box was hand packed.  It is made in China and it looks like they would at least throw the bad cups out when they were packing them in the box.  The section in which there is no enamel is pretty darn noticeable.  Everything else seems fine.  My box might be a fluke but it was pretty disappointing to see that the quality was not what I expected.  The runs in the paint coating and the uneven layers make me think that this are not going to last very long. {"overall": 4.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 25, 2016", "reviewerID": "A3BFAE0URXWIUZ", "asin": "B0009PUTHA", "style": {"Color:": " One Color"}, "reviewerName": "Amazon Customer", "reviewText": "A little than expected but good!!", "summary": "Four Stars", "unixReviewTime": 1466812800}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "08 3, 2017", "reviewerID": "AAXAB62G5OZB3", "asin": "B0009PUT20", "reviewerName": "Edward Kirton", "reviewText": "I don't recommend hanging this bag or using the shower head.  It's difficult to hang high enough and the nozzle wastes water as you slide it in/out to turn the flow on/off (a push-button would have been better).  Some brands of these bags have built-in chemical thermometers which change colors to indicate temperature, but the way I use this bag it isn't necessary.\n\nAs an easy and cheap way to heat up water, this is great.  Fill and leave in a sunny spot.  The water can actually get too hot, so check it before letting the kids bathe.  Add cold water until acceptable -- cooler than you'd want at home, in order to allow more people to shower per bag.  It saves a lot of time (and fuel) over heating that much (cold) water on a stove.\n\nWe dispense a third to a half of the heated water into a collapsable bucket and add cold/hot water (e.g. from stove) to bring it to a comfortable temperature.  Use a cup to scoop the water for bathing.  This method not only conserves water, allows accurate temperature control, but allows you to ration the water.  It would be difficult to pour boiling water in the bag directly if it wasn't warm enough (e.g. you don't get back to camp until sunset and the water has already cooled somewhat).  I've found that using the nozzle, one person may consume 3/4 the bag (one big friend used the entire 5 gal).  By splitting and using a cup, 2-3 adults can thoroughly bathe with 5gal.  When rationing smaller amounts, we tell folks to bring their water bottle (cold water) with them in case they run out.\n\nOur family of five is served with a single 5gal bag by adding cold/hot water.  We keep the kettle on while folks are bathing and can all shower one after the other with no waiting for the water to heat on the stove.  We use a full-size house kettle, not a dinky camping kettle.\n\nI also own a Zodi shower (propane water heater) but don't even use it anymore as this simple low-tech method is sufficient, faster, and packs better.\n\nFor the shower tent, the pop-up style one didn't last; we now use one with proper steel poles and it's much better, albeit large to pack.  But whenever there's a strong wind, the pop-up wouldn't hold up.  Also the popup seemed colder because the wind seemed to pass through the flimsy nylon too easily.  I don't remember what brand we used to have for the popup, but here's the shower stall we use now (recommended):&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Texsport-Instant-Portable-Outdoor-Camping-Shower-Privacy-Shelter-Changing-Room/dp/B000ITVSSQ/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Texsport Instant Portable Outdoor Camping Shower Privacy Shelter Changing Room</a>", "summary": "Works perfectly well the way I use it (read description)", "unixReviewTime": 1501718400}

Ive used this pad every time Ive gone hiking or camping or even backpacking. it has NEVER failed me. it makes the night alot easier if inflated enough. you cannot just let it inflate by itself. i let mine inflate and then i add a few extra puffs of air until its filled right. you cant fill it too much or else it kinda becomes a ballon. all in all im happy with it and if you need something just to go camping (not backpacking) then definitely buy this. its quality.\n\nupdate: i got a new sleeping pad today, a lightweight sleeping pad that still has more padding than this sleeping pad. the air in the Coleman moves around too much so any weight you put on it in that spot the air just moves out of the way. still would not recommend.", "summary": "I understand what everyone is complainig about", "unixReviewTime": 1353542400}
{"overall": 1.0, "vote": "2", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "01 5, 2012", "reviewerID": "AMVC9WTXYKNJ1", "asin": "B0009PUTHA", "style": {"Color:": " One Color"}, "reviewerName": "J. Edgar Mihelic, MBA", "reviewText": "After blowing through what seemed more than our fair share of air mattresses, I decided to take a different tack.  I remembered my father's army-issue pad that inflated and was comfortable on hard surfaces.  I was much lighter at the time, so that may have played some role.\n\nI was happy when I found these, and I bought two since they seemed so similar to what I had in mind.\n\nThe product's description is right.  It does self inflate.  The problem  is what you do after they self inflate.  You can leave the valve open, but then you have no padding.  Or you close out the valve, and you trap the air in.  The problem is that the air rushes around to where there is no pressure on the pad, and you again have no padding, but this time you have ballooning where the air rushed to.  Basically your padding becomes a foot support.\n\nThese were returned the next day.  I do no recommend this product.  If I were to make a recommendation to the manufacturer, I would tell them to find a way to isolate the air so that it actually creates padding where it is needed.  One way would be to create chambers so that air movement would be restricted.  As is, the product is useless for my purposes, and I am having trouble imagining a situation where it would not be.\n\nI went and bought another air mattress the next day.", "summary": "The product is useless", "unixReviewTime": 1325721600}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "108", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 9, 2008", "reviewerID": "A28BX3MM90A6FI", "asin": "B0009PUQ50", "reviewerName": "hotdog12", "reviewText": "Well, O.K., I don't sneer at hurricanes. But after Hurricane Ike and a week without power, we decided to upgrade our emergency lighting to more than flashlights, candles and chemical light sticks.\n\nI bought three of these family-sized Coleman lanterns and three MicroPacker lanterns (also reviewed). The first time I turned on this family-sized lantern I said \"WOW!\" This is a serious light! I measured the light output of this lantern (I'm a photojournalist) and discovered it puts out half the light of a bare 40 watt bulb, but much, much more light than a 25 watt bulb. That is plenty of light for reading and walking around like a human being instead of stumbling around with flashlights.\n\nThe \"low\" setting is almost as bright as the \"high\" setting (only one-half stop dimmer), but extends the battery life from 17 hours to a fantastic 28 hours! I figure one set (8) of fresh \"D\" cells should last though a week of dark nights.\n\nThe family-sized lantern is tough and well-made. It's not waterproof, but I wouldn't worry about taking it out into the rain. It doesn't have rubber seals, but  the nice, tight fittings should keep it dry.\n\nOne minor point: the large clear housing is a Coleman tradition, but a simple clear cylinder would be more streamlined and compact. The lantern is about the size of a full-sized gas mantle unit. I wouldn't backpack with it, but it is a great unit for emergencies and base camps. Now if Coleman only made a battery-powered air conditioner . . .", "summary": "I SNEER AT HURRICANES!", "unixReviewTime": 1223510400}

{"reviewerID": "ABBA5RERGQHVC", "asin": "B0009PURKE", "reviewerName": "Zantos", "verified": true, "reviewText": "For what you pay and what you get with this cooler, it is of EXCELLENT value.
