Those Yeti's may be amazing but those prices are just absurd and cannot be justified by anyone who isn't literally a mountain man or a hunter who needs ice not to freeze for 10 days. Most of us normal guys who go weekend camping, don't fall into either of those categories, and so we turn our Yeti search into a \"what cooler is also awesome but doesn't cost me my first born child\" search.\n\nI've only ever owned Coleman and Igloo coolers and so that search began with those two. When I was underwhelmed with what Igloo had out there, I made the switch to Coleman and was immediately impressed by this cooler.\n\nMy search criteria where as follows;\nMetal hinges (had an old Igloo with plastic hinges finally blow out on me, granted it was a 30yr old cooler so props to Igloo)\nMetal handles\nSolid handle and/or locking mechanism\nHard lined and o-ring sealed\n\nThe Coleman Steel-Belted Cooler fit all of these criteria and was available for the modest price of $80. I deemed the 54 quart to be of substantial size based on the \"can capacity\" that is listed in the description. I love that Coleman knows their customers and knows we will want to know how many beer...I mean soda cans, that the cooler can fit.\n\nTrust me folks, I've beaten this thing up to heck and back on my camp trips and it has performed admirably. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "43", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "11 11, 2009", "reviewerID": "A3MGC1454RG5QK", "asin": "B0009PUSSK", "reviewerName": "dave h", "reviewText": "Like others have said, the current Crescent 15 Degree F bag being sold is a medium-dark blue and charcoal color, not lime green and charcoal as pictured.  The blue panels are diamond-rip stop polyester taffeta, and the charcoal parts do not appear to be rip-stop.  It's filled with 2 lbs 14 oz of \"Coletherm\" hollow core poly fill insulation. The net pack weight (the bag in the stuff sack) is just over 4 lbs.  I bought two, and one weighed 4 lb 0.5 oz and the other 4 lb 1.8 oz on a postal scale.  The stuff sack weights 2.5 oz, so the sleeping bag alone weighs just under 4 lbs, which is a good rule-of-thumb maximum limit for a sleeping bag to take backpacking.\n\nIt easily can keep you comfortable down to the 15 degree F rating. This bag is very compressible for it's loft.  The size in the included stuff sack is 10\" diameter and 14\" long, which most people will find to be an odd size for backpacking. However, it will fit (stuffed) into 1100-1200 cubic inch backpack compartments.  It easily fits in an 9\" x 24\" compression sack (not included) and squeezes down to approx. 9\" x 17\" pack size if you want to attach it outside your pack.\n\nFor the price/weight, this bag is a great buy for both general camping and light-to-medium backpacking for 3-season use by Boy Scouts.  Although it is true you can get goose-down bags for the same temperature range that are about 1 lb lighter and more compressible for hard-core backpacking, I'm generally opposed to down bags for Boy Scouts for several reasons:  a. down is outrageously expensive, especially given the likelihood of some rough treatment and short lifespan, b. a down bag is useless if it gets wet, and c. they require special cleaning or special soap for home washing.\n\nMy only complaints are that the shell isn't 100% rip-stop material, and the included stuff sack is an odd size, but at a price around 40 bucks, both can be forgiven.", "summary": "Good all-purpose scout bag for price", "unixReviewTime": 1257897600}
{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "20", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 31, 2009", "reviewerID": "ASQ2R1K6IMBEE", "asin": "B0009PUSSK", "reviewerName": "Michael Green", "reviewText": "Backpacking on the cheap, that's how I roll. No, really I am basically a beginner on a tight budget so I'm on the prowl for deals. I scoured Amazon and I settled for this Coleman Crescent bag, because well, Coleman is a name I've trusted for years, I'd never heard of the  other brands, and I really didn't know exactly what I was looking for. Not long after I ordered the bag I realized it was supposedly for \"tall\" people, which I certainly am not. Then after talking to my Uncle who has been backpacking for 20+ years, I started to worry about the 5.2 pound listed weight of the bag. All my fears were for naught though because when the bag arrived I immediately saw that it wasn't the same bag. Yes, it was a Coleman Crescent, but it was blue with a completely different design on the front, it was normal sized, and it weighed less then 2.5 pounds. It easily fit into the stuff sack and fit perfectly into my 35.00$ Cuscus Backpack. I will warn you however that this bag looks like it will only fit into bigger packs, as in 85 litres and higher...Needless to say I spent the entire month of August humping this bag into the mountains up here in the great white north of Washington State.. It probably only dipped into the low 40's or high 30's at the lowest, but I was so hot some nights I had to strip off thermals in the middle of the night. As a matter of fact, every single time ive used this bag I had to partially unzip it because I woke up in the night too hot.\n\nSo to recap... (1)The bag isn't too expensive. (2)The bag they send you is better then the bag described. (3) It is fairly lightweight, and should fit into or under your large pack, or easily strap onto an external frame (I've done both with it). (4)It keeps you warm at night.\n\nWinter is around the corner so I should test the 15 degree rating as I backpack deep into fall, but I'm guessing it will do alright. The only knock I have is that there isn't any room to move your legs. I know it's a mummy bag and all, but dang, the legs are a little too snug. Up next, get rid of my 40.00$ 4-man dome tent that I'm packing in everywhere.", "summary": "Not the bag I ordered, but as luck would have it...", "unixReviewTime": 1251676800}

You will need an unobstructed 20' X 15'-wide space. Assembly first requires linking the one collapsible 14' main pole (grey) and two collapsible 9' crossover poles (black) before sliding these poles into their reinforced sleeves.\n\nThis is also not billed as a 1-person job. Once the tent poles are inserted, one person must support the tent while the other person fits the end poles into the web strap grommets. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "4", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "08 26, 2007", "reviewerID": "A3CP8DVTUDKIKT", "asin": "B0009PUQDM", "reviewerName": "J. chapman", "reviewText": "This is a very cool little boat.  It's fun to use, comes with the paddle and is very maneuverable.\n\nThe only drawback is that some water will splash over the sides, so you'll most likely be sitting in a little puddle.  The place to stash gear is kind of small, but if you keep everything in a drybag, you don't have to worry about it getting wet and the cargo net should keep it secure.\n\nPeople have mentioned that the paddle can break easily.  In my opinion, that's probably a result of not pushing the metal ends all the way into the black plastic handle parts.  If you push them in all the way and tighten them down, there will be plenty of \"purchase\".  I can't imagine the paddle breaking under normal use if it's put together all the way.  A longer paddle would be nice though because it will drip on you.  By the way, if you don't inflate the backrest all the way, you can make it a little more comfortable for just lounging.\n\nThe only improvements I'd like to see are another cargo area behind the seat, larger tracking fins, more attachment areas so you can tie off to other inflatable boats and a longer paddle, but as-is, it's still a great little inflatable boat and lots of fun to use.\n\nI've owned this boat for probably 6 or seven years now. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "11 2, 2014", "reviewerID": "A317ENKKDB0Q9G", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "L Hunter", "reviewText": "I have used this two years now for my camping beach trips and it's been a great little cabana.  It's not my favorite but it's getting 5 stars because is holds up well to extreme winds and a few storms that we left it set up on the beach for while we ran for shelter in the car. It's small and portable and can be put up by one person (with a bit of difficulty ---and not in high winds) It is not at all hard with two, even in the high wind if you take the time to fill the included sand bags with sand, insert them in the in interior pockets to help weight it down so you don't have a kite on your hands.  My only regret is that it only accomodates ground sitting or low beach chairs which are hard for me to get out of.  I prefer my umbrella but when the wind is high I use this for shade AND it's a wonderful wind block when you close up the back window. This way I can make sandwiches and we aren't eating sand in every bite.  All in all I am most pleased with this purchase.  There are ones out there that \"pop\" up and are taller, but not as stable as this one is in the ever present wind that seems to come everytime I am on the beach.\nAs I mentioned, I left it during a storm once, we threw the cooler and chairs inside and closed up both flaps (the front you see pictured actually can zip up as well or it's a sitting spot) and although it's not meant to be waterproof it kept the stuff reasonably dry and the stuff helped keep it from blowing away :)  I would also suggest stronger stakes if you are in high winds, the small ones don't really do much but with the sand and my gear it's managed to hold ok without them.  I use this along with my umbrella and I can spend all day on the beach and not burn. {"reviewerID": "A1GRBKL1FZCKYU", "asin": "B0009PURKE", "reviewerName": "Ductape", "verified": false, "reviewText": "That is what this cooler is like......... because when you walk into a room (or campsite), and this cooler is there, you just have to look at it. It's sooooo darned sexy !!\n\nOK, so we have had ours about seven years or so. We bought it when we were still tent camping, and now we use it with our pop-up camper. We could not be much happier with any cooler. You need to make one improvement as soon as you buy this, but it's so inexpensive, I still have to give this 5 stars. I'd give it 6 if I could. Go to your nearest big box home improvement store and buy a small roll of white adhesive backed 1/4\" X 1/4\" foam gasket by Frost King or similar manufacturer. Clean the groove in the lid with a solvent like Mineral spirits or similar. Peel the backing off the gasket and stick the gasket into the groove in the lid, working your way around to  the back where you started. Cut the gasket so its essentially one continuous seal, leaving as small of a gap between start and finish as possible. Now when you close the lid you will have a virtually air tight seal.\n\nWe go camping a week, or sometimes eight days at a time. Before we leave I go to the grocery store and buy 2 five lb. pieces of block ice to put in the bottom. If you have the freezer space, you could make some block ice at home and save the 4 or 5 bucks. After placing the block ice one either side of the bottom of the cooler, I add our weeks worth of food.... bacon, dogs, burgers, bacon, milk, butter, bacon, steak, bacon, you name it ! Then on top of the food I add regular ice, which I make at home, though sometimes we buy it bagged at the store. This cooler keeps ice 8 days or more this way....... no kidding ! I'm so completely impressed. I have left the cooler closed after returning home and had some of the block ice still in it over 9 days.\n\nYes, I also grew up camping with a 1960s original steel belted Coleman cooler and, yes, I'll admit the quality of the vintage coolers was better. Thicker steel, better latch, screw on O-ringed drain cap, and built in bottle opener. Believe me, I will get that ole Coleman from my big brother one day !! It will be mine...... oh yes, it will be mine !!! But the reality is, the 'new' steel  belted coolers are what we can go out and buy today, and this one is great. Get it in stainless steel and it will be guaranteed never to shrink, stink, wrinkle or rust !", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "11 19, 2014", "summary": "CLEAVAGE !!!", "unixReviewTime": 1416355200}

{"overall": 3.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 3, 2014", "reviewerID": "A1B6YAUB3VLAD5", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "John Strange", "reviewText": "Recently had a week on Cape Cod with this shade tent; four days on the beach; all of them sunny and warm, one day very windy.\n\nBuild quality is solid and I expect to have many seasons use out of this tent. It is roomy for two adults. The large rear window has an insect screen and can be opened for air circulation. When fully closed, there is enough room for one adult to get changed.\n\nThe windy day exposed a couple of flaws. First, if it's windy you'll need better pegs. The six pegs provided would be adequate for firm soil, but not sand. Second, I'm not sure why but the two guy ropes would not stay tightened (even when there was no wind). The nylon friction devices slipped far too easily on the cord. I've never had this problem before on any other tent and may need to buy replacements.\n\nThis shade tent was difficult to put up single-handed. I am an experienced camper, and over the years have owned a number of tents with the shock-corded pole design. All of the others (including my current three-person made by Coleman) I could/can erect unassisted in a few minutes. I think the biggest issue with this tent is that the sleeves for the poles are mesh, rather than solid material. This makes sliding the poles in and out a real hassle; the pole joints continuously snag on the mesh, so you need an extra pair of hands to help guide them through.\n\nOverall I'm happy with my purchase because once the tent is up it does its job very well, and I have no doubts about its quality and longevity.", "summary": "Nice design, but not totally user-friendly", "unixReviewTime": 1409702400}

I have an 80L pack and it fits inside, but leaves little room for much else besides sleeping bag and clothes. Seriously, if you get lost this thing will make a good signal.  Hopefully the bears are colorblind. I caught a really good sale elsewhere Memorial day weekend.  But on to the review.\n\nI was a backpacker in high school and college and a little beyond.  But I've been away from it for a couple of decades.  Bear canisters didn't exist way back when so, I'd never used one.  And I never had a problem with bears in the the White Mountains of NH where I used to hike.  But I did have plenty of problems with mice around shelters and chipmunks and squirrels and raccoons.  Annoying little buggers.  We also have coyotes, fox, bobcats / lynx, the very rare reported cougar sighting, and brainless golden retrievers on the trail.  By far, I worry more about rodents than bears.\n\nSo when I got into backpacking again, I did a lot of reading to catch up on equipment and clothing trends.  One thing I found is that many areas and national parks around the country are now requiring some form of bear resistant protection for your food.  Hmmm, never even crossed my mind.  Apparently black bear populations are doing really well here in the Northeast and human / bear interactions have increased to the point where it's not all that unusual to get a visit from a lazy thief looking for snacks.\n\nSo I looked around at bear canisters and quickly narrowed my choices down to two options, the Bear Keg and the Bear Vault BV500.  I finally chose the Bear Keg.  Why?\n\n1.)  Size: Both are large.  The Bear Vault is 700 cu in or 11.47 liters.  The Bear keg is just slightly larger at 716 cu in or 11.73 liters.  But call the size a tie.  Both can handle food for two people for 4-5 days.\n\n2.)  Access: Both have an opening of almost exactly 7\" which is fine for getting stuff in or out.  Again, no significant difference.\n\n3.)  Weight: Here we get into the biggest difference between the two options.  The Bear Vault is made from polycarbonate and weighs 2.5 lbs.\n\nThe Bear Keg is made from some other polymer but they don't state exactly what and it weighs in at a whopping 3.5 lbs empty.  So the Bear Vault wins on weight which is a biggie.\n\n4.) Locks:  Here's the second big difference.  The Bear Vault uses a screw on lid with plastic tabs that need to be depressed in order to rotate the lid.  But people report that depressing those tabs requires a leaning curve.  And they say that when the plastic is cold it doesn't flex very well.  Also cold fingers are apparently hard pressed to operate the tabs.  But most importantly bears in the Adirondacks of NY, about two hours from my home have apparently figured out how to use the tabs just fine.  The Bear Vault has proven to be defeatable by real black bears.\n\nThe Bear Keg on the other hand uses three rotating latches that require some sort of tool to open.  A coin, a key, a knife, something with a thin straight edge.  The locks are simple, easy to use in any weather, and reliable.  But best of all, bears haven't figured out how to defeat them as long as you close up the keg properly.\n\n5.)  Color:  No, I'm not gonna get into a discussion of trail fashion here.  The Bear Vault uses clear polycarbonate which provides a really nice side benefit.....you can see what's in the canister and where it is in the canister.  This cuts down on digging, dumping, and repacking.  But a clear canister can be a lot more difficult to find in the woods.  What if a bear plays with it for 15 minutes and moves it 100 feet from its original location.  Clear or black canisters are a lot tougher to see when you don't know where to look.\n\nThe Bear Keg on the other hand uses an opaque day glow yellow polymer that stands out like a sore thumb against a green, brown, and grey background in the woods.  It also had a band of reflective material around the middle in case you're searching for it with a headlamp at night.  The convenience of a clear container does me no good if I can't find the container.  Also, these bear canisters are not so huge that it's very difficult to find stuff in them.  And it gets easier every day as you consume the food in them.\n\n6.)  Price:  Both the Bear Vault and the Bear Keg have the same list price and both can be found discounted to near the same price online.  So price is not a discriminating factor.\n\n7.)  Attaching To A Pack:  The Bear Vault has dimples and ridges molded in for grip.  These allow it to be cinched to a pack with paracord or a velcro strap.\n\nThe Bear Keg is smooth and slippery all the way around with an oval shape that's fatter at the center than the ends.  That makes it tougher for a bear to manipulate but it also means it's tougher to attach to a pack.  For that reason, They sell a nylon carrying case for the Bear Keg but that increases the cost and drives up the weight even more.  Not a problem for me, my pack is a 110 liter Kelty Red Cloud.  I carry everything inside my pack.  It's easier than lashing stuff to the outside.  If you intend to lash a canister outside your pack the carry case is a must have.  But DO NOT place the canister at night with the case on.  The nylon bag provides a bear with a convenient carry handle to cart off your bear keg, thereby defeating the whole idea of protecting your food supply.\n\nSo in the end, what made me buy the Bear Keg over a lighter alternative were better security, easy to use locks, and the high visibility color.  I couldn't find any place in the lower 48 where the Bear Keg is not certified for use.  On the other hand, the Adirondacks near my home won't allow the Bear Vault because bears have learned how to defeat the locks on it.\n\nI docked the product one star for weight.  This is one of the heaviest options on the market.  I'd love to see them get the weight down a pound or so without compromising volume or security.  But maybe that's a tough wish to fulfill.\n\nPS - Either of these canisters makes a serviceable camp stool for eating, lacing up your boots, washing dishes, or washing clothes.\n\nHappy trails and be safe out there.", "summary": "Good security, easy to use locks, and high visibility overcame the high 3.5 lb weight for me.", "unixReviewTime": 1496275200}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "7", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 30, 2014", "reviewerID": "A12B7ZMXFI6IXY", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Hyoun Kim", "reviewText": "Over a year and a half ago, my wife's extended family had a beach trip planned in 2014.  This was before my wife was even pregnant.  Fast forward to a few months ago, we were concerned about sun exposure with our daughter (who would be 4 months old by the time we would use this tent).  Our pediatrician gave us 2 guidelines.\n1. Limit all sun exposure, if possible.\n2. If #1 is not possible, then use baby sunscreen (but try to not use it until she's 6 months old).\n\nBy those 2 guidelines, I started searching all over for some kind of protection on the beach.  I originally saw the&nbsp;<a data-hook=\"product-link-linked\" class=\"a-link-normal\" href=\"/Sport-Brella-Umbrella-Portable-Sun-and-Weather-Shelter/dp/B002CLQ1T4/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_rvw_txt?ie=UTF8\">Sport-Brella Umbrella - Portable Sun and Weather Shelter</a>&nbsp;at a local store.  They had it set up on display but there were a few things I didn't like about it.\n\nFirst, it seemed too low on the ground.  I know that 90% of the time I will be sitting down in it but it just seemed too low when using beach chairs with a fairly tall adult.\n\nSecondly, there is no \"bottom\" on it.  It's open to the ground.  So whatever you place the Sport-Brella on, you need to lay down some towels, tarp, or something else unless you want your butt on the ground.  In my case, it would be the sand.\n\nLastly, I didn't like that the Sport-Brella didn't have the ability to close.  It's wide-open design meant that the usage for shade was limited to the sun movement and there was no privacy.  Meaning when my baby is trying to sleep or if I'm changing her/changing my clothes, then it's wide open for everyone to see.\n\nSo that's when I started looking for alternatives and saw the Coleman Beach Shade.  After reading a couple reviews and seeing pictures of other buyers (who also had babies) with it, I was sold.\n\nThe tent is plenty big enough.  Fully assembled with the front flap down & anchored (as seen in the picture) it can easily accommodate two adults and a baby with plenty of space for a diaper bag, cooler, etc.  With front flap up, an adult and a baby can easily lay down on their backs with it.\n\nWith the design, you get plenty of sun protection via the shade & SPF fabric.  The ability to open the rear for venting air or even as an exit is a nice touch.  It doesn't get too hot in there and while on the beach, there was a nice breeze flowing through the tent.\n\nAlso, I *LOVED* that it came with both stakes AND sandbags for options to anchor the tent down.\n\nMy only complaint about the tent is that when assembling, it can take a little while to put together.  When trying the first time, it can easily take you 20 minutes to put it together.  It definitely becomes easier if you have a second person.  I've assembled/disassembled this tent at least a dozen times now and although I get better at it with each try, it still takes time to put together.  I've shaved my time down to about 8-10 minutes.  With the tent, you get 3 poles.  The 2 shorter black poles run from front to back.  The long gray pole runs across the two black poles.  Once the poles are installed, you fit each end into a grommet at the base of the tent.  The problem is that the long gray pole gets caught on the mesh fabric regardless of whether you're assembling or disassembling the tent.  Part of the reason it gets caught is because the poles can collapse.  This is part of the reason how/why the tent can fit in the carry bag.  When shoving the rod through the mesh (or pulling), sometimes the pole collapses and you have to fix it.  This is why it's so hard to put the tent together.  And because of that, I dock it one star.\n\nOverall I love this tent and would gladly recommend it to anyone looking for shade on the beach... especially those with babies!", "summary": "Purchased for My Infant - Excellent Tent But A Little Hard to Set Up", "unixReviewTime": 1404086400}

{"reviewerID": "A1P99CJ8VCQ0HB", "asin": "B0009PURKE", "reviewerName": "Review King", "verified": true, "reviewText": "(I left a shorter review of this cooler earlier, but after further use wanted to return to leave a more comprehensive review.)\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nI purchased this cooler on the recommendation of a friend who had several at a tailgate party I attended. After searching around for the best price I settled on purchasing the green colored cooler (which was the cheapest at the time) from Amazon. As a prime eligible purchase, it arrived two days later in perfect condition. Absolutely no dings, scratches, or dents like other reviews mention. It was perfectly packaged in factory boxes.\n\nAPPEARANCE\n\nThe cooler is plastic encased in steel. The colored portion you see is steel whereas the white portion is plastic. Some people seem to believe this cooler is all steel. It is not. It is steel belted as the description clearly states. The latch is metal and plastic. The handles are also metal but with plastic grips. The cooler's appearance is stylish. Also, there is NO bottle opener on this version of the cooler. Some reviews allude to the presence of a bottle opener on the outside of the cooler. There is certainly not one on the version I ordered.\n\nFUNCTIONALITY AND USE\n\nHands down this is the best cooler I have ever owned. I take a lot of road trips and travel a lot for work and used to carry along an old generic plastic cooler with me to keep snacks, water, and soda. This cooler has replaced my old beat up travel buddy. It fits nicely in the back of my Ford Escape and has more then enough storage space for meats, cheese, bread, yogurt, fruit, beer, and ice. I can stock it with enough food for a 3-5 day trip easily. The cooler keeps ice for about two to three days outside of extreme temperatures. Two or three two liter bottles of ice are enough to keep everything cold for at least 2 says. If necessary, the ice can be supplemented with a bag of two from the motel to get you through the last day or two of your trip. I do not use the chemical ice packs (except one small one, see below), but they might last a little longer.\n\nNow just one thing to consider before you purchase this item. The cooler can get heavy especially when fully loaded. Of course it depends on what you put in the cooler, but I have loaded mine up to what was probably more then fifty pounds. That can be a lot of weight to carry especially longer distances. Unless you are a large burly man don't plan on carry this cooler, fully loaded, around all day long. (The plastic grips do a good job of stopping the handles from cutting into your hands when carrying and it is on the heavy side). To get around this limitation, I keep a small cold pack in the cooler and a small insulated bag I got as a freebie at a convention. Whenever I need to take something from the car to a different location and do not want to lug the entire cooler I just place what I need in the insulated bag with the cold pack.\n\nTIPS\n\n1. Don't waste your money buying bagged ice at convenience stores. Fill recycled two liter bottles 3/4 way full of water and freeze them. Use these bottles as ice packs. It will not only save you the mess of melted ice, but also a few dollars because you won't have to buy ice.\n\n2. Make sure to chill everything that will go in the cooler at least overnight. This will help extend the life of the ice in the cooler.\n\n3. It is useful to keep something like a bottle opener or cork screw in your cooler. Even a small folding knife can be a lifesaver when you need to cut open a package or some food.\n\nCONCLUSION\n\nThis cooler is well worth the money. Yes, you can find cheaper alternatives in stores and online. But, the value of this cooler cannot be surpassed. You may save a few dollars by buying a generic plastic cooler, but those savings will quickly be lost with all your ice purchases and loss of food due to heat.", "overall": 5.0, "reviewTime": "09 16, 2013", "summary": "Great Cooler, Excellent for Roadtrips", "unixReviewTime": 1379289600}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 23, 2014", "reviewerID": "ABS4QMWGQWIA3", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Scott Johnson", "reviewText": "I mostly burst into flames at the beach, so when my girlfriend suggested we get something like this for the upcoming family beach day, I was relieved and immediately ordered it from Amazon.  It arrived on time (as usual), and we did a dry run in the back yard.  I figured that was better than breaking up in front of her family at the beach if it were really hard to put together.  One pass over the instructions -  which are cleverly attached to the case so they can't be lost - and I was on my way.  It probably too me ten minutes the first time, but it wasn't that difficult at all.  The most difficult part was putting it back in the case.  But we all know that these things never go back in there the way they were.\n\nBeach day came a couple of days later and it was time for the true test.  I was worried about the stakes not staying in the beach sand, but they performed fine.  It was a little tougher to assemble on the beach than it had been in the back yard due to the wind and sand, but I had experience on my side and it was up in no time.  We convinced the kids that filling the included sand bags was a game, so that pretty much took care of itself.  I did end up spilling one of the sand bags inside of the shade.  I wish the drawstrings had some kind of tension closure.  I think next time I'll bring Ziploc bags to put inside of the sandbags.  Or I could just be more careful.  There were other variants of this nearby on the beach, so I got to watch their experience.  They mostly went up faster, but seemed to not store as compactly.  They also either did not offer as much coverage, or didn't have the complete zip up feature like the Coleman did.  I ended up changing inside of this one which was a neat feature.  The kids enjoyed getting inside and zipping it up also.  Though, out in the sun it got very hot very quickly with the zipper closed.\n\nI can see how the wind could be an issue, .but if you open the back window it seems to pass through.  Overall the shade was awesome and just what I needed.  Almost everyone ended up in it at some point.  One of the kids took a nap in it (when the others weren't using it as a beach fort).  My girlfriend took a nap in it, I spent much of my time avoiding spontaneous combustion in there.  It did fill up with sand pretty easily, but it's the beach... what are ya gonna do?\n\nI have four improvements that it could use:\n1. Two more stakes to hold the front flap down - I'll probably end up buying some because i didn't like that it was just loose.\n2. The lack of side windows made it a little isolating when inside the shade\n3. On this occasion the winds were blowing 8 mph with gusts of 15 mph. I set my lunch pack just inside the screen door to weigh the fabric down as I went through the steps I had practiced during the test run. I experienced zero issues. I used the spikes which were okay. It's important to angle them with the wind. I think I will tie ribbon on them like another user suggestes for next time so they don't get lost, or if I decide to use the sand bags I will bring ziplock bags to keep the sand from sifting out. There are mesh pockets inside the tent for said bags but I think other people have tied them to the outside of the tent and buried them. This setup took under 10 minutes. {"overall": 3.0, "vote": "84", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "01 19, 2009", "reviewerID": "A1QFFRX44YPXX8", "asin": "B0009PUTDE", "reviewerName": "Andrew J. Riemer", "reviewText": "I've been wilderness camping for over 26 years.  When I first started (as a Boy Scout), a folding shovel was high on my list of \"must have\" camping gear.  After purchasing one, however, and carrying it with me on a number of outings, I soon came to a different conclusion.\n\nWhy do most people want to carry a shovel? I usually hear three reasons: 1) to dig a trench around a tent, 2) to shovel ash out of the fire pit, and 3) to dig a scat hole (a hole for depositing excrement).  Let me address those three items, and then address some different types of camping or outings that may further influence your decision.\n\nTRENCHING AROUND TENTS\n----------------------\nSimply put, this is an outdated practice that causes erosion in campsites.  Trenches eventually fill and overflow, carrying off soil and altering the conditions in the site.  In fact, most campsites (and all National Parks and wilderness areas) prohibit trenching.  If you really want the floor of your tent to stay dry on the inside, purchase a tent with a tub floor (where the seams are raised off the bottom of the tend) and a good rain fly.\n\nSHOVELING ASH\n-------------\nWhile a shovel can be used to shovel ash out of a fire pit, so can small gargen trowel, a metal cup, a metal plate, or even a frying pan.  You're likely already going to be carrying a cup, plate, or pan, so there is no need to carry the extra gear (the shovel).  A large stick can be used to stir coals in an active fire, and the cookware can be rinsed with water after using it to dig out the fire pit.\n\nSCAT HOLES\n----------\nWhen digging a hole for human waste, you typically need to turn only a few inches of soil.  I've found that a garden trowel does a splendid job, and it weighs only a few ounces compared to the 2.4 lbs. of this shovel.\n\nDIFFERNT CAMPING METHODS REQUIRE DIFFERENT GEAR\n---------------------------------------------\nLet's face it, it makes a difference if you are driving into a campsite rather than hiking in.  If driving in, you are less concerned about how heavy your gear is, so a shovel like this one may be a nice luxury.  If backpacking or on any wilderness excursion where you are carrying everything you need, you feel every extra ounce you carry.  In such cases, a gardening trowel makes more sense.  You can get one made from composite plastics that is very hard and durable, but weighs only a few ounces.\n\nIn my years of experience, I found that the weight of the shovel was not worth the benefit I received from it while on wilderness treks.  However, I love keeping one of these in the trunk of my car to help dig out if I get stuck in the snow.\n\nThe Coleman folding shovel is a nice little tool.  You just need to decide if you want to carry it with you when you spend time in the wilderness.", "summary": "Great for the car--do you really need one for camping?", "unixReviewTime": 1232323200}

{"overall": 1.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "02 21, 2013", "reviewerID": "A2KH5YM52WBQM2", "asin": "B0009PUTDE", "reviewerName": "roundmot", "reviewText": "I was looking for a folding shovel to include in a Roadside Emergency Kit for the trunk of my family car. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "9", "verified": false, "reviewTime": "08 27, 2010", "reviewerID": "A2VQ0V1TWXF3U7", "asin": "B0009PVUW8", "style": {"Style Name:": " PRO (109 mm Balls)"}, "reviewerName": "Mark A. Baker", "reviewText": "I played bocce at the beach for the first time a couple of months ago, and I was hooked.  I went home and immediately did hours of research to find the best one for the price.  This set won out in the end.  So I played with this one and another Sportcraft (100 mm black / red) one, and the quality was there for both of them, but I am satisfied that I ordered this set because of the 4 colors and the slightly larger (109mm) size.  Let me be brief --\n\nPros:\n1) high quality material\n2) weighted really nicely, nice size too\n3) 4 colors, then each 2 bocce balls of the same color are differentiated by different markings, making it possible for up to 8 different people to play. I have needed 8 balls a couple of times, so this alone has made this set worth it.\n4) Great pallino and measuring device\n\nCons:\n1)  cheap bag.  I've seen better from cheaper sets at the store.  The bag will not likely outlast the set.\n2)  Paint wear pretty quickly.\n  --Pro:  who cares?! It adds character!\n\nI enjoyed my set so much after the first few uses, that I ordered one from Amazon for my father's birthday.  He loves it, and he will be able to play it with his grandkids which shows the versatility of this game.\nBonus tip:  Free trial of Amazon prime got it to me next day with just a few bucks more.  Well worth it!\n\n****UPDATE****\nI have now owned this set for almost five years.  This is a product that has been so good, I felt obligated to revise my review.  This set has seen countless games, on the beaches of Florida, to the mountains of Colorado to the sand dunes in Southern Utah.  Bocce has become easily my most favorite outdoor game.  My wife just commented today, \"you have made a lot of friends with that game.\"  It's true, it's a great game because people don't need experience to play or have fun.  Anybody can just join in and get the hang of it.\n\nI have only owned this one set, and it has held up beautifully.  The balls now all have \"character\", with the paint being severely dulled and worn, but it doesn't affect gameplay at all.  Just as predicted, the bag is about dead, but just refuses to bust open.  It is ripping at the seams.  I'm not sure what I'll do when the bag breaks.  Maybe I can have the company send me a new one. The balls have no chips or cracks after many hard hits on rocks, concrete, and against each other, so I expect them to continue to last.  I have played with 3 other sets (not sure the manufactueres).  This one felt like the best size and weight for my throw, and the materials feel better than most.  Bottom line, the game of Bocce is tons of fun, and this set is the best I've played with.\n\nI have had many times where more than four people want to play.  Usually it is more than four but less than eight.  This is tricky, because then each person would really only have one ball to throw.  Although that is still fun, part of the skill of the game is to throw your first ball and then adjust for the second so that you get better.  If you only throw one ball, it takes away that aspect.  So I am going to get a second set so that everyone can throw at least two balls.", "summary": "Recommended for the price", "unixReviewTime": 1282867200}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 23, 2013", "reviewerID": "A1EHHEQIEYDL6C", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Tina Hood", "reviewText": "Was so glad to find a more affordable option compared to the Kelty.  As we live 1.5 hours or more from the closest saltwater beach, when we go, we stay all day.  After setting this up, folks who were leaving, stated that if they had a shelter like us, they wouldn't be leaving.  The temp was in the high 90's with nary a cloud in sight.  A great day to test out our shelter.\n\nPrior to purchasing this, we used two beach umbrellas and would need to move with the shade all day -- but if you're on a real crowded beach and your neighbors are real close, you have to move your umbrellas all day.  Either way, it's annoying, inconvenient, and can be downright dangerous if you've fallen asleep.\n\nThis eliminates almost all of that.  I say almost as we still needed an umbrella in front until later in the afternoon when the sun was mostly behind us.\n\nWe enjoyed the partial privacy afforded by blocking our view of our side neighbors.  It was very nice to take a nap and not worry about the sun moving OR feeling as though you're on display while you sleep.\n\nWe only used stakes around the edges of the shelter, we didn't feel we would need tie-out lines.  At times the wind was extremely gusty, and although we didn't use the tie-out lines, the shelter didn't go anywhere -- many beach umbrellas became projectiles and our own umbrella turned inside out -- so the wind was very strong.\n\nWe also liked having items in the shelter that were kept sand-free.  It was nice to have everything contained within the shelter.  And if you're like us, and like to go for long walks, it's nice to know that your stuff isn't exposed to everyone and the sea gulls.\n\nWe had the back window open and rolled up, for ventilation, until the sun moved back there.  Then we unhooked it, and let it hang so we'd be shaded but still have ventilation.\n\nWe are more than pleased with this shelter.  It's easy to set up, roomy, stays put in gusty winds, is easy to take down, and doesn't weigh much.  We are looking forward to our next beach day!", "summary": "F.A.B.U.L.O.U.S.!!!", "unixReviewTime": 1374537600}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "03 12, 2013", "reviewerID": "A8W5F04E18Y1D", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Anonymous", "reviewText": "I was hesitant to purchase this based upon some of the complaints, but having assembled this today (in the house) I do not foresee any quality problems or other issues, and expect this tent will last for years to come.\n\nAssembly is just like a normal tent, with fiberglass rods that assemble into a longer pole.  There are three poles, each about 6 to 8 feet long assembled.  The poles slide into mesh sleeves, which are less durable than nylon fabric, but prevent sand from filling the sleeves.  Just take your time during tent assembly and disassembly, do not force the rods, and the mesh should not be a problem.\n\nAs for the tent itself, it is quite large, easily fitting two adults, possible three.  In the back is a door/window with a solid panel and screen, depending upon which zipper you open (there are two on the back door, one for the nylon flap, one for the screen).  The large front door also zips shut for privacy/changing clothes.\n\nThe carry case is also nice and well made, with handles, to carry everything in a compact form.\n\nThis tent is a really great item, and I will update this review should there be any issues, which I do not foresee given the nice quality of this tent.\n\nThe tent is made in Bangladesh.\n\nUPDATE: MAY 5 2013\nWe took this to the beach, where the conditions were windy.  Set up required two adults to fight against the wind.  Total set up time must have been 10 minutes, however, once set up it provided shelter from the wind and sun.  We stayed all day at the beach until almost sunset, and without the tent the wind and sun would have forced us to leave much sooner.  Some strong gusts did occasionally push the tent sides in a bit, but they popped back out as the wind subsided.  On windy days, I would not leave the tent without a person inside to prevent it blowing away.  The included sand bags, which we used, would not have prevented the tent from blowing away. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "10 31, 2016", "reviewerID": "AOOCZBTIWKRDB", "asin": "B0009PURJK", "reviewerName": "Rave On", "reviewText": "This is a must-have item if you use Coleman fuel for your gas stoves and lantern.  I don't know why I waited so long to get one.  You replace the  white cap on the fuel can (standard 1\" diameter) by putting this threaded filler device in place of the cap.  Put the nozzle into the fuel canister of your stove or lantern and push down which releases the liquid fuel from the fuel can into your stove or lantern.  You can hear the fuel going into the stove or lantern \"glug glug, glug\".  When the sound stops, it is full.  You just life the filler assembly out of the stove/lantern and you are done. {"overall": 4.0, "vote": "157", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 4, 2012", "reviewerID": "A2LIQOW3N9IHAD", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Fern", "reviewText": "We have owned this tent for a month or so and we have used it 6 or so times already.  We had bought it so that my 6 month old wouldn't get too much sun when we are at the beach. I'll start off by telling you the features that we like about it.\n* It produces a good amount of shade\n* It's nice looking\n* It could double as a camping tent for a child or small adult without gear in a pinch\n* It has a floor that extends out passed the canopy.\n* If set up correctly, it is rock solid against even moderate wind. We have not been out in a storm or really heavy winds but you probably wouldn't want to be at the beach bad weather anyway.\n* The back flap can be tied open, zipped to a mosquito net, or zipped with a nylon flap.  Very versitile.\n* It packs away in a nice small, light package.\n\nThe only thing that I don't like about it is that they used a netted material to make the sleeves that the poles slide through.  I understand why they chose it and don't really know if there would have been a better material to use.  They used it so that it doesn't get full of sand and for it to dry very if wet.  However, 90% of the time assembling it you  will spend it dealing with the couplings and ends of the poles getting gigged on the netted material. If your not careful I can see how it would tear quite easily.  You have to be patient and take your time  sliding it through while helping releasing the snags as they present themselves (cause they will).  It seems as if the slower you try to do it, the faster and easier it will go.  Even with one person. Isn't that the case with most things though?\nI like the sandbags.  If you fill them up all the way and burry them in the sand the tent will be rock solid. The stakes are pretty thin and will not work in the sand obviously.  They don't seem like they will take much hammering unless it's really soft dirt.  Try attaching the filled sand bags before setting it up so you won't have to fight the wind.  Then move it where you like it and then burry the sandbags to really anchor it down.  That's how I do it and it works great.  Once up, you will love it. {"image": ["https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/61sRDjvvPZL._SY88.jpg"], "overall": 5.0, "vote": "286", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "09 23, 2011", "reviewerID": "A2KUPH96YRYLJZ", "asin": "B0009PUTIE", "style": {"Color:": " Lime"}, "reviewerName": "Drew Cheney", "reviewText": "If you're a parent, the picture I uploaded pretty much sums it all up. Our son took his nap on the beach in Maui, so this thing was worth it, just for that.\n\nWe've used it once on the beach in Monterey, CA, and 5 times at various beaches in Maui (just a few weeks ago), and there's no signs of cheap-o wear-and-tear. For the price, this \"tent\" is extremely well-made, and is ready to go, right out of the bag.* If you want to stake out the front flap and also use the included lines, though, you'll need to buy 2 more stakes. The included sand bags actually came in handy on a windy day on Maui.\n\nIt folds up well, and the stuffed bag is small enough to fit in a smaller suitcase (not a carryon, as it's a little less than 23 inches long). If you want to go hard-core on weight-reduction, you could probably replace the fiberglass poles with aluminum poles (keep the tips, though, or you won't be able to keep anything in place!).\n\nTwo things I'll add to what others have said:\n1. For effective venting with the tent all closed up, I kept the back window unzipped at the bottom, and the front flap unzipped at the top. Even in Maui, the moving air kept the interior of the tent cool enough for comfortable napping.\n2. If you want MORE venting and don't want to allow the sun in through the rear window, use Metal Binder Clips to clip the unzipped flap against the \"frame\" of the window. Fiddling with the setup can give you some pretty good airflow.\n\nI would definitely buy this, again.\n\n*One thing I would definitely add to the carry-bag, though, is a small whisk broom to clean out sand before naps or collapsing. It's not vital, but it will add to user comfort and help your tent last longer.", "summary": "AWESOME. 'Nuff said...", "unixReviewTime": 1316736000}

I imagine with a helper and in actual use outdoors set up and take down would take about the same amount of time, or if my helper is off chasing our kid making sure she doesn't drown in the ocean it might take a whopping 15 minutes for setup.\n\nI like that there are sand bags; I also like that there's a little line to hang stuff to dry just inside the \"ceiling\" of the tent. It's a good size--I think it will provide ample shade for our little family of three, but perhaps not quite enough for us plus the grandparents. Peterson", "reviewText": "In short, this bag is heavy, but that's the cost of a bag rated at 0 degrees.  You can find lighter 0 degree bags, but you will certainly pay more for them.  On the other hand, because the bag is so thick, I don't use a sleeping pad, so it washes out for me.  I just used this bag for a winter camping trip (it got to the low 20s, maybe high teens) and I generally felt comfortable.  No issues with the zipper snagging either, which was great.  Finally, the bag rolls up large in the provided sack, so I recommend getting a compress bag.  You can get it down to at least 2/3s of the size with that method. {"image": ["https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81Fiw5iYeGL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81BsLA101JL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81fCsQ4kdnL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71fA6+JlkqL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81IcyTT9ohL._SY88.jpg", "https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81TS9SgwtlL._SY88.jpg"], "overall": 5.0, "vote": "67", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "06 26, 2017", "reviewerID": "ABE99RSP9GNHC", "asin": "B0009PUSO4", "reviewerName": "Henry W Dwyer", "reviewText": "Purchased this for elk hunting in the winter. Lowest the temps have gotten is in the 20's and one night it was snowing, but I stayed perfectly warm in a tent with this sleeping bag. I'm 5'9, 200, and there is plenty of room inside it for me. I don't feel cramped and my feet do not touch the end. The bag fits snug around my shoulders (but not uncomfortable tight) which helps keep in warm air throughout the night. On a few occasions, I've had to unzip the bag during the night to let cool air in. My only complaint, and it's not enough to drop a star, but the carrying bag this comes in is very small. It sometimes takes 2 people to put this sleeping bag back into the carrying case.\n\n*** Update ***\n\nAfter using this bag a few more times for camping, I've figured out how to properly roll it up so it goes into the carrying bag more easily. Start at the top of the bag and fold it in half length ways. 3/4 down the bag where it tapers to a smaller size, leave that part unfolded. As you roll the bag up, the small end should be the same width as the top half when its folded. This will reduce the thickness of the bag when rolled up, and it will go into the carrying bag much easier.\n\nAt first, I would fold the bag in half lengthways, all the way down, then roll it up. This was making it too bulky to fit properly in the bag and would take 2 people to put it in. Now, I can roll it up and have it back in the bag in about a minute.\n\nI've attached some pictures that show the dimensions of the sleeping bag rolled up in the carrying bag. This may be helpful for anyone that is planning on using this bag for backpacking, but not sure if it will be too bulky. Also, so you can see how the size of this bag compares to a larger sleeping bag, I took a picture of it laying on top of a Teton XXL sleeping bag.\n\nDimensions:\n - Length from end to face opening: 73\"\n - Width at the shoulders: 30\"", "summary": "Kept me toasty warm in 20 degree weather!", "unixReviewTime": 1498435200}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "03 22, 2014", "reviewerID": "AENDDM5JWHX1U", "asin": "B0009QRRUG", "reviewerName": "Matthew Brown", "reviewText": "I just got two of them today, and have been sparring with them all day.  But I feel I'm ready to write a review on it so here we go:\n\nDurability is not an issue with these bokken.  At first I thought it may be, but they can take some pretty heavy usage as long as you don't beat down a metal post with it.  Me and my wife have been smacking these around about as much as you would in a tournament, and they are barely even scuffed.\n\nThe only removable part would be the handguard, or tsuba (but this is Murica, so I'm gonna use English).  The handguard is pretty tough to slip into its place, but not impossible.  The O-ring keeps it on really well, too.  ALMOST no slippage, although after a couple of bouts it does come out of place a very little bit.\n\nThe grip is really comfortable.  HOWEVER, when your hands start sweating it does get a little slippery, but I would recommend gloves and other safety gear anyway, so no complaint here.  It also weighs and handles really closely to my katana, and it has the proper amount of flexibility as a sword should.  If you were to get struck by this in training, there wouldn't be as much damage done as a wooden bokken, although you will feel it for sure (especially the fingers, but that's what gloves are for).\n\nAs a whole, I'm really glad I bought these.  They simulate actual combat very well, and are very sturdy.  I recommend these to anybody studying Japanese martial arts.", "summary": "As good as they come", "unixReviewTime": 1395446400}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "04 30, 2012", "reviewerID": "A1A629D04LRFUD", "asin": "B0009QRRUG", "reviewerName": "Spore", "reviewText": "I was going to buy a wooden bokken as a practice sword but I noticed this Cold Steel Bokken was only a little bit more $$. I'm very glad I spent the extra cash.\n\nThe sword is constructed of a very strong polycarbonate plastic that is very tough. You could spar with this sword and it will last a very long time even if you are very aggressive. I took a few whacks with it at various things and there isn't a single dent on it.\n\nThe only downside to this sword is the very slight flex when hitting something, compared to a wooden sword. The flex will be unnoticeable unless you are focusing on it, and you will not notice it if you are engaged.\n\nFor people purchasing this sword for personal, non-professional, or non-sporting use, I just want to warn you how dangerous even this plastic sword is. There are videos on youtube where people use this sword to easily crush watermelons and break wooden crates. Also, make sure you know the laws in your state (or country if outside the US) regarding carrying these publicly, in some states it isn't legal to carry one of these outside, even in plain sight. You could be arrested.\n\nFinally, I would like to add that I will most likely be keeping this sword, but I will also purchase an O Bokken, which is only a few inches larger, but it is over 50% heavier. This bokken is great for people under 6 feet, but the O Bokken might be more appropriate if you are taller or want to get stronger.", "summary": "A great practice sword for a reasonable price", "unixReviewTime": 1335744000}

{"overall": 2.0, "vote": "4", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "02 7, 2016", "reviewerID": "AV4IP1U7MPZ1O", "asin": "B0009PUSO4", "reviewerName": "SBN Codey", "reviewText": "I bought this sleeping bag knowing it was too heavy for backpacking, thinking it would be worth the extra weight just so I wouldn't be cold during winter camping trips. I was wrong.\nFirst off, this bag is enormous. Compression sacks do very little for this. You WILL have to strap it to the outside of your bag, unless you have a milsurp large ALICE bag, in which case it will fill over half of the storage space. I estimate it takes up 30L of space in it's stuff sack.\n\nSecond off, this bag is heavy. It's heavier than my tent, heavier than my backpack. It's actually the heaviest thing in my pack. That's somewhat to be expected as a cheap zero-degree bag, but let's observe that...\n\nThis is not a zero-degree bag. I took it on several camping trips with a low of 32F. It is only comfortable if you're fully dressed: multiple layers, jacket, two pairs of socks and a beanie. This last trip I went without the jacket and only wore one pair of thick wool socks, and was miserably cold all night. Note that this was 32F, and had the aid of a thermal reflecting sleeping pad. The description boasts comfort down to 15F. I'd argue probable survival at those temps, but not a cozy night.\n\nI was prepared to make some sacrifices in weight to save money and still be warm, but in the end I was disappointed in all regards.\nI would rate 1 star, but I must admit that it is warmer than my 40F Summer bag, and at least on this last trip I didn't die or lose extremities to frostbite. I expect these to last a long time and be warm enough for anything except winter camping. It absolutely keeps us warm even in fall and winter inside a tent.\n\nYes, in the camping world of gadgets ... the lighter an item is, it is disproportionately expensive. This sleeping bag is much heftier than very high end ones that are equally warm yet super light. {"overall": 4.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "04 5, 2013", "reviewerID": "A1LY3BVE3G6HKZ", "asin": "B0009PUSO4", "reviewerName": "JRB", "reviewText": "I do three season hiking in the Appalachian Trail region. In early spring and late fall the temperatures can get pretty low. I had decided that I wanted a mummy bag previously and began searching for something around the 20+ degree range. I stumbled upon this bag and given its price thought that it would make a good purchase. I believe I made the right choice.\n\nPros - This bag is warm. While the description states that it is a \"0-Degree\" bag, I would not suggest using it in that type of weather. A lot of individuals see that and believe that they could sleep in 0-degree weather comfortably. That is not the case. My guess is that this bag would be comfortable around 30-degrees. I have not yet had it out in weather that cold so I cannot say for sure. Furthermore, in weather that cold I typically place a couple of body or hand warmers in the bag with me. You could also use a sleeping bag liner which would make this bag warmer as well. For most individuals camping in typical camping weather, this bag will be more than enough.\n\nIn order to reach that 0-degree rating, the bag has a considerable amount of insulation inside of it. This makes it fairly comfortable to sleep in. I use a self-inflating sleeping pad when I hike. The combination of the bag and the pad made for a relatively comfortable nights sleep.\n\nCons - As stated above, the warmth and comfort is achieved through a generous amount of insulation. This also results in the bag being fairly heavy and bulky. You will have a difficult time attempting to stuff this into a backpack (I use a Teton 5200 and I cannot fit it into the sleeping bag compartment. Instead I put it in the main compartment and put my clothes in the sleeping bag compartment). If you have the money and will be doing a lot of backpacking I would suggest getting a smaller, more manageable, bag.", "summary": "A warm bag at a reasonable price", "unixReviewTime": 1365120000}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "5", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 18, 2011", "reviewerID": "AEEXMTGSUYS3Y", "asin": "B0009PUSO4", "reviewerName": "flyboynyc", "reviewText": "After reading all the reviews on here, I decided to purchase this sleeping bag for my camping trip this past October.  I was initially looking to buy an inexpensive sleeping bag for my brother since he didn't have one, but I ended up giving him my old Wenzel bag and decided to purchase a newer one for myself.  I didn't want to spend a lot of money, but I didn't want something that was only going to last for one season before falling apart either.  This Coleman bag fit the bill nicely.\n\nSince I was pretty much looking to use this particular bag for car camping excursions or short backpacking trips, I wasn't as concerned about the weight or bulk of the bag as I normally would be.  I like the Coleman brand in general, and while it's definitely not on par with the higher end brand names like The North Face, Marmot, etc., their products do serve their purpose as long as you understand and accept their limitations for what they're worth.  This bag is probably too bulky for any real backpacking trips, but throw it in the car and it's great for car camping and base camp.  I liked the look of the bag and especially the extra \"toe space\" this bag provided.  After hanging the bag up for a day and letting it air out (just to ensure there would be no chemical odors and to allow the bag to \"loft up\") I jumped in and my brother and I each tested it out and compared it to my old Wenzel Windy Pass 0-degree Mummy Bag from 2008.  While both bags offered similar features and comfort, I much prefered the zippers on this Coleman bag and found the anti-snag feature interesting.  Overall, I found this bag to be comfortable and worth the price.\n\nTemperatures on our camping trip dropped down to the low 50's at night so I can't really attest to how warm the bag COULD be in colder weather, but it was perfectly comfortable on this particular trip.  Initially I found the bag too hot and had to unzip it open, but eventually zipped myself back in as I cooled down and ended up sleeping very well each night of our trip in long underwear in this bag.  The stuff sack included with the bag is rather large, and I'm not sure why other reviewers found it difficult to pack it back in.  I carefully rolled my bag up and packed it in an even smaller compression sack in effort to save space in my car trunk (there were 4 of us camping with all my gear packed in my Mazda3, so space was at a premium) but it would have been a cinch to just stuff it back into its own included carry sack.\n\nOverall, a good purchase but like others have said, probably not the sleeping bag you'd want to bring with you on backpacking trips due to its size.  Great for car camping, base camp, sleepovers, or any other times that space and weight are not an issue.  In those situations you'll probably want to get a higher end sleeping bag for that purpose.", "summary": "Good sleeping bag for the price", "unixReviewTime": 1324166400}

{"overall": 4.0, "vote": "532", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "02 1, 2010", "reviewerID": "A2KWX5AVVCC2NU", "asin": "B0009PUSO4", "reviewerName": "youtoo", "reviewText": "I bought this bag and took it out backpacking at White Sands National Monument in NM in Jan.  A winter storm hit the day before I left and it was COLD out there.  I'm not sure of the exact temperature, but I know that it was either high teens or low 20s.  My waterbottle and my dog's water bowl both completely froze throughout as did the condensation on the outside of my tent, and my car was a big ice block when I got back to it in the morning.  The bag actually did pretty well.  I pulled the face hole as tight as I could and just cuddled down inside the bag without sticking my face out (it was too cold if I put my face out).  I have Raynaud's disease and my hands/nailbeds often are very cold and turn blue in cold weather from poor circulation, but they were nice and warm inside the bag without extra gloves on.  I was impressed by that.  Overall I was ok, but not as warm and comfortable as I would have been at home in my own bed of course.  It did it's job and kept my appendages warm enough and me alive in what could have been hypothermia conditions without the proper gear.  My only real gripe about this bag is that it is huge when it's rolled up.  It's too big to fit into the sleeping bag compartment of my NorthFace backpacking pack (so I imagine it's too big for any), and it takes up a very large portion of the pack when stuffed in the only way it will fit.  Due to this reason I wish I would have gotten a different bag.  It would be great for anyone who is just setting up their tent right next to their car, but not the best choice for a backpacker.", "summary": "Nice product do not buy if you're planning on backpacking", "unixReviewTime": 1264982400}

Leigh", "reviewText": "Any sword that is only $15 is in fact very dangerous. These swords are called wallhangers because they are only designed to by hung on a wall, not swung. The reason is that underneath the handle is a very small piece of metal that connects to the blade itself. (Called the Tang) In a real martial arts sword, the tang is normally a thick piece of metal that is almost the thickness of the sword itself. If you swing a wallhanger too often or too hard it can break at the tang, and fly off and hurt someone.\n\nIf you want to learn more about how dangerous these wallhangers are do a google search on the words: anatomy of a wallhanger\n\nAny sword designed for real martial arts practice- like Iaido, starts at $250 not $15, and should be bought at a reputable Iaido store. (sorry I am not allowed to recommend web sites here).\n\nSo be smart, either hang this sword back on the wall, or throw it out before your baby brother/sister hurts someone.", "summary": "Dangerous", "unixReviewTime": 1148688000}

The bike nor mirror has not suffered any major spills. Instead, I often find myself leaning the bike on the left side where the mirror is attached. Each time, the mirror gently bumps against a wall or car or some other vertical surface which I lean the bike against.\n\nThe mirror's upper hinge has become looser and looser to the point where it now simply flops around and won't hold it's place. I suppose the mirror is designed with a tiny bit of give or play to allow for easy adjustment; as a result, the mirror is easy to move and jar loose with even the slightest pressure, resulting over time in a loose joint with a lot of play that simply cannot be tightened.\n\nIt's par for the course: it's a $12 mirror so durability may be too much to ask, but there must be a manufacturer out there who can design a mirror that doesn't loosen over time, even if it requires selling at a slightly higher price point?", "summary": "Upper Hinge Gradually Loosens and Becomes Unstable", "unixReviewTime": 1525219200}

This design cleverly uses friction to keep the mirror locked in place once you adjust it. You just have to make sure you don't over tighten them to the point of breaking the plastic or stripping the threads. {"overall": 5.0, "vote": "7", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 29, 2017", "reviewerID": "AEJDSIFM3O2W0", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Arizona Doug", "reviewText": "This bike mirror really is deserving of the high praise and ratings. When I ordered this mirror, I also ordered the Hafny Bar End Bike Mirror and the Venzo Handlebar Stainless Steel Mirror. The latter two were much smaller in mirror image surface, making your rearward view somewhat insufferable. Also, they weren't shabby but their product engineering was inferior to the Mirrycle. The Mirrycle is engineered with male hex bolts that screw into micro-tapered female brass pieces that become tighter and tighter as you screw the hex bolt in place. Yes, it is a bit difficult to screw the hex bolt into place with the hex key (provided) but what you get when you're finished is a rearview mirror on your handlebar that does not jiggle. Yes, it bounces as the handlebar bounces--can't avoid the physics of bicycle riding--but all the jiggle in the mirror is eliminated. With the larger mirror surface, you get a much better rearward view, and you can adjust it with your hand. Terrific product, and terrific value. I wish I had not waited to get this.", "summary": "Far better than the competition", "unixReviewTime": 1501286400}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "2", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "07 17, 2017", "reviewerID": "AHLF5V8B3Z8C7", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "-=Rudy=-", "reviewText": "I bought one of these for my own bike a couple of years ago from a bike shop, and just recently bought a second one here on Amazon for another new addition to the bike fleet.  This little thing is more sturdy than I give it credit for.  When the mirror heats up outdoors in the sun, the fittings can get loose.  I have been able to tighten them beyond what I think is safe for plastic, yet it has held up with no problem, and even at that tightness the mirror is still adjustable.  Luckily the grips I use on both bikes (made by Ergon) have open ends, so I was easily able to put the mirror into the left handlebar end without having to cut or modify the original grips. The plastic is poly-carbonate with threaded brass inserts for the screws. Assembly was easy, as long as the screws were oiled first. {"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "03 19, 2017", "reviewerID": "A2LT0ZKWMDX20Y", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Wanda E.", "reviewText": "My absolute favorite bike handlebar mirror and I've tried several.", "summary": "Five Stars", "unixReviewTime": 1489881600}
{"overall": 5.0, "verified": false, "reviewTime": "03 18, 2017", "reviewerID": "AGDOWFCL6E4JE", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Jon Helberg", "reviewText": "Just installed the Mirrycle bicycle mirror today and took it for a test run.\n\nA few observations and comments.\n\nAgreed, assembly is not entirely easy. As mentioned by numerous reviews, the screws drive hard to the point that you think you're actually cracking the plastic plus the included Allen wrench requires some strength to turn. But not to worry. Read the instructions and theyll confirm the hard drive and that you will not crack the plastic. I didn't try WD40 or any other lubricant so cannot say if that would ease the assembly.\n\nI installed the Mirrycle onto a GT hybrid bicycle and after using a Dremel tool to create an opening in the end of my handle grip I found the handlebar opening accepted the smaller of the two wedges for mounting. I chose to follow the alternative down and under installation mentioned on Amazon reviews which is quite clever and works very well however I believe you may get a better site picture using the normal above and to the side installation which would facilitate not having to move your eyes so far from your frontal path to do so. The primary disadvantage to the normal up-and-out installation is that the mirror really sticks out there very exposed and if/when you dump your bike or ride close to any shrubs, etc., your mirror will be the early casualty, plus the storage shed where we keep our bikes is small which would necessitate tucking the mirror in upon each return. Do whichever works best for you.\n\nFrom the lower mounting position I could see both myself and directly behind me but I don't believe that provides the maximum field of view. On my initial trip I stopped a couple times to adjust the mirror in a similar manner to what you would do with a car, i.e., if you can see part of yourself/your bike in the mirror, tilt it out just a little further until you cant and that should be about right. Once adjusted properly you only need to tilt your head a tad one way to see either part of yourself directly behind the mirror or a tad the other way to see much more of the road to your direct left.\n\nI was amazed at how solid this mirror rode exhibiting absolutely no jitter or vibration. The large convex shape  offered a wide, clear field of view which allowed me not only to see what was coming from behind me but also what was to the near left rear of me as well.\n\nThis was only my first day with this product but Im impressed with the quality and the flexible mounting options it offers.", "summary": "Recommended", "unixReviewTime": 1489795200}

{"overall": 5.0, "vote": "6", "verified": true, "reviewTime": "10 13, 2016", "reviewerID": "A3NGOG8Z78AZSD", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Edward Barnett", "reviewText": "I installed one of these on my mountain bike fifteen years ago. Survived lots of heavy trail riding, banging into trees, etc. Recently the plastic stem finally cracked, and I was delighted to find out that the same Mirrycle MTB bar end mount design is still available. Not surprising, I guess, since they pretty much nailed it the first time. The mirror is large enough to provide an excellent view of the whole road behind. Unlike smaller mirrors, or helmet-mounted mirrors, this model doesn't require your head to be in exactly the right position to see the road behind you. No way cars will sneak up on you with this model. Installation is very simple, and adjustment is almost as easy as adjusting side mirrors on a car (although you'll probably want to use a tool to really tighten it into position once its angled exactly as you want it). As I mentioned, durability for me has been outstanding. The arm holds the mirror out a few inches from the end of the handlebar, which is great for visibility, but if you ride narrow trails with trees or cliffs really tight on the sides, there's a chance you'll scrape the mirror on obstacles from time to time. I've had this happen, but I just twist the mirror back into position. Great visibility, outstanding durability, inexpensive. An excellent investment in riding safety.", "summary": "Super safety addition. Extremely durable.", "unixReviewTime": 1476316800}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 10, 2016", "reviewerID": "AZOQ8PJLQ5RG5", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Robert", "reviewText": "I installed this a couple of weeks ago. This mirror is well designed and exceeded my expectations.\nWhen I first started installing it I thought it was defective because I could not get the threads of the screws to start. I tried grinding the starter thread because it would not start more than a 1/2 turn.\nThen I remembered what I had read when I ordered it and looked at the instructions. The tight threads are this way by design. This allows you to adjust the mirror while riding so that you can get it exactly where you want it. The alternative would be very difficult. You would have to adjust then ride, then adjust and re-adjust every time it would get moved. Or the screws would back out when the mirror gets turned.\nThe mirror will allow you to see oncoming traffic on both sides of the road or, regardless of whether you riding with or against traffic, because it has a wide field of view.\n\nAn excellent value for the money. The only thing I would like to see different is the type of plastic. The plastic in the mirror mount I bought is hard and probably brittle. I suspect it will break if I drop the bike or otherwise strike the mount with any appreciable force. The brittle, hard plastic is no doubt necessary to facilitate the tight threads so the female threaded portion won't come loose or break free inside the plastic when tightening.\nA think a better but no doubt more expensive design would incorporate some flexibility to avoid breakage.", "summary": "Well designed, a smart purchase.", "unixReviewTime": 1470787200}

{"overall": 5.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "12 3, 2015", "reviewerID": "A1E0XYSGS9DYQH", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "morgan greywolf", "reviewText": "Best MTB/ATB bike mirror ever.  Accept no substitutes.  This thing attaches to the end of the bar with some opposing wedge-shaped pieces with a long socket-head bolt going through them and a barrel nut squeezing them together.  As the screw gets tightened, the wedge pieces expand out towards the tube walls on the handlebars. This creates an anchor 2-3 inches or so into the end of the handle. Once it's in, this thing is *not* *moving* until you loosen the bolt. Assembly and attachment is very easy and takes only minutes. Everything you need to attach this onto your handlebars is included, but you will need a utility knife to cut a hole in any rubber/plastic grips you have. Includes both a larger and smaller wedge piece to accommodate different sized bars.  High-quality build and finish. Fortunately, the Kickbike had end plugs that prevented me from having to cut the grips.\n\nYes, assembling these components is quite difficult.  As the instructions clearly indicate, the brass inserts are tight!  This keeps the mirror from moving while allowing you to move it when necessary.  I ride this Kickbike on back country paved roads, gravel roads, and even access trails, and have never had the mirrors move once, even after reaching 28 mph on rough pavement!  I cannot understand the poor reviews.\n\nThe mirrors are convex, which helps detect traffic behind you.  Having a mirror both right and left woks wonders for the Kickbike, which gives me complete visibility behind me regardless whether I am kicking or walking left or right, and regardless of how I have the handlebars oriented.  Remember, this is the primary reason for convex mirrors; you need the greater field of view when the handlebars are turned.\n\nThey are also glass; where can you find glass mirrors for this price nowadays? Roberti", "reviewText": "If you want a bike mirror, look no further...seriously. It's well made, solid, and holds its position while riding over paved roads and rough terrain alike. I just don't understand the people that write that it moves around as they ride. The field of view is perfect for the size and gives the rider all the info you need at a glance. It's multi adjustments assures a perfect POV for all size riders. When you assemble it prior to installing it on your bike, you'll notice the brass threads that you screw the Allen bolts into. The brass is a softer metal and makes for a tighter fit...so as you assemble the mirror, don't be discouraged as to how hard it is to screw the bolts into the threads...it's meant to be like that. It comes with the Allen wrench so you can leave it in your seat bag if you need it. The only time I loosen it up is to turn the bike upside down to adjust something or fix a tire. {"overall": 4.0, "verified": true, "reviewTime": "08 4, 2015", "reviewerID": "A2QNXPU9C7JMX1", "asin": "B0009R96YK", "style": {"Color:": " Black 1 Mirror"}, "reviewerName": "Amazon Customer", "reviewText": "I wanted a mirror but I wanted to keep it small, and this fills that need nicely.  The mirror is convex so it shows a fairly large area behind, and yet it's not too strongly curved so the things I want to see are big enough to recognize.  It arrived in a very small box because it's completely disassembled, but it was quick and easy to assemble and to mount very securely on the end of my handlebar.  There are really only two small issues that keep me from giving it 5 stars:  It's nearly impossible to adjust the mirror while riding--there are cap screws holding everything tight--so it took some trial and error to find the best position.  And because it's small and right on the end of the handlebar, it took some experimenting to find a position that wouldn't show my a lot of my forearm at the expense of overtaking vehicles.  But knowing what I know now, I'd gladly buy it again.", "summary": "Good little mirror", "unixReviewTime": 1438646400}
